description: These episodes will provide the foundational knowledge needed get you started in the world of IT security, which covers a wide range of topics from password policies to risk assessment to the three main areas of information security, which address the confidentiality, integrity and availability of data and keeping it secure. This course provides great starting point for those that are new to the world of IT security.
name: Security Fundamentals
subtitle: Core security concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss the basics of Information Security. They focus on the CIA triad security model, defining each component, and providing examples.
episodes.title: Information Security
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11,170 --> 00:00:16,970
All right, welcome to the first episode
of security fundamentals here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:16,970 --> 00:00:19,960
I'm your host, Don Pezet, and
I've got our resident security expert,

4
00:00:19,960 --> 00:00:21,470
Mike Roderick, here with me.

5
00:00:21,470 --> 00:00:25,990
And we're about to embark upon a journey,
a journey of IT security or

6
00:00:25,990 --> 00:00:30,690
information security and
all of the things that a regular,

7
00:00:30,690 --> 00:00:33,860
average, run-of-the-mill employee needs
to be familiar with if you're going to

8
00:00:33,860 --> 00:00:36,520
be using computers and
more importantly using the Internet.

9
00:00:36,520 --> 00:00:40,600
There's a lot of pitfalls and things that
we need to watch out for out there, and

10
00:00:40,600 --> 00:00:42,590
the information security
umbrella is a big one.

11
00:00:42,590 --> 00:00:44,880
It covers a lot of different topics.

12
00:00:44,880 --> 00:00:48,040
So that's what we're gonna be tackling as
we go through this series, each episode,

13
00:00:48,040 --> 00:00:50,790
grabbing different areas of
what we need to be aware of.

14
00:00:50,790 --> 00:00:53,270
And boy, there's a lot we need to
be aware of, isn't there, Mike?

15
00:00:53,270 --> 00:00:54,620
>> There really is, Don.

16
00:00:54,620 --> 00:00:56,830
And before we dive into all
those different things,

17
00:00:56,830 --> 00:00:59,580
I think one of the things we want
to make sure we have is a good

18
00:00:59,580 --> 00:01:02,820
foundational knowledge
about information security.

19
00:01:02,820 --> 00:01:06,630
We talk about security and
the need for it, but what do we mean?

20
00:01:06,630 --> 00:01:09,650
What do we mean by that
foundational security?

21
00:01:09,650 --> 00:01:12,590
There are several different
models out there that we can use,

22
00:01:12,590 --> 00:01:17,400
and one of the most common ones
is known as the CIA triad.

23
00:01:17,400 --> 00:01:18,260
Now when I talk about that,

24
00:01:18,260 --> 00:01:21,380
I'm not referring to
the Central Intelligence Agency

25
00:01:21,380 --> 00:01:24,380
that we find here in the US or
anything like that.

26
00:01:24,380 --> 00:01:29,530
The CIA triad is a very accepted
security model that allows us to

27
00:01:29,530 --> 00:01:34,490
kind of test or verify that our
security methods and policies

28
00:01:34,490 --> 00:01:37,970
that we put in place in an organization
are doing what they're supposed to do,

29
00:01:37,970 --> 00:01:41,530
and they're indeed keeping
our information safe.

30
00:01:41,530 --> 00:01:43,020
They call it the CIA triad.

31
00:01:43,020 --> 00:01:46,430
It's got three main points,
hence the name triad.

32
00:01:46,430 --> 00:01:49,660
And the C stands for confidentiality,

33
00:01:49,660 --> 00:01:54,470
the I is going to be integrity,
and the A is for availability.

34
00:01:54,470 --> 00:01:59,800
All three of those are very key components
when it comes to information security.

35
00:01:59,800 --> 00:02:02,470
>> And it's important that we at least
have a basic grasp of what each of those

36
00:02:02,470 --> 00:02:03,560
three ideas are,

37
00:02:03,560 --> 00:02:08,080
because information security more than
likely expands beyond what you think of.

38
00:02:08,080 --> 00:02:10,900
When people think of information security,
they think of stuff we do on computers,

39
00:02:10,900 --> 00:02:13,120
right, anti-virus, firewalls.

40
00:02:13,120 --> 00:02:18,250
But it expands even beyond that to things
like locked doors and insurance policies

41
00:02:18,250 --> 00:02:22,100
and things you wouldn't even normally
associate with computers, but are equally

42
00:02:22,100 --> 00:02:26,810
important to maintaining a functioning,
safe and secure IT environment.

43
00:02:26,810 --> 00:02:30,270
So Mike, let's break each one of these
down and give everybody kind of an idea of

44
00:02:30,270 --> 00:02:33,040
what they mean, what they do,
why they're important.

45
00:02:33,040 --> 00:02:34,446
And let's start off with confidentiality.

46
00:02:34,446 --> 00:02:35,755
>> All right, it's a good place to start.

47
00:02:35,755 --> 00:02:38,570
It's one of the more easy ones,
I think, for people to understand.

48
00:02:38,570 --> 00:02:41,990
They might have dealt with
this in one way or the other.

49
00:02:41,990 --> 00:02:46,420
Confidentiality, as you're probably aware,
just means making sure that the data or

50
00:02:46,420 --> 00:02:50,950
whatever it is we're trying to
protect remains confidential.

51
00:02:50,950 --> 00:02:54,200
In other words,
only the authorized people or

52
00:02:54,200 --> 00:03:00,395
entities have access to that information,
whether that's data or access to

53
00:03:00,395 --> 00:03:05,155
the server closet or something like that,
keeping that information confidential.

54
00:03:05,155 --> 00:03:08,435
>> And that's pretty challenging
because in the early days of computing,

55
00:03:08,435 --> 00:03:09,425
networks were small.

56
00:03:09,425 --> 00:03:11,265
You only had a couple of computers.

57
00:03:11,265 --> 00:03:14,155
They were private inside
individual businesses, and

58
00:03:14,155 --> 00:03:17,095
you didn't have to worry about somebody
intercepting your data as it moved between

59
00:03:17,095 --> 00:03:19,615
machines that were right
there in the same room.

60
00:03:19,615 --> 00:03:22,060
And so as we grew and
the Internet developed,

61
00:03:22,060 --> 00:03:26,850
a lot of those technologies were not
prepared to hide or secure your data.

62
00:03:26,850 --> 00:03:30,310
And so
technologies we use every day like email,

63
00:03:30,310 --> 00:03:33,630
email is sent across
the Internet in plain text.

64
00:03:33,630 --> 00:03:36,010
Anybody could intercept that and
read your email.

65
00:03:36,010 --> 00:03:38,430
It is not a secure
communication mechanism.

66
00:03:38,430 --> 00:03:42,360
So we've had to take additional
steps to secure our data,

67
00:03:42,360 --> 00:03:45,210
to protect it, and
that's what confidentiality is all about.

68
00:03:45,210 --> 00:03:49,680
If I send an email to Mike, I want to
make sure that only Mike can read that.

69
00:03:49,680 --> 00:03:52,160
I don't want just anybody to be
able to grab that and read it.

70
00:03:52,160 --> 00:03:55,350
Or if it's my mortgage documents,
my banking, tax records,

71
00:03:55,350 --> 00:03:59,100
whatever, I want to make sure that
I can keep that data private.

72
00:03:59,100 --> 00:04:01,200
And that's what
confidentiality is all about.

73
00:04:01,200 --> 00:04:02,910
>> Exactly.
There's several different things we can

74
00:04:02,910 --> 00:04:05,560
use to provide that confidentiality.

75
00:04:05,560 --> 00:04:08,060
One of the big ones is
going to be encryption.

76
00:04:08,060 --> 00:04:10,590
Encryption allows me to take something.

77
00:04:10,590 --> 00:04:11,540
We use these fancy terms.

78
00:04:11,540 --> 00:04:15,110
We take something called plain
text which is human readable and

79
00:04:15,110 --> 00:04:18,790
convert it into something
we call cipher text.

80
00:04:18,790 --> 00:04:23,460
Which means in order to read it I'm gonna
need the appropriate key to decrypt and

81
00:04:23,460 --> 00:04:25,370
retrieve that plain text back out.

82
00:04:25,370 --> 00:04:29,260
And it's one of the most common ways
to provide that confidentiality.

83
00:04:29,260 --> 00:04:32,900
Because if you don't have access to the
key then you're not gonna be able to get

84
00:04:32,900 --> 00:04:34,430
access to that data.

85
00:04:34,430 --> 00:04:38,050
I can show you a real quick
example here of some encryption.

86
00:04:38,050 --> 00:04:41,240
What I've got on my screen here
is just a spreadsheet, and

87
00:04:41,240 --> 00:04:42,980
I've made a basic cipher algorithm.

88
00:04:42,980 --> 00:04:44,840
This is,
if you're familiar with encryption,

89
00:04:44,840 --> 00:04:47,340
this is what's known as a Caesar cipher.

90
00:04:47,340 --> 00:04:49,720
It's just a shift in characters.

91
00:04:49,720 --> 00:04:54,180
Across the top, I have our English
alphabet, my letters here.

92
00:04:54,180 --> 00:04:58,670
On the next row you can see it's the same
alphabet but everything is shifted over,

93
00:04:58,670 --> 00:05:01,050
in this case by three characters, and

94
00:05:01,050 --> 00:05:04,510
then at the end it wraps
back around after the Z.

95
00:05:04,510 --> 00:05:06,650
We go back to the A, B and C.

96
00:05:06,650 --> 00:05:09,350
And all I'm going to do
to do the encryption

97
00:05:09,350 --> 00:05:12,250
is to find the letter I'm looking for
across that top row.

98
00:05:12,250 --> 00:05:15,150
Let's say I want to encrypt the letter K.

99
00:05:15,150 --> 00:05:18,850
Well, the letter K simply becomes an N,
all right?

100
00:05:18,850 --> 00:05:23,970
So if we take an example here, I've got my
plain text, my human readable hello world.

101
00:05:23,970 --> 00:05:27,400
My cipher text then,
the first letter would be an h.

102
00:05:27,400 --> 00:05:29,960
And if I look at the h, that becomes a k.

103
00:05:29,960 --> 00:05:33,460
So you can see the first letter
of my cipher text is a k.

104
00:05:33,460 --> 00:05:37,722
The next letter was an e,
which becomes an h, so there's my h, and

105
00:05:37,722 --> 00:05:42,800
on down the road proceeding letter
by letter through that plain text.

106
00:05:42,800 --> 00:05:46,250
So now this is known as my cipher text.

107
00:05:46,250 --> 00:05:47,990
This is my encrypted form.

108
00:05:47,990 --> 00:05:50,930
And if you didn't know,
if I was to erase this.

109
00:05:53,270 --> 00:05:56,560
You didn't know what
the original text was and

110
00:05:56,560 --> 00:06:01,570
if you didn't know what algorithm,
what method I use to encrypt that data or

111
00:06:01,570 --> 00:06:06,440
the key I used, more specifically, then
you would not be able to read that data.

112
00:06:06,440 --> 00:06:07,630
If you know the key, though,

113
00:06:07,630 --> 00:06:11,850
if you know I shifted three characters
to the right, all you would have to do

114
00:06:11,850 --> 00:06:15,810
then to decrypt it would be to shift
three characters back to the left.

115
00:06:15,810 --> 00:06:17,380
So you would just do the opposite.

116
00:06:17,380 --> 00:06:20,490
A k then would go back to an h,
and on down the row.

117
00:06:20,490 --> 00:06:22,230
And you can get
the original text back out.

118
00:06:22,230 --> 00:06:24,800
But if you don't know the key,
you're not gonna get access or

119
00:06:24,800 --> 00:06:26,320
you're not gonna get that data.

120
00:06:26,320 --> 00:06:29,240
>> Yeah, now what Mike just showed
you guys is a very simple cipher,

121
00:06:29,240 --> 00:06:30,730
one we could do in our head.

122
00:06:30,730 --> 00:06:34,790
The ciphers that your computer
uses are far more advanced.

123
00:06:34,790 --> 00:06:39,140
Using hundreds or even thousands of bits
of encryption security to be able to give

124
00:06:39,140 --> 00:06:44,490
you cipher text that is near impossible
to reverse unless you've got that key.

125
00:06:44,490 --> 00:06:48,770
So every time you browse to a website and
it goes to a secure connection,

126
00:06:48,770 --> 00:06:50,000
that little lock appears.

127
00:06:50,000 --> 00:06:53,340
Or every time you fire up
your company VPN connection.

128
00:06:53,340 --> 00:06:58,420
Any time you do that kind of stuff,
you're doing really strong encryption

129
00:06:58,420 --> 00:07:02,480
on the back-end that would be very,
very difficult for somebody to break in.

130
00:07:02,480 --> 00:07:07,095
And that means any data you transmit
over that connection is confidential.

131
00:07:07,095 --> 00:07:10,410
Only you and the person you're
connecting to will be able to read and

132
00:07:10,410 --> 00:07:13,040
understand that data
because you have that key.

133
00:07:13,040 --> 00:07:18,080
Everybody else just sees garbled gibberish
on the network and your data is safe.

134
00:07:18,080 --> 00:07:21,150
So inside of the information
security world,

135
00:07:21,150 --> 00:07:24,370
confidentiality is one of the things
that we've got to provide.

136
00:07:24,370 --> 00:07:29,303
Everything that we do in terms of
information security should contribute to

137
00:07:29,303 --> 00:07:33,090
at least one of the three little
contents of the CIA triad.

138
00:07:33,090 --> 00:07:36,432
VPNs, SSL,
they all contribute to confidentiality.

139
00:07:36,432 --> 00:07:39,460
>> And encryption's not the only way
that we provide confidentiality.

140
00:07:39,460 --> 00:07:42,410
In fact, just using your user ID and
password, right?

141
00:07:42,410 --> 00:07:45,700
When you log onto your system at work,
you've got your My Documents and

142
00:07:45,700 --> 00:07:48,340
those other folders that
only you have access to.

143
00:07:49,420 --> 00:07:51,810
Once you log on, you get access to those.

144
00:07:51,810 --> 00:07:52,861
I don't have access to those, for example.

145
00:07:52,861 --> 00:07:55,431
Your coworkers can't get into
your My Documents folder.

146
00:07:55,431 --> 00:07:57,261
So that ID, that username and

147
00:07:57,261 --> 00:08:00,931
password is providing a layer
Of confidentiality as well.

148
00:08:00,931 --> 00:08:03,281
Access control is Donner
doing the same thing.

149
00:08:03,281 --> 00:08:07,820
We go to a resource and
say an NTFS partition.

150
00:08:07,820 --> 00:08:12,120
We can control who has read and
who has right, who has full control and

151
00:08:12,120 --> 00:08:13,260
things like that.

152
00:08:13,260 --> 00:08:15,990
That is again, giving us another
level of confidentiality.

153
00:08:15,990 --> 00:08:19,230
Remember confidentiality doesn't
necessarily mean you don't get access to

154
00:08:19,230 --> 00:08:20,260
the data at all.

155
00:08:20,260 --> 00:08:22,770
But I can control what level
of access you have too.

156
00:08:22,770 --> 00:08:26,430
So that's another part of confidentiality
and we talk about security.

157
00:08:26,430 --> 00:08:31,730
We're always gonna talk about layers of
defense having more than one layer so

158
00:08:31,730 --> 00:08:34,162
we can start combining
these methods as well.

159
00:08:34,162 --> 00:08:36,812
You're gonna have to have
a password to log on to my system.

160
00:08:36,812 --> 00:08:39,798
You're gonna have to have
permissions to access that file, and

161
00:08:39,798 --> 00:08:42,510
you're gonna need the key
to decrypt that file.

162
00:08:42,510 --> 00:08:44,780
So we can add all three
of those layers for

163
00:08:44,780 --> 00:08:48,570
example, to provide that confidentiality
for that particular document.

164
00:08:48,570 --> 00:08:51,570
>> And don't forget the low tech
solutions that factor into this.

165
00:08:51,570 --> 00:08:53,090
If I want to keep my computer safe,

166
00:08:53,090 --> 00:08:56,220
it might be as simple as locking
the door to my office, right?

167
00:08:56,220 --> 00:08:59,230
Now, somebody can't physically get
in the room where my computer is and

168
00:08:59,230 --> 00:09:01,720
my data stays private or

169
00:09:01,720 --> 00:09:06,190
when I'm throwing papers away that I
printed I run them through a shredder.

170
00:09:06,190 --> 00:09:09,360
That shredder is part of what's providing
confidentiality, nobody is gonna be able

171
00:09:09,360 --> 00:09:11,920
to read these documents cause I've
destroyed them at this point.

172
00:09:11,920 --> 00:09:14,890
So confidentiality is a big area, and

173
00:09:14,890 --> 00:09:18,850
in information security we're
securing the information.

174
00:09:18,850 --> 00:09:20,130
We're not securing technology.

175
00:09:20,130 --> 00:09:21,740
We're not securing just our computer.

176
00:09:21,740 --> 00:09:25,460
It's the information in all of its forms,
and that's why it's such a big topic.

177
00:09:25,460 --> 00:09:26,690
>> Exactly.

178
00:09:26,690 --> 00:09:29,770
All right, and if we move on into our
triad then we got confidentiality.

179
00:09:29,770 --> 00:09:31,730
That's our first leg of our triad.

180
00:09:31,730 --> 00:09:34,910
The next leg is gonna be
something known as integrity.

181
00:09:34,910 --> 00:09:37,170
And really if we wanna define
integrity in a simple way,

182
00:09:37,170 --> 00:09:39,100
it just means to make sure that the data,

183
00:09:39,100 --> 00:09:43,690
the information is not modified
either maliciously or accidentally.

184
00:09:43,690 --> 00:09:45,940
It doesn't have to be
an intentional attack.

185
00:09:45,940 --> 00:09:47,900
All right, we could have data
corruption and things like that.

186
00:09:47,900 --> 00:09:52,050
So integrity is all about making
sure that the data is not modified,

187
00:09:52,050 --> 00:09:54,605
that it remains as it was intended.

188
00:09:54,605 --> 00:09:58,650
>> Yeah, if you're using
a network like the Internet,

189
00:09:58,650 --> 00:10:01,940
you're passing across routers
that you don't control,

190
00:10:01,940 --> 00:10:04,460
that you don't necessarily even know
the companies that are involved in.

191
00:10:04,460 --> 00:10:07,780
So you may pass across 10,
15 different routers, that means 10 or

192
00:10:07,780 --> 00:10:09,780
15 different Internet service providers.

193
00:10:09,780 --> 00:10:12,370
Anybody along that journey
could intercept your traffic.

194
00:10:12,370 --> 00:10:14,830
Well it's bad enough they intercept it and
read it, but

195
00:10:14,830 --> 00:10:16,740
if they want to go really bad.

196
00:10:16,740 --> 00:10:20,020
They can modify that traffic and
then send it along and

197
00:10:20,020 --> 00:10:24,140
it looks like it came from you but it's
been modified beyond your original intent.

198
00:10:24,140 --> 00:10:27,180
That means the integrity has
been broken for your data.

199
00:10:27,180 --> 00:10:31,320
We need ways to validate that integrity to
ensure that our information hasn't been

200
00:10:31,320 --> 00:10:32,000
tampered with.

201
00:10:32,000 --> 00:10:35,150
And there's a number of technologies
out there that can do it.

202
00:10:35,150 --> 00:10:38,830
So Mike, you've got an example
of like an integrity violation.

203
00:10:38,830 --> 00:10:39,640
>> I do, exactly.

204
00:10:39,640 --> 00:10:43,220
I've got a simple little drawing I drew
up here in this is a great example.

205
00:10:43,220 --> 00:10:45,590
This is what can happen out
there in the real world.

206
00:10:45,590 --> 00:10:50,420
I've got a situation where Alice wants
to send a check say over to Adam.

207
00:10:50,420 --> 00:10:55,230
So initially she writes this check and
it says, pay to Adam the amount of $100.

208
00:10:55,230 --> 00:10:58,970
But somewhere during
the transmission of that information

209
00:10:58,970 --> 00:11:01,960
we can see there was
an unauthorized modification.

210
00:11:01,960 --> 00:11:05,160
And when that check is to the other end,
all of a sudden it says

211
00:11:05,160 --> 00:11:09,370
not Adam getting a $100, but
it says Don is retrieving a 100,000.

212
00:11:09,370 --> 00:11:10,840
Wait, did you change that on?

213
00:11:10,840 --> 00:11:11,488
>> I love this example.

214
00:11:11,488 --> 00:11:12,980
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's my favorite example in

215
00:11:12,980 --> 00:11:13,610
the whole show.

216
00:11:13,610 --> 00:11:18,335
>> Somehow, Don became the recipient
of that $100,000 check there but

217
00:11:18,335 --> 00:11:21,842
that's a great example of
where integrity was not kept.

218
00:11:21,842 --> 00:11:22,920
>> Right.

219
00:11:22,920 --> 00:11:25,650
>> We lost our integrity
on that information.

220
00:11:25,650 --> 00:11:28,554
>> So one great way that we can ensure
that integrity is through the use of

221
00:11:28,554 --> 00:11:30,270
something called a digital signature.

222
00:11:30,270 --> 00:11:34,945
And a digital signature is where we run
like a little mathematical algorithm

223
00:11:34,945 --> 00:11:38,590
against the data and
it creates a certain number.

224
00:11:38,590 --> 00:11:42,660
And when somebody receives the data
that we're sending they can run the same

225

algorithm and they should get the same

push heat out, and
the servers went into thermal shutdown.

455
00:23:03,920 --> 00:23:05,671
So, they didn't even
have get in the building.

456
00:23:05,671 --> 00:23:07,541
They didn't even have to
know how to hack anything.

457
00:23:07,541 --> 00:23:09,780
They just stuck sticks in
the air conditioning units.

458
00:23:09,780 --> 00:23:11,151
>> It could have been
a ten-year-old doing this.

459
00:23:11,151 --> 00:23:13,621
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and the way you prevent that?

460
00:23:13,621 --> 00:23:14,511
You put up a fence.

461
00:23:14,511 --> 00:23:17,131
A fence with some razor wire or whatever.

462
00:23:17,131 --> 00:23:18,541
Now people can't get to the AC units.

463
00:23:18,541 --> 00:23:22,060
It's easy to overlook physical security.

464
00:23:22,060 --> 00:23:23,000
It's not, you know,

465
00:23:23,000 --> 00:23:25,731
you don't have to have a PhD in
Computer Science to put up a fence.

466
00:23:25,731 --> 00:23:27,991
So that kind of stuff is easy overlook.

467
00:23:27,991 --> 00:23:32,351
And a guard that patrols a building,
that helps with availability.

468
00:23:32,351 --> 00:23:34,569
Right.
We deter somebody trying to break in when

469
00:23:34,569 --> 00:23:36,821
they see somebody
patrolling that building.

470
00:23:36,821 --> 00:23:40,741
These are all steps that fall
under information security.

471
00:23:40,741 --> 00:23:45,500
So don't pigeon-hole your mind into
thinking just of computers when it

472
00:23:45,500 --> 00:23:47,691
comes to information security.

473
00:23:47,691 --> 00:23:50,601
It's not all about firewalls,
and VPNs, and antivirus.

474
00:23:50,601 --> 00:23:55,216
It's also about more mundane
things like insurance policies,

475
00:23:55,216 --> 00:23:59,151
security guards, locked doors,
that kind of stuff.

476
00:23:59,151 --> 00:24:02,631
>> And it's not just the security,
the IT people that are responsible for

477
00:24:02,631 --> 00:24:03,391
this, right?

478
00:24:03,391 --> 00:24:06,641
It's you, it's I,
it's everybody that uses that network.

479
00:24:06,641 --> 00:24:10,581
I've gotta make sure that I'm locking my
screen when I walk away from my computer.

480
00:24:10,581 --> 00:24:14,486
I've gotta make sure that I'm not
propping that backdoor open so

481
00:24:14,486 --> 00:24:17,621
that anybody could walk through and
not have a code.

482
00:24:17,621 --> 00:24:21,141
So we've got to make sure that we
understand that everybody's responsible.

483
00:24:21,141 --> 00:24:23,631
And that's really what
CIA triad is all about.

484
00:24:23,631 --> 00:24:30,380
It's a general outline telling us what
it means to keep our information secure.

485
00:24:31,875 --> 00:24:35,070
>> Well, Mike, I think we've done a pretty
good job of running down the three

486
00:24:35,070 --> 00:24:36,706
main areas of information security.

487
00:24:36,706 --> 00:24:40,692
So that just to recap, we did
confidentiality, which is making sure that

488
00:24:40,692 --> 00:24:44,895
our data was only visible by people
we intended to be visible to.

489
00:24:44,895 --> 00:24:48,856
We did integrity to make sure that our
data wasn't modified after we sent it.

490
00:24:48,856 --> 00:24:52,245
So, if somebody gets it,
it is the way we intended it to be.

491
00:24:52,245 --> 00:24:53,381
And then, we did availability.

492
00:24:53,381 --> 00:24:57,317
Making sure that our information is
available to the people who want to use it

493
00:24:57,317 --> 00:24:58,621
when they want to use it.

494
00:24:58,621 --> 00:25:02,175
Those are the three main things that
we need to provide with any kind of

495
00:25:02,175 --> 00:25:05,621
information security environment,
and they're all critical.

496
00:25:05,621 --> 00:25:07,601
You can't just have one and
ignore the others.

497
00:25:07,601 --> 00:25:09,021
You've really got to work on all three.

498
00:25:09,021 --> 00:25:09,871
>> Exactly.

499
00:25:09,871 --> 00:25:11,703
Think about a tripod.
If you've got two legs on a tripod,

500
00:25:11,703 --> 00:25:13,161
it's not gonna stand up too well.

501
00:25:13,161 --> 00:25:14,950
[LAUGH] Gotta have all three legs there.

502
00:25:14,950 --> 00:25:17,911
>> We could have two, and like,
lean against the wall or something.

503
00:25:17,911 --> 00:25:19,401
[LAUGH]
>> A couple bookshelves on one side.

504
00:25:19,401 --> 00:25:20,981
>> All right.

505
00:25:20,981 --> 00:25:24,351
Well, ladies and gentlemen, I think it's a
good spot for us to wrap up this episode.

506
00:25:24,351 --> 00:25:26,801
I hope you guys enjoyed it,
and be sure to stay tuned.

507
00:25:26,801 --> 00:25:28,461
Right.
This is the first episode.

508
00:25:28,461 --> 00:25:30,241
We've got a whole series ahead of us.

509
00:25:30,241 --> 00:25:33,346
We're going to dive into all sorts
of different technologies and

510
00:25:33,346 --> 00:25:36,291
components that make up a good
information security policy.

511
00:25:36,291 --> 00:25:38,350
So, stay tuned for that.

512
00:25:38,350 --> 00:25:40,381
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pizet.

513
00:25:40,381 --> 00:25:41,431
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

514
00:25:41,431 --> 00:25:46,950
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss different authentication methods. They cover the different types authentication factors and give examples of each.
episodes.title: Authentication
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,470 --> 00:00:11,260
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11,260 --> 00:00:14,340
All right, welcome back to
another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14,340 --> 00:00:16,140
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

4
00:00:16,140 --> 00:00:17,670
Back again with Mr Mike Roderick.

5
00:00:17,670 --> 00:00:18,400
How's it going, Mike?

6
00:00:18,400 --> 00:00:19,430
>> It's going fantastic,

7
00:00:19,430 --> 00:00:23,080
Don, because we've got another episode of
our security fundamentals coming your way,

8
00:00:23,080 --> 00:00:27,360
and in this episode, we're going to
be talking about authentication.

9
00:00:27,360 --> 00:00:28,800
Very important part of security.

10
00:00:28,800 --> 00:00:32,860
I think most people kind of familiar
with the concept of authentication, but

11
00:00:32,860 --> 00:00:37,550
it's one of those ones where there's a lot
of misconceptions as well when it comes to

12
00:00:37,550 --> 00:00:38,280
authentication.

13
00:00:38,280 --> 00:00:39,340
So let's dive into it.

14
00:00:39,340 --> 00:00:42,940
Let's break it down and explain to
you all the different methods and

15
00:00:42,940 --> 00:00:45,010
ways that we can provide it an occasion.

16
00:00:45,010 --> 00:00:48,080
But before we go there, Don,
we wanna define authentication, right?

17
00:00:48,080 --> 00:00:50,330
Cuz it's one of those terms,
we hear all the time, but

18
00:00:50,330 --> 00:00:53,080
a lot of people misunderstand
what it actually means.

19
00:00:53,080 --> 00:00:56,420
And authentication,
what it boils down to is

20
00:00:56,420 --> 00:01:00,885
being able to prove the identity
of someone or something.

21
00:01:00,885 --> 00:01:02,585
It really doesn't have to be a person.

22
00:01:02,585 --> 00:01:05,435
A computer can authenticate as well.

23
00:01:05,435 --> 00:01:06,835
We can authenticate software, so

24
00:01:06,835 --> 00:01:09,085
there's different ways we go
about this authentication.

25
00:01:09,085 --> 00:01:13,325
We most commonly think about it
as us sitting at our computer or

26
00:01:13,325 --> 00:01:15,555
at our device and logging in.

27
00:01:15,555 --> 00:01:17,100
But there are others.

28
00:01:17,100 --> 00:01:20,210
And what I see a lot of times
is people will misunderstand

29
00:01:20,210 --> 00:01:23,440
the difference between
an authentication and authorization.

30
00:01:23,440 --> 00:01:25,800
They'll try to use those
terms interchangeably, and

31
00:01:25,800 --> 00:01:28,020
it's really important that we
understand the difference.

32
00:01:28,020 --> 00:01:30,720
Because if we're calling tech support of
if we're calling somebody to try to get

33
00:01:30,720 --> 00:01:33,590
help, and we're telling him it's
an authentication issue but

34
00:01:33,590 --> 00:01:37,460
it's actually an authorization issue,
that changes the troubleshooting method.

35
00:01:37,460 --> 00:01:40,170
It changes how they're going to
go about fixing that problem.

36
00:01:40,170 --> 00:01:42,980
So remember authentication
is proving your identity,

37
00:01:42,980 --> 00:01:45,970
or verifying the identity of someone or
something.

38
00:01:45,970 --> 00:01:50,190
Authorization is determining whether or
not that person or

39
00:01:50,190 --> 00:01:54,760
thing has permissions to access
whatever it is we're protecting.

40
00:01:54,760 --> 00:01:57,490
So I cannot authorize somebody

41
00:01:57,490 --> 00:01:59,630
unless they've gone through
with an occasion first.

42
00:01:59,630 --> 00:02:04,800
In other words, I can't tell you if you
have read permission over this document

43
00:02:04,800 --> 00:02:06,130
if I don't know who you are.

44
00:02:06,130 --> 00:02:09,230
So successful authentication
has to occur first.

45
00:02:09,230 --> 00:02:11,870
Authorization occurs after that.

46
00:02:11,870 --> 00:02:15,100
Remember authentication is
verifying your identity.

47
00:02:15,100 --> 00:02:18,650
And Don, there's several things we
can base authentication on, right?

48
00:02:18,650 --> 00:02:21,890
>> Yeah,
there is a whole just sordid array.

49
00:02:21,890 --> 00:02:25,770
And it ranges from technical matters
of authentication to non-technical.

50
00:02:25,770 --> 00:02:29,130
If you think about
authentication its basest level,

51
00:02:29,130 --> 00:02:31,660
be something like the locks on your house,
right?

52
00:02:31,660 --> 00:02:34,060
So if you have a lock on your front door.

53
00:02:34,060 --> 00:02:37,710
If you have the key you can unlock it,
and you can get in.

54
00:02:37,710 --> 00:02:38,570
You just authenticated.

55
00:02:38,570 --> 00:02:41,480
You said, I'm supposed to be
here because I have the key.

56
00:02:41,480 --> 00:02:45,040
But that's not a very good form
of authentication is it, right?

57
00:02:45,040 --> 00:02:47,070
Because if I leave
the key on the ground and

58
00:02:47,070 --> 00:02:51,580
somebody finds it they can
now be authenticated, right?

59
00:02:51,580 --> 00:02:54,600
And, are they supposed
to be there in my house?

60
00:02:54,600 --> 00:02:56,410
No, they just happened to get the key.

61
00:02:56,410 --> 00:02:58,700
So basic authentication
isn't very flexible, but

62
00:02:58,700 --> 00:03:01,380
in computers we can get really advanced.

63
00:03:01,380 --> 00:03:05,340
Now, the most common type of
authentication that we have out there is

64
00:03:05,340 --> 00:03:08,570
the username and
password combination, right?

65
00:03:08,570 --> 00:03:12,360
>> Yeah, and we talk about authentication,
there's really three main factors

66
00:03:12,360 --> 00:03:15,610
we can base authentication off of,
it's something you know or

67
00:03:15,610 --> 00:03:20,470
something you have or something you are.

68
00:03:20,470 --> 00:03:23,660
So those are the big three
security factors that we

69
00:03:23,660 --> 00:03:25,480
can use in the authentication method.

70
00:03:25,480 --> 00:03:26,870
And what Don's referred to, username and

71
00:03:26,870 --> 00:03:30,350
password, that's based on
something you know, right?

72
00:03:30,350 --> 00:03:33,750
You know the password that's
associated with your account.

73
00:03:33,750 --> 00:03:35,270
So if you can type it in,

74
00:03:35,270 --> 00:03:39,810
that's the computer's way of verifying
that you are the owner of that account.

75
00:03:39,810 --> 00:03:41,280
I don't know your password.

76
00:03:41,280 --> 00:03:42,890
I can't log in as you.

77
00:03:42,890 --> 00:03:46,800
So, and that's a very common method
because it's very easy to implement.

78
00:03:46,800 --> 00:03:49,720
And it's built into most of our
operating systems and our devices.

79
00:03:49,720 --> 00:03:54,370
So there's not extra hardware to manage or
maintain or anything like that.

80
00:03:54,370 --> 00:03:56,030
So it's very simple.

81
00:03:56,030 --> 00:03:56,670
It's easy.

82
00:03:56,670 --> 00:04:00,070
It's also one of the weaker forms
of authentication because it's so

83
00:04:00,070 --> 00:04:03,880
easy to people share their
password with other people.

84
00:04:03,880 --> 00:04:05,330
They write them down.

85
00:04:05,330 --> 00:04:08,530
Hackers try to guess your password or
break your password, so

86
00:04:08,530 --> 00:04:10,560
it is not the strongest method.

87
00:04:10,560 --> 00:04:13,380
In fact, after I say all that, you might
think, Well, why the heck do we use it?

88
00:04:13,380 --> 00:04:15,670
It's, again, because it's so
easy to implement.

89
00:04:15,670 --> 00:04:18,910
It's already built in to
most of the stuff we have.

90
00:04:18,910 --> 00:04:22,460
All right, let me show you a quick example
of authentication using user ID and

91
00:04:22,460 --> 00:04:22,990
password.

92
00:04:22,990 --> 00:04:27,130
Here I've got a Windows device pulled up,
and it's actually on my lock screen.

93
00:04:27,130 --> 00:04:28,640
I'm gonna just type in my password.

94
00:04:31,190 --> 00:04:34,390
If I type it in incorrectly,
I will get something like this.

95
00:04:34,390 --> 00:04:37,100
So I am not authenticated successful.

96
00:04:37,100 --> 00:04:39,520
>> And that was planned, right?
That was part of the lab.

97
00:04:39,520 --> 00:04:41,100
>> [LAUGH] I'll show you
what it looked like there.

98
00:04:41,100 --> 00:04:45,356
If I type in the password correctly,
I guess I should have told you that first.

99
00:04:45,356 --> 00:04:47,750
We can say that I'm able to
get back into my desktop.

100
00:04:47,750 --> 00:04:51,310
So that's one of the ways that we
can authentic, verify your identity.

101
00:04:51,310 --> 00:04:53,010
If you don't know the password,

102
00:04:53,010 --> 00:04:56,220
you're not going to be able to
hopefully get on to that system.

103
00:04:56,220 --> 00:04:57,690
>> Now that that type of authentication,

104
00:04:57,690 --> 00:05:02,860
that's not much different than the example
I gave of using the key to a house, right?

105
00:05:02,860 --> 00:05:04,850
With the key to the house,
you unlock it with that key,

106
00:05:04,850 --> 00:05:07,470
anybody could get that key from you and
get in.

107
00:05:07,470 --> 00:05:11,420
I could get Mike's password, and
if I log in as Mike, with his password,

108
00:05:11,420 --> 00:05:12,830
then it's gonna think that I'm him.

109
00:05:12,830 --> 00:05:15,460
It has no way of knowing
that I'm not Mike.

110
00:05:15,460 --> 00:05:17,310
I just happen to be somebody
who knows the password.

111
00:05:17,310 --> 00:05:20,820
>> Exactly, and that is one of the big
vulnerabilities of that method.

112
00:05:20,820 --> 00:05:26,460
It's just, again, so easy to implement
that it's still very commonly used.

113
00:05:26,460 --> 00:05:30,120
So back to something you know,
we got that that username and password.

114
00:05:30,120 --> 00:05:34,430
It could be a PIN that you had to punch
in, like on a door here, our building,

115
00:05:34,430 --> 00:05:38,330
we have entry way doors have
a little keypad on the side of them.

116
00:05:38,330 --> 00:05:41,980
And if I come up to that door, the door's
locked, it's got a magnetic lock on it.

117
00:05:41,980 --> 00:05:45,900
I can punch in the appropriate PIN,
and I can get that door to open.

118
00:05:45,900 --> 00:05:49,050
Also something you're probably
familiar with, secret questions.

119
00:05:49,050 --> 00:05:50,900
You see this a lot on websites now.

120
00:05:50,900 --> 00:05:54,290
All right, where you have to go in,
and you have to verify your identity.

121
00:05:54,290 --> 00:05:59,170
And they're gonna ask you the name of your
first pet or your mother's maiden name or

122
00:05:59,170 --> 00:06:00,330
something like that.

123
00:06:00,330 --> 00:06:04,010
Again, that's something that
hopefully only you know, and

124
00:06:04,010 --> 00:06:06,400
they can verify your identity that way.

125
00:06:06,400 --> 00:06:10,520
So first category of authentication
is based on something you know.

126
00:06:10,520 --> 00:06:14,380
Second category is going to be
based on something you have, and

127
00:06:14,380 --> 00:06:16,800
this is a system that
we're seeing more and

128
00:06:16,800 --> 00:06:21,850
more of, because the cost is
coming down on the equipment.

129
00:06:21,850 --> 00:06:27,260
This is things like key fobs or
smart cards and some of these are gonna

130
00:06:27,260 --> 00:06:30,200
cross boundaries and we'll explain
what I mean here in just a little bit.

131
00:06:30,200 --> 00:06:33,710
But something that's in your possession
is what we're talking about with this

132
00:06:33,710 --> 00:06:34,210
category.

133
00:06:34,210 --> 00:06:37,450
And Don,
I think you've got an example of a token

134
00:06:37,450 --> 00:06:39,680
which is an example of something you have.

135
00:06:39,680 --> 00:06:42,830
>> Yeah, actually I got two examples of
tokens cuz I use these personally, right?

136
00:06:42,830 --> 00:06:47,800
Now, for my own accounts whenever you have
a presence on the Internet, like if you

137
00:06:47,800 --> 00:06:51,800
have a Facebook page or Twitter or
whatever, people can discover you.

138
00:06:51,800 --> 00:06:54,250
It's kind of the whole
purpose of social media.

139
00:06:54,250 --> 00:06:57,870
Well, if they can discover you they
can attempt to log in as your account.

140
00:06:57,870 --> 00:07:00,155
If I know your email, email address,
or if I know Mike's email address,

141
00:07:00,155 --> 00:07:04,455
I can just try to log in as him, so if I
could get his password, I could get in.

142
00:07:04,455 --> 00:07:09,205
But it would be even harder to get in if
you combined it with something you have.

143
00:07:09,205 --> 00:07:10,555
So let me show you an example.

144
00:07:10,555 --> 00:07:13,765
I've got with me right here,
this is a hardware token.

145
00:07:13,765 --> 00:07:16,905
And this little guy right here,
I put it on my key chain.

146
00:07:16,905 --> 00:07:21,820
And whenever I go to a computer to log in,
I don't just put in my password.

147
00:07:21,820 --> 00:07:23,410
I also plug this in.

148
00:07:23,410 --> 00:07:26,090
It plugs right into the USB
port on my computer.

149
00:07:26,090 --> 00:07:29,500
Here, let me just kind of bring my
computer around so you guys can see it.

150
00:07:29,500 --> 00:07:32,860
I basically just take this and
I pop it right in the USB port.

151
00:07:32,860 --> 00:07:35,110
And you might've seen the little
blue light flicker a bit.

152
00:07:35,110 --> 00:07:38,970
When I go to log in, I just tap this and
the blue light lights up, and

153
00:07:38,970 --> 00:07:43,190
it's sending my authentication
credentials right here from this token.

154
00:07:43,190 --> 00:07:47,698
So if somebody wants to log in as me,
well, I can tell them my password, and

155
00:07:47,698 --> 00:07:51,649
they still wouldn't be able to get
in unless they had this token.

156
00:07:51,649 --> 00:07:55,642
Now, this is a physical token, something
that I actually have to have that I bought

157
00:07:55,642 --> 00:07:58,165
specifically for
the purposes of authentication.

158
00:07:58,165 --> 00:07:59,865
But it doesn't have to be like that.

159
00:07:59,865 --> 00:08:02,360
It could be something that you use For
other things.

160
00:08:02,360 --> 00:08:07,110
So for example I've got my cell phone,
and I use a little program on here.

161
00:08:07,110 --> 00:08:09,010
Let me just pull it up here real quick.

162
00:08:09,010 --> 00:08:12,450
A little program called
the Google Authenticator, and

163
00:08:12,450 --> 00:08:16,300
what it does is it displays
codes on my screen.

164
00:08:16,300 --> 00:08:19,130
So 700753, that's my code right now.

165
00:08:19,130 --> 00:08:22,890
And you might notice this little kind
of pie over here that's getting smaller

166
00:08:22,890 --> 00:08:23,890
and smaller.

167

00:27:00,930 --> 00:27:04,350
Otherwise there's really no point

551
00:27:04,350 --> 00:27:08,990
And if you ever think your password

552
00:27:08,990 --> 00:27:11,520
I mean there's no sense

553
00:27:11,520 --> 00:27:16,630
If you think somebody saw you typing

Now if you made a mistake and

00:27:18,830 --> 00:27:23,430
you sent your password via email

556
00:27:23,430 --> 00:27:25,590
It's better to be safe than sorry.

557
00:27:25,590 --> 00:27:29,640
>> Yeah, this is definitely an area

558
00:27:29,640 --> 00:27:34,460
Anytime that you think,

00:27:34,460 --> 00:27:39,470
I'm seeing some funny activity from my
Yahoo account, or something like that.

00:27:39,470 --> 00:27:40,310
Just change the password.

562
00:27:42,120 --> 00:27:44,270

563
00:27:44,270 --> 00:27:45,790
A lot of websites do anymore.

564
00:27:45,790 --> 00:27:47,810
Hey, it's been a while since
you changed your password.

565
00:27:47,810 --> 00:27:50,400
Why don't you go ahead and do that now and
give you that opportunity.

566
00:27:50,400 --> 00:27:51,870
I mean, all you did was log in, and

00:27:51,870 --> 00:27:57,020
they jump you right to that page because
they understand how necessary it is to,

568
00:27:57,020 --> 00:28:00,260
at random, change your password,
keep that complexity.

569
00:28:00,260 --> 00:28:03,600
And then like Mike was saying before about
sharing your password being a no-no.

570
00:28:03,600 --> 00:28:07,484
Working in IT as administrators
we see it all the time.

571
00:28:07,484 --> 00:28:12,830
And if you're just an end user, and you're
thinking, man, this isn't a big deal.

572
00:28:12,830 --> 00:28:15,890
I work with Sue, and
she's a nice person, right?

573
00:28:15,890 --> 00:28:19,025
Well maybe Sue gets angry at
the company one day, right?

574
00:28:19,025 --> 00:28:23,945
Maybe Sue is awesome today, and tomorrow
she's mad and she decides to do something,

575
00:28:23,945 --> 00:28:25,405
and you guys share a password.

576
00:28:25,405 --> 00:28:28,405
Well now it's either you or Sue that
did it, and Sue's not gonna go oh,

577
00:28:28,405 --> 00:28:30,065
it was me, it was me.

578
00:28:30,065 --> 00:28:33,245
She's gonna mm, I'm not,
here it's this guy over here, right?

579
00:28:33,245 --> 00:28:35,261
So that's something you'd want to avoid.

580
00:28:35,261 --> 00:28:40,090
It just makes it easy to keep you out of
trouble to not share those passwords.

581
00:28:40,090 --> 00:28:43,200
Make sure that everything you
do was legitimately done by you.

582
00:28:43,200 --> 00:28:43,820
>> Exactly, exactly.

583
00:28:45,580 --> 00:28:49,270
All right, well Dan I think we've covered
passwords pretty thoroughly there.

584
00:28:49,270 --> 00:28:51,340
>> Awesome.
Hopefully our users out there got a lot

out of this and understand the importance

00:28:54,460 --> 00:28:57,000
Yeah, can it be a pain

It sure can, but it's our best and

first line of defense against
anything that might happen.

00:29:02,150 --> 00:29:05,180
So it's good for us to understand
these things, why we do it and

590
00:29:05,180 --> 00:29:06,920
how we should be doing it properly.

591
00:29:06,920 --> 00:29:07,930
All right, Mike.

592
00:29:07,930 --> 00:29:10,930
That being said, I guess we've come

593
00:29:10,930 --> 00:29:12,320
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it.

594
00:29:12,320 --> 00:29:15,690

22
00:01:00,840 --> 00:01:07,420
All right, when we talk about a virus,

23

encompassing term for

24

25

Malware actually comes from
the combination of malicious software and

26

we shorten them, squish them together,

27
00:01:21,042 --> 00:01:26,960
Virus is just one category of malware and
really a virus is categorized by or

28
00:01:26,960 --> 00:01:30,730
what makes it a virus is
the way that it spreads, right?

29
00:01:30,730 --> 00:01:36,280
A virus is a piece of malware that

30
00:01:36,280 --> 00:01:41,170

typically some type of executable

31
00:01:41,170 --> 00:01:44,570

that you get a hold of this file.

32
00:01:44,570 --> 00:01:50,000
You download something from the Internet
or a friend sends you something right and

00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:52,870

00:01:52,870 --> 00:01:57,260
install something on your machine and
it is, but it's not what you thought.

35
00:01:57,260 --> 00:02:01,350
And then what happens is, is that virus
once you've run that infected program,

36
00:02:01,350 --> 00:02:05,710
that virus is now sitting up in memory on
your computer, and everything else that

37
00:02:05,710 --> 00:02:10,380
you open up, it can try to attach to and
things that you don't realize.

38
00:02:10,380 --> 00:02:15,110
And then you share those files with

39
00:02:15,110 --> 00:02:16,610

40
00:02:16,610 --> 00:02:20,720
So the thing about a virus is that it

41
00:02:20,720 --> 00:02:25,160
And it really does need our help,

42
00:02:25,160 --> 00:02:29,070
And Daniel, I know you've obviously

00:02:31,980 --> 00:02:32,590
>> Oh yeah.

46

They get pretty dirty.

47
00:02:33,570 --> 00:02:35,700
They will definitely do some stuff.

48
00:02:35,700 --> 00:02:38,460
One of the worst things they can do

49
00:02:38,460 --> 00:02:41,200
This is probably the worst thing

50
00:02:41,200 --> 00:02:43,220
because now, all my stuff is gone.

00:02:43,220 --> 00:02:47,160
Hopefully we do things like backups and

it's situations like this that make

That is why we do these things and

virus propagation is something

What's going on?

And I'm like, well,

00:03:25,690 --> 00:03:30,390
obviously we need to do a better job of
informing our users on what we need, how

67
00:03:30,390 --> 00:03:34,880
we can avoid those viruses from actually
getting our systems in the first place.

00:03:34,880 --> 00:03:36,760
>> Exactly.
So viruses can be very bad,

00:03:40,660 --> 00:03:44,140
the brain of your computer

I won't be able to do anything else.

I try to click on something and

Several different things, like you said,

it could access personal information on

as you said starting deleting

00:04:09,900 --> 00:04:15,150

00:04:39,360 --> 00:04:42,310

92
00:04:42,310 --> 00:04:46,880
Now, it could just be the program itself

00:04:46,880 --> 00:04:47,770

All the time things are slowing down,

00:05:36,230 --> 00:05:39,220
I don't want viruses, so

00:05:39,220 --> 00:05:40,740
Right?
That's going to protect me,

00:06:41,290 --> 00:06:42,672
Which one do you want?

00:06:42,672 --> 00:06:43,430
What [INAUDIBLE] buy free.

00:06:43,430 --> 00:06:44,910
Some of them are pay.

Is the pay better than the free?

00:06:46,330 --> 00:06:48,630
Well, you know it really

00:06:48,630 --> 00:06:51,870
What you want is an antivirus

00:06:51,870 --> 00:06:53,690

00:06:53,690 --> 00:06:58,620
If I install that antivirus software and

00:07:01,860 --> 00:07:06,070
Yeah, it might be keeping me safe but

So I want one that's relatively light,

145
00:07:14,050 --> 00:07:17,070
I've got to make sure that it's being kept

00:07:17,070 --> 00:07:19,420

works in different ways but

00:07:19,420 --> 00:07:22,240

148
00:07:22,240 --> 00:07:26,810

00:07:26,810 --> 00:07:29,510
when they find an infected

00:07:29,510 --> 00:07:33,190

00:07:33,190 --> 00:07:34,720

152
00:07:34,720 --> 00:07:38,480

153
00:07:38,480 --> 00:07:40,840

154
00:07:40,840 --> 00:07:43,280
Cuz new viruses are being
detected every day,

155
00:07:43,280 --> 00:07:46,430
and they're putting out
new definitions every day.

156
00:07:46,430 --> 00:07:49,263
So I've gotta make sure that my
anti-virus software is being up to date.

157
00:07:49,263 --> 00:07:52,267
If I buy some software, and
it updates once a month,

158
00:07:52,267 --> 00:07:54,468
that's really pretty much useless.

159
00:07:54,468 --> 00:07:56,515
Because, like I said,
they're coming out every day.

160
00:07:56,515 --> 00:08:00,858
So you want anti-virus software that's
Being maintained, it's being kept up to

161
00:08:00,858 --> 00:08:05,610
date, and doesn't take a lot of resources,

00:08:05,610 --> 00:08:07,330
If they're doing updates every day, but

00:08:09,840 --> 00:08:14,180
Maybe they're just a slacker company,

00:08:16,420 --> 00:08:17,260
That's really,

00:08:17,260 --> 00:08:21,500
if I can find a free one that does all

Windows Defender, for example,

00:08:24,380 --> 00:08:27,360
It's built into your Windows operating

00:08:31,210 --> 00:08:33,360
So, it's kept up to date constantly.

00:08:45,780 --> 00:08:47,970
it made it really hard

00:08:47,970 --> 00:08:50,566
>> Yeah, I've used the corporate
versions of Symantec antivirus, and

00:08:50,566 --> 00:08:53,370
they do a really good job of finding

00:08:53,370 --> 00:08:53,870
>> .

00:25:33,380 --> 00:25:36,120
They're gonna say, hey,

521
00:25:36,120 --> 00:25:38,045

00:25:38,045 --> 00:25:40,098
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's how it works, and

00:25:40,098 --> 00:25:44,200
I know when you get a fake AV cuz I get

00:25:44,200 --> 00:25:46,310
I'm like,
are you getting some weird stuff?

00:25:46,310 --> 00:25:47,620
And you say, yeah, I am.

Did you click on that?

00:25:48,600 --> 00:25:52,050
And hopefully you say no, I didn't,

528
00:25:52,050 --> 00:25:55,670
That's the right answer, any time you

529
00:25:55,670 --> 00:25:59,310
>> That's the thing as an end-user it's

00:26:07,550 --> 00:26:11,410

00:26:12,770 --> 00:26:15,210
Most companies have a maybe
a web page they can go to or

see before you click on it.

Hey I got this thing that says I've got

You should if you think your company

It's a company-provided computer.

540
00:26:29,180 --> 00:26:32,086
So just check, you know,
it's better to be safe than sorry.

541
00:26:32,086 --> 00:26:34,370
Now Daniel, I wanted to go back for

542

We've talked about all these

All right, so what I've got on my screen

00:26:46,490 --> 00:26:49,240
they've got a free version as
well as a pay version and Daniel,

00:26:49,240 --> 00:26:51,320
it's probably one of my favorites.

It's one that I keep on a thumb drive just

549
00:26:54,700 --> 00:26:56,490
clean their machine,
and their machine is so

00:26:56,490 --> 00:27:00,340

00:27:00,340 --> 00:27:02,100
It does a fantastic job.

00:27:05,040 --> 00:27:06,640

00:27:06,640 --> 00:27:08,640
So what I've done is I went ahead and

00:27:16,760 --> 00:27:19,112

00:27:23,228 --> 00:27:28,660

00:27:29,340 --> 00:27:32,690
And I don't know if it'll

What I should be able to do is come in

566
00:27:38,782 --> 00:27:43,020

567
00:27:43,020 --> 00:27:46,450
Once that scan finishes, those items

568
00:27:46,450 --> 00:27:49,270
So what it's doing is it's grabbing
those things and saying hey,

569

570

I'm gonna grab it, and I'm not gonna

And then what I do is I come in here and I

But, I'll tell you, I've never had

577
00:28:17,780 --> 00:28:20,780

578
00:28:20,780 --> 00:28:23,970
>> Yeah, I've used it heavily and

579
00:28:23,970 --> 00:28:28,530
It is hands down one of the, it's a must

580
00:28:28,530 --> 00:28:30,240
And it's so easy to use.

581
00:28:30,240 --> 00:28:35,250
Anybody can use it's very, very simple,

582
00:28:35,250 --> 00:28:37,088
So if you want to run it
on your home machine,

583

it shouldn't be much of a problem.

584
00:28:38,598 --> 00:28:42,492
You can get these things from like

585
00:28:42,492 --> 00:28:46,563
straight from their website even if you
want, but I think their official portal is

586
00:28:46,563 --> 00:28:49,910
from download.com, but very,
very handy piece of software.

587
00:28:49,910 --> 00:28:52,890
It's a good thing just to run even if

588
00:28:52,890 --> 00:28:56,510
Run that guy once a month, you know,

00:28:56,510 --> 00:28:59,610
because it does a really good

00:28:59,610 --> 00:29:00,240

00:29:00,240 --> 00:29:04,800
The free version is reactive, where you

00:29:08,178 --> 00:29:10,870
The pay version will give

00:29:13,560 --> 00:29:17,740

596
00:29:17,740 --> 00:29:18,759
>> Yeah.
>> So Malwarebytes,

597
00:29:18,759 --> 00:29:21,045
go out there to malware,
I think it's malwarebytes.org.

598
00:29:21,045 --> 00:29:22,810
They've got a great web site.

599
00:29:22,810 --> 00:29:24,710
Get their product and use it.

600
00:29:24,710 --> 00:29:28,960
Like I said, I recommend it to all my
friends, my family, my mother uses it.

601
00:29:28,960 --> 00:29:31,850
It's a really good program and
it keeps us safe.

602
00:29:31,850 --> 00:29:36,140
As you guys saw throughout this episode,
lots of different types of malware,

603
00:29:36,140 --> 00:29:39,580
lots of ways for
the bad guys to get it on your machine.

00:29:39,580 --> 00:29:40,950
We can't stress it enough.

00:29:40,950 --> 00:29:43,750
You've got to try to keep yourself safe.

606
00:29:43,750 --> 00:29:46,090
That means using good practices,

00:29:46,090 --> 00:29:49,695
not clicking on things from people that

00:29:49,695 --> 00:29:53,510
Malwarebytes to scan my machine to make

All right,

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss the concept of social engineering. They define various types of social engineering, as well as give some examples. They also discuss how to protect against social engineering.
episodes.title: Social Engineering
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,012 --> 00:00:03,093
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03,093 --> 00:00:10,273
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10,273 --> 00:00:13,140
All right, welcome back to
another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:13,140 --> 00:00:16,920
I'm your host, Don Pezet,
today with me is Mr. Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:16,920 --> 00:00:17,740
How's it going, Mike?

6
00:00:17,740 --> 00:00:18,660
>> I'm doing fantastic,

7
00:00:18,660 --> 00:00:22,080
Don, we're getting ready to do another
episode of our security fundamentals.

8
00:00:22,080 --> 00:00:25,730
And in this episode we're gonna talk about
something known as social engineering.

9
00:00:25,730 --> 00:00:29,555
It's one of these terms that you've
probably heard about in the news or

10
00:00:29,555 --> 00:00:33,842
read about in some articles about these
security breaches that have occurred.

11
00:00:33,842 --> 00:00:36,012
And we're gonna take a look
at what it actually mean,

12
00:00:36,012 --> 00:00:38,990
what are they talking about,
this social engineering?

13
00:00:38,990 --> 00:00:39,660
>> Yeah, it is.

14
00:00:39,660 --> 00:00:42,790
It is a security buzzword,
you hear about it a lot, and

15
00:00:42,790 --> 00:00:46,494
it's one of those terms that doesn't
mean just one specific type of attack.

16
00:00:46,494 --> 00:00:49,120
It's actually a number of different
methods that we can use or

17
00:00:49,120 --> 00:00:52,520
trying to to pull off
a social engineering attack.

18
00:00:52,520 --> 00:00:56,680
But they all share a common element and
the common element is the target.

19
00:00:56,680 --> 00:00:58,580
The target is a person.

20
00:00:58,580 --> 00:01:02,140
We as human beings are often the weakest
link in a security structure, right Mike?

21
00:01:02,140 --> 00:01:02,990
>> We really are.

22
00:01:02,990 --> 00:01:06,140
This is one of the attacks that that
doesn't even have to take advantage of

23
00:01:06,140 --> 00:01:06,970
the technology.

24
00:01:06,970 --> 00:01:09,912
As Don said,
it's taking advantage of human nature.

25
00:01:09,912 --> 00:01:13,175
When we talk about social engineering,
we're not attacking the system,

26
00:01:13,175 --> 00:01:15,705
we're attacking the person
behind the system.

27
00:01:15,705 --> 00:01:20,255
And it's really very simple to do,
you see this done a lot,

28
00:01:20,255 --> 00:01:23,780
and it's a relatively
easy attack to carry off.

29
00:01:23,780 --> 00:01:27,820
And it's because of the way humans are,
the way we behave.

30
00:01:27,820 --> 00:01:33,050
Humans have this desire to be liked,
they want their friends to like them.

31
00:01:33,050 --> 00:01:36,030
They want to be recognized
among their peers.

32
00:01:36,030 --> 00:01:39,210
They want to make sure they
show respect for authority.

33
00:01:39,210 --> 00:01:40,990
Somebody in authority comes and

34
00:01:40,990 --> 00:01:44,360
ask you a question you typically
respond in the appropriate way.

35
00:01:44,360 --> 00:01:47,490
You're like, oh, this is my boss or
this is somebody that demands respect.

36
00:01:47,490 --> 00:01:49,880
I'm gonna respond to them in that way.

37
00:01:49,880 --> 00:01:51,100
Or just to prove knowledge.

38
00:01:51,100 --> 00:01:53,620
A lot of times it's taking
advantage of people that

39
00:01:53,620 --> 00:01:55,990
want to show off how much they know.

40
00:01:55,990 --> 00:01:59,450
So we're talking about attacking
the system with social engineering.

41
00:01:59,450 --> 00:02:02,130
We're really focusing on the human aspect.

42
00:02:02,130 --> 00:02:06,460
And that's one of the things that makes
it so difficult for as network admins to

43
00:02:06,460 --> 00:02:11,460
protect against is because it's not
something I could just apply a patch to.

44
00:02:11,460 --> 00:02:13,902
I can't download Human 2.0 and
run that and

45
00:02:13,902 --> 00:02:16,760
protect myself against social engineering.

46
00:02:16,760 --> 00:02:19,464
Well, social engineering in a nutshell, as
Don said, it's kind of an umbrella term.

47
00:02:19,464 --> 00:02:21,792
It covers a lot of different
avenues of attack, but

48
00:02:21,792 --> 00:02:23,850
they all have that one thing in common.

49
00:02:23,850 --> 00:02:27,470
We're attacking the human
instead of the system.

50
00:02:27,470 --> 00:02:30,360
>> And we're gonna talk a little
more about it later, but

51
00:02:30,360 --> 00:02:35,360
the only solution to social engineering
is awareness, right, is making sure that

52
00:02:35,360 --> 00:02:40,150
our end users recognize that a social
engineering attack is happening.

53
00:02:40,150 --> 00:02:42,122
And that's basically what we're
gonna do here in this episode.

54
00:02:42,122 --> 00:02:45,955
We're gonna show you guys examples of the
different styles of a social engineering

55
00:02:45,955 --> 00:02:49,841
attack, the way it can occur, so that you
can recognize that when that's happening

56
00:02:49,841 --> 00:02:53,123
and you can say, wait a minute,
I don't need to answer that question or

57
00:02:53,123 --> 00:02:55,298
this is not the way this
is supposed to happen.

58
00:02:55,298 --> 00:02:58,120
I'm not gonna divulge my
password to these people

59
00:02:58,120 --> 00:02:59,610
because you've recognized what's going on.

60
00:02:59,610 --> 00:03:01,480
So that it all comes down to awareness.

61
00:03:01,480 --> 00:03:02,620
>> Exactly.

62
00:03:02,620 --> 00:03:05,480
So one of the first sign of a social
engineering we want to talk about like I

63
00:03:05,480 --> 00:03:07,020
said there are several different kinds.

64
00:03:07,020 --> 00:03:10,310
The first one is pretexting and
this is a very common one.

65
00:03:10,310 --> 00:03:14,430
Pretexting really means
making up a fake scenario or

66
00:03:14,430 --> 00:03:19,460
an elaborate story or lie to try
to get information out of people.

67
00:03:20,640 --> 00:03:23,730
An example might be,
let's say I call somebody up,

68
00:03:23,730 --> 00:03:27,412
maybe they work at the front desk or
they're some employee at a company.

69
00:03:27,412 --> 00:03:29,840
I'm gonna call him up and
I'm going to do some name dropping.

70
00:03:29,840 --> 00:03:33,950
I could have gotten these names maybe
off of a web site or maybe in response

71
00:03:33,950 --> 00:03:38,700
to an e-mail and I get the names of some
of your I.T. people at your company.

72
00:03:38,700 --> 00:03:41,670
And then I'm gonna call this company up,
call any employee from that company,

73
00:03:41,670 --> 00:03:43,710
and I'm gonna say, hey look,
this is Bob in IT, and

74
00:03:43,710 --> 00:03:47,780
we're going through an upgrade
on their database application.

75
00:03:47,780 --> 00:03:50,330
And I need to make sure that when
we reset it on Monday morning,

76
00:03:50,330 --> 00:03:52,020
you still have access to it.

77
00:03:52,020 --> 00:03:54,150
So I need to get your password from you.

78
00:03:54,150 --> 00:03:58,380
And a lot, you'd be surprised how many
employees will actually fork over their

79
00:03:58,380 --> 00:04:01,860
password because they think it's
something that they need to do, right?

80
00:04:01,860 --> 00:04:04,890
They don't want to be the only one on
Monday morning that can't access that

81
00:04:04,890 --> 00:04:05,740
database.

82
00:04:05,740 --> 00:04:06,890
It's Bob from I.T.

83
00:04:06,890 --> 00:04:11,080
I know I've seen that name on letterhead
or on some e-mails or things like that.

84
00:04:11,080 --> 00:04:12,570
So I'm pretty sure this
is the guy from IT.

85
00:04:12,570 --> 00:04:14,490
Why would anybody else call me about that?

86
00:04:14,490 --> 00:04:15,560
So they just fork it right over.

87
00:04:15,560 --> 00:04:16,943
They share that information.

88
00:04:16,943 --> 00:04:18,850
But it wasn't Bob from IT, right?

89
00:04:18,850 --> 00:04:19,570
It was me.

90
00:04:19,570 --> 00:04:22,970
I just called up and
pretended to be somebody else.

91
00:04:22,970 --> 00:04:25,600
If you guys probably heard
of some named Kevin Mitnick,

92
00:04:25,600 --> 00:04:27,960
this is one of the famous hackers.

93
00:04:27,960 --> 00:04:32,090
He's one of the first hackers that
was really prosecuted by the F.B.I.

94
00:04:32,090 --> 00:04:34,060
and he's done a lot of different attacks.

95
00:04:34,060 --> 00:04:37,500
And I watched a really interesting
interview with him after he got released

96
00:04:37,500 --> 00:04:42,900
from prison and the guy asked him,
what attack were you most proud of?

97
00:04:42,900 --> 00:04:44,840
And being politically correct, he says,

98
00:04:44,840 --> 00:04:47,860
well I'm not really proud
of any of my attacks.

99
00:04:47,860 --> 00:04:51,090
But the one that surprised me
the most was when he called up,

100
00:04:51,090 --> 00:04:54,590
I believe it was Nokia at the time,
he called them up and

101
00:04:54,590 --> 00:04:58,880
was able to get the source code for
a new phone they were working on.

102
00:04:58,880 --> 00:05:02,350
All by just calling them up on the phone,
dropping the right names,

103
00:05:02,350 --> 00:05:03,740
talking the right talk.

104
00:05:03,740 --> 00:05:06,700
and was able to get them to
send that information to him.

105
00:05:06,700 --> 00:05:10,710
>> Another great example of pretexting
is what's called a 419 scam.

106
00:05:10,710 --> 00:05:14,820
419 scams have been around a long time, a
lot of people think of them as emails, but

107
00:05:14,820 --> 00:05:17,260
they actually started back in
the day as mailed letters.

108
00:05:17,260 --> 00:05:20,280
You'd get a letter and
it would have a big story in there.

109
00:05:20,280 --> 00:05:25,000
Somebody, usually an attorney,
was contacting you, and they represent

110
00:05:25,000 --> 00:05:29,860
African royalty or an ambassador or
somebody like that, and basically

111
00:05:29,860 --> 00:05:33,330
they're telling you a story and I've got
a great example right here on my computer.

112
00:05:33,330 --> 00:05:37,550
So this is a photocopy of a letter and
basically it's just sending a message

113
00:05:37,550 --> 00:05:41,575
to you and letting you know this person
saying they're in the United Kingdom,

114
00:05:41,575 --> 00:05:45,460
they visited South Africa, and
something happened, right?

115
00:05:45,460 --> 00:05:50,990
There's a person, this person,
Mutassim Billah Gadhafi, who has died.

116
00:05:50,990 --> 00:05:55,380
And their money is tied up in an estate,
and they wanna transfer it out,

117
00:05:55,380 --> 00:05:58,040
but they don't want to pay a bunch
of taxes or something like that,

118
00:05:58,040 --> 00:06:00,000
in this case it's 32 million pounds.

119
00:06:00,000 --> 00:06:04,280
And what they say is, if you let me
transfer the 32 million pounds to you,

120
00:06:05,490 --> 00:06:08,370
then you can transfer it
back to another account for

121
00:06:08,370 --> 00:06:11,620
me, and keep a million pounds for
yourself, right?

122
