So it does change,
you have to stay on top of it.

528
00:27:27,360 --> 00:27:28,300
>> It does and you might wonder,

529
00:27:28,300 --> 00:27:30,090
well why don't they just take
some of those weaker ones out?

530
00:27:30,090 --> 00:27:33,290
Why even leave them in the list and
allow them to be negotiated for?

531
00:27:33,290 --> 00:27:36,850
And that's because while the longer key,

532
00:27:36,850 --> 00:27:41,420
the stronger the algorithm is true, that
also means the more processing power that

533
00:27:41,420 --> 00:27:45,470
it takes to perform those mathematical
algorithms to take that plain text,

534
00:27:45,470 --> 00:27:48,500
turn into ciphertext, and
convert it back into plain text.

535
00:27:48,500 --> 00:27:51,745
So you might have an older system
that just doesn't have the horsepower

536
00:27:51,745 --> 00:27:56,145
to actually perform the calculations
if we use a 4,096-bit key.

537
00:27:56,145 --> 00:28:00,185
I'd love to use that on everything, but
that's going to slow some things down.

538
00:28:00,185 --> 00:28:04,345
My little wireless access point couldn't
handle it, it would choke the system.

539
00:28:04,345 --> 00:28:07,450
So in that case I've got to
choose one that's strong, but

540
00:28:07,450 --> 00:28:10,657
not quite as strong as that 4,096-bit key.

541
00:28:10,657 --> 00:28:12,960
>> Yeah.
And you know who's to blame, Mike?

542
00:28:12,960 --> 00:28:14,055
The United States.

543
00:28:14,055 --> 00:28:17,460
>> [LAUGH]
>> A lot of it is our fault,

544
00:28:17,460 --> 00:28:21,040
where the United States government
had rules for a long time that said

545
00:28:21,040 --> 00:28:25,170
if you wrote software that used encryption
or made hardware that used encryption,

546
00:28:25,170 --> 00:28:30,013
you couldn't sell it to other countries
unless you limited it to, is it 40 bits?

547
00:28:30,013 --> 00:28:30,840
I think it was 40 or 48.

548
00:28:30,840 --> 00:28:33,010
It was 40 bits.

549
00:28:33,010 --> 00:28:35,580
So for years,
even though we had stronger encryption,

550
00:28:35,580 --> 00:28:39,780
we'd only export this 40 bits stuff, and
so that kind of became the standard.

551
00:28:39,780 --> 00:28:42,200
If you wanted your equipment
to work all over the world,

552
00:28:42,200 --> 00:28:45,040
you cap it at 40 bit, which was weak.

553
00:28:45,040 --> 00:28:49,790
And at the time, they said they did that
because they didn't want foreign powers or

554
00:28:49,790 --> 00:28:51,440
whatever to have better
encryption than us.

555
00:28:51,440 --> 00:28:55,200
And now we know it's that, well,
they wanted to be able to view everything.

556
00:28:55,200 --> 00:28:57,050
>> [LAUGH]
>> So apparently that worked.

557
00:28:57,050 --> 00:29:00,920
So we are seeing a lot of
people correct for that and

558
00:29:00,920 --> 00:29:04,410
get better about it and encryption
standards are being developed independent

559
00:29:04,410 --> 00:29:06,500
of the United States now
which is a good thing.

560
00:29:06,500 --> 00:29:09,930
Really independent of any government
would be a great idea, so.

561
00:29:09,930 --> 00:29:13,330
All right, but hopefully,
through our examples and our stories here,

562
00:29:13,330 --> 00:29:17,780
you guys have had a chance to
learn why encryption is important.

563
00:29:17,780 --> 00:29:20,970
It's not just a cool thing, it's not just
neat to see that little lock up there.

564
00:29:20,970 --> 00:29:23,150
It actually serves a purpose.

565
00:29:23,150 --> 00:29:27,320
It's really incredibly beneficial,
especially when using networks like

566
00:29:27,320 --> 00:29:31,480
the Internet or the free wireless at
Starbucks or whatever it is that you're

567
00:29:31,480 --> 00:29:35,492
using, if you're on a network you don't
trust, you need to encrypt your data.

568
00:29:35,492 --> 00:29:37,620
>> This is that confidentiality,

569
00:29:37,620 --> 00:29:40,300
a big part of what we're trying
to do when we implement security.

570
00:29:41,470 --> 00:29:44,220
>> All right, well ladies and
gentlemen, this is a good spot for

571
00:29:44,220 --> 00:29:45,880
us to wrap up this episode.

572
00:29:45,880 --> 00:29:47,420
We hope you guys enjoyed it.

573
00:29:47,420 --> 00:29:47,940
Stay tuned,

574
00:29:47,940 --> 00:29:51,720
we've got more security fundamentals
episodes coming up down the road.

575
00:29:51,720 --> 00:29:55,120
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

576
00:29:55,120 --> 00:29:56,120
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

577
00:29:56,120 --> 00:29:57,406
>> And we'll see you next time.

578
00:29:57,406 --> 00:30:03,310
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike cover full disk encryption. They discuss the benefits of full disk encryption and differentiate between full disk and file-level encryption.
episodes.title: Disk Encryption
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11,109 --> 00:00:11,738
All right.

3
00:00:11,738 --> 00:00:14,276
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,276 --> 00:00:15,962
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:15,962 --> 00:00:17,380
Back again with Mr. Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:17,380 --> 00:00:18,138
How's it going, Mike?

7
00:00:18,138 --> 00:00:19,940
>> It's going fantastic,
Don, really excited.

8
00:00:19,940 --> 00:00:23,172
We've got another episode of our
security fundamentals coming your way.

9
00:00:23,172 --> 00:00:27,300
And in this episode, we're gonna be
talking about full drive encryption.

10
00:00:27,300 --> 00:00:30,157
Where instead of encrypting
an individual file or folder,

11
00:00:30,157 --> 00:00:33,100
we're going to encrypt
the entire hard drive.

12
00:00:33,100 --> 00:00:39,110
>> Now, Mike, help me out here, why would
I want to encrypt my entire hard drive?

13
00:00:39,110 --> 00:00:41,586
My computer,
I've got a password on it, right.

14
00:00:41,586 --> 00:00:42,362
It's secure.

15
00:00:42,362 --> 00:00:45,113
When I walk away from my desk,
I make sure I lock the screen,

16
00:00:45,113 --> 00:00:46,832
so nobody's going to get at my data.

17
00:00:46,832 --> 00:00:49,925
Isn't encrypting the whole
disk a little like overkill?

18
00:00:49,925 --> 00:00:52,134
>> You might think that, and
those are some good practices, right?

19
00:00:52,134 --> 00:00:55,705
Walk away from you computer,
lock that screen, you're using a good,

20
00:00:55,705 --> 00:00:56,666
strong password.

21
00:00:56,666 --> 00:01:00,143
The problem is, what if somebody
steals the computer, right?

22
00:01:00,143 --> 00:01:03,487
On our mobile devices,
on these laptops, easy to leave those

23
00:01:03,487 --> 00:01:08,330
things laying around somewhere, easy for
somebody just to walk by and pick it up.

24
00:01:08,330 --> 00:01:11,301
And sure, they can't get into your
computer because you get that

25
00:01:11,301 --> 00:01:12,390
good strong password.

26
00:01:12,390 --> 00:01:15,632
I've got it nice and long, and
they aren't going to be able to get that.

27
00:01:15,632 --> 00:01:18,256
What if they just take the hard
drive out of your computer, right?

28
00:01:18,256 --> 00:01:19,216
This is not difficult.

29
00:01:19,216 --> 00:01:20,634
We can pop that laptop open.

30
00:01:20,634 --> 00:01:22,321
I can take that hard drive out.

31
00:01:22,321 --> 00:01:24,314
I can throw it in my own computer.

32
00:01:24,314 --> 00:01:26,181
I know the password to my computer.

33
00:01:26,181 --> 00:01:28,357
Now, I've got access to all of your data.

34
00:01:28,357 --> 00:01:32,431
So, this is why we want to look at
encrypting the entire hard drive,

35
00:01:32,431 --> 00:01:35,366
because somebody could
steal the drive itself.

36
00:01:35,366 --> 00:01:38,180
So, it's really gonna help us
protect against that theft.

37
00:01:38,180 --> 00:01:42,280
Another thing that can help us
protect with is drive disposal.

38
00:01:42,280 --> 00:01:45,676
When you throw those hard drives away,
and we try to sanitize them,

39
00:01:45,676 --> 00:01:47,655
we try to remove all the data from them.

40
00:01:47,655 --> 00:01:50,535
But we've seen there's some
really good recovery tools

41
00:01:50,535 --> 00:01:54,441
out there that allow people to pull back
data that was deleted a long time ago.

42
00:01:54,441 --> 00:01:57,449
This is another layer of defense
against something like that as well.

43
00:01:57,449 --> 00:01:59,533
Because if that drive's encrypted,

44
00:01:59,533 --> 00:02:03,580
they can't simply put it in another
computer and try to remove that data.

45
00:02:03,580 --> 00:02:08,071
>> Yeah, and this has become increasingly
important as people buy laptops instead of

46
00:02:08,071 --> 00:02:10,000
desktops these days, right?

47
00:02:10,000 --> 00:02:13,680
And Mike, you and me both,
we use laptops as our primary computers.

48
00:02:13,680 --> 00:02:17,790
If I have a desktop at home, it's not like
I'm gonna leave my desktop on a cab or

49
00:02:17,790 --> 00:02:19,488
lose my desktop at the airport.

50
00:02:19,488 --> 00:02:21,260
But a laptop, that happens.

51
00:02:21,260 --> 00:02:24,127
But somebody could break into my house and
get that computer.

52
00:02:24,127 --> 00:02:26,751
So, encrypting the whole
disk is important really,

53
00:02:26,751 --> 00:02:29,449
regardless of whether your
computer is mobile or not.

54
00:02:29,449 --> 00:02:30,752
People can get at that system.

55
00:02:30,752 --> 00:02:31,786
>> Absolutely.

56
00:02:31,786 --> 00:02:35,668
And from the IT perspective,
we're encrypting that entire hard drive.

57
00:02:35,668 --> 00:02:39,831
We can encrypt most operating system
support file encryption where we can go in

58
00:02:39,831 --> 00:02:42,302
and I can say, ooh,
this is a sensitive file.

59
00:02:42,302 --> 00:02:45,435
It's got passwords in there, it's got
personal identifiable information,

60
00:02:45,435 --> 00:02:47,410
credit card information,
something like that.

61
00:02:47,410 --> 00:02:48,789
We can encrypt that file.

62
00:02:48,789 --> 00:02:53,323
Or we can even encrypt an entire
folder of files if we choose to do so.

63
00:02:53,323 --> 00:02:56,597
But that means that I have
to decide what's important,

64
00:02:56,597 --> 00:03:00,160
what needs to be protected,
what doesn't need to be.

65
00:03:00,160 --> 00:03:03,569
If we encrypt the entire hard drive,
everything is protected, right?

66
00:03:03,569 --> 00:03:05,136
There is no deciding.

67
00:03:05,136 --> 00:03:06,663
There's no mistakes being made.

68
00:03:06,663 --> 00:03:10,450
We're going to encrypt it all,
even temporary files that get created when

69
00:03:10,450 --> 00:03:14,260
you're working with your data,
swap files, and things like that.

70
00:03:14,260 --> 00:03:17,834
It's all protected,
because the entire drive is protected.

71
00:03:17,834 --> 00:03:22,613
>> One of the things that I really like is
they've made this is painless as possible.

72
00:03:22,613 --> 00:03:24,479
A lot of people here, oh,
I gotta encrypt things.

73
00:03:24,479 --> 00:03:25,693
This is gonna be hard, right?

74
00:03:25,693 --> 00:03:27,583
I got to do all sorts of
stuff to get it working.

75
00:03:27,583 --> 00:03:28,607
You really don't.

76
00:03:28,607 --> 00:03:30,652
Most operating systems, like Windows and

77
00:03:30,652 --> 00:03:35,050
Mac OS, have simple wizards you walk
through that enable encrypting the drive.

78
00:03:35,050 --> 00:03:38,317
And from then on, when you turn your
computer on, you provide your password

79
00:03:38,317 --> 00:03:41,499
just like normal, you log in,
you don't even realize it's encrypted.

80
00:03:41,499 --> 00:03:44,621
My laptop has been encrypted
since the day that I got it,

81
00:03:44,621 --> 00:03:49,019
and I don't do anything differently than
I would if my drive was unencrypted.

82
00:03:49,019 --> 00:03:52,835
So I get that level of protection
without having to take any extra action.

83
00:03:52,835 --> 00:03:53,555
>> Exactly.
And

84
00:03:53,555 --> 00:03:58,552
they have really made it really easy for
us to keep that data safe.

85
00:03:58,552 --> 00:04:02,712
And basically, what's happening,
that entire drive is gonna get encrypted.

86
00:04:02,712 --> 00:04:06,961
And as you said, it's a simple wizard that
we go through, and then, from then on,

87
00:04:06,961 --> 00:04:10,730
when you boot that computer up,
it's gonna decrypt that information and

88
00:04:10,730 --> 00:04:11,980
it's going to pass it.

89
00:04:11,980 --> 00:04:15,064
Like, let's say I double-click on a file,
it's gonna decrypt that file,

90
00:04:15,064 --> 00:04:17,016
throw it out into memory
where I can work with it.

91
00:04:17,016 --> 00:04:18,213
I open it up with Word.

92
00:04:18,213 --> 00:04:20,139
It's all transparent to the end user.

93
00:04:20,139 --> 00:04:21,174
That's the thing.

94
00:04:21,174 --> 00:04:23,172
We don't have to do anything different.

95
00:04:23,172 --> 00:04:24,675
I double-click on the file.

96
00:04:24,675 --> 00:04:26,510
It opens up just like normal.

97
00:04:26,510 --> 00:04:28,825
I just type in data, I make changes to it.

98
00:04:28,825 --> 00:04:29,752
I save it.

99
00:04:29,752 --> 00:04:33,290
It goes back to the hard drive and
it gets encrypted all over again.

100
00:04:33,290 --> 00:04:36,080
So to the end user, to us,
it makes no difference.

101
00:04:36,080 --> 00:04:39,346
But to the bad guy, if he tries to steal
that drive, it makes a big difference.

102
00:04:39,346 --> 00:04:43,204
He's not gonna be able to get access,
well, we shouldn't say not able to, but

103
00:04:43,204 --> 00:04:46,497
it's gonna be very impractical that
he gets data off of that drive.

104
00:04:46,497 --> 00:04:47,958
>> Yeah.
What happens is that they turn,

105
00:04:47,958 --> 00:04:51,128
let's say it's a laptop, they steal
my laptop, and if they power it on,

106
00:04:51,128 --> 00:04:52,625
they'll get to the logon screen.

107
00:04:52,625 --> 00:04:54,593
And, if they know my log on,
then they can log in.

108
00:04:54,593 --> 00:04:56,010
The encryption doesn't help them, right?

109
00:04:56,010 --> 00:04:58,143
[LAUGH] So,
you do have to have basic security.

110
00:04:58,143 --> 00:05:01,519
But, if they don't know my password and
they rip this hard drive out and

111
00:05:01,519 --> 00:05:04,007
they stick it in their computer,
it's encrypted.

112
00:05:04,007 --> 00:05:05,000
They can't get in.

113
00:05:05,000 --> 00:05:07,650
You have to provide a valid
password at that login screen,

114
00:05:07,650 --> 00:05:10,310
otherwise it doesn't decrypt,
doesn't know to do that.

115
00:05:10,310 --> 00:05:12,125
So that's a key component.

116
00:05:12,125 --> 00:05:15,295
And because it's so simple,
there's really no reason not to do it.

117
00:05:15,295 --> 00:05:19,750
On modern computers, you should be
doing full disk encryption, all right?

118
00:05:19,750 --> 00:05:22,511
>> And a lot of these will support
different methods for decrypting.

119
00:05:22,511 --> 00:05:26,255
In a corporate environment,
it might be set up to auto unlock.

120
00:05:26,255 --> 00:05:28,404
If your organization uses smart cards,

121
00:05:28,404 --> 00:05:32,584
it might be that you have to swipe your
smart card in order to unlock that drive.

122
00:05:32,584 --> 00:05:36,202
So, they've got different ways they
can provide that mechanism, but again,

123
00:05:36,202 --> 00:05:38,310
it's really very simple, very easy.

124
00:05:38,310 --> 00:05:40,018
Once it's turned on, and
turning it on is easy.

125
00:05:40,018 --> 00:05:42,394
Most operating systems, as you said,
have something built in.

126
00:05:42,394 --> 00:05:45,584
In Windows,
we've got something called BitLocker.

127
00:05:45,584 --> 00:05:46,767
That's very easy to do.

128
00:05:46,767 --> 00:05:48,349
In fact, I can show you right now.

129
00:05:48,349 --> 00:05:51,055
I've got a Windows 8.1 machine pulled up.

130
00:05:51,055 --> 00:05:52,742
And I want to turn on BitLocker.

131
00:05:52,742 --> 00:05:56,543
So I've opened up my Control Panel, and
I'm navigating my way into System and

132
00:05:56,543 --> 00:05:57,125
Security.

133
00:05:57,125 --> 00:06:01,162
In fact, you can simply type in
BitLocker up there in the search and

134
00:06:01,162 --> 00:06:02,470
find it very easily.

135
00:06:02,470 --> 00:06:03,564
Come to this screen and

136
00:06:03,564 --> 00:06:06,510
I can see the different drives
I have available in my system.

137
00:06:06,510 --> 00:06:08,910
Now, I want to protect my data drive.

138
00:06:08,910 --> 00:06:11,332
That's where I keep a lot of
my sensitive information.

139
00:06:11,332 --> 00:06:16,408
So, all I have to do is come over here and
click Turn On BitLocker.

140
00:06:16,408 --> 00:06:18,532
It's going to launch a little wizard, and

141
00:06:18,532 --> 00:06:21,549
it's going to first ask me how
do I want to unlock this drive.

142
00:06:21,549 --> 00:06:24,110
In this case, I'm going to use a password.

143
00:06:24,110 --> 00:06:27,229
I don't have a smart card, but in
a corporate environment where you've got

144
00:06:27,229 --> 00:06:29,732
smart card readers,
maybe you will want to use that option.

145
00:06:29,732 --> 00:06:33,380
So I'm just gonna provide
the password that I

146
00:06:33,380 --> 00:06:37,416
want to use twice to make
sure I type it in the same.

147
00:06:37,416 --> 00:06:41,151
And then,
I'll continue on with our wizard.

148
00:06:41,151 --> 00:06:43,005
And then, it's gonna give me
a couple of options here.

149
00:06:43,005 --> 00:06:46,538
Because it's gonna create
what's called a Recovery Key.

150
00:06:46,538 --> 00:06:49,786
One thing we've got to keep in mind
when we do full drive encryption,

151
00:06:49,786 --> 00:06:53,485
there's always the possibility that I'm
unable to get back into that drive.

152
00:06:53,485 --> 00:06:56,323
For example, here, I'm setting a password.

153
00:06:56,323 --> 00:06:58,030
What if I forget that password?

154
00:06:58,030 --> 00:07:00,890
How do I get back into that drive?

155
00:07:00,890 --> 00:07:03,682
Or if I have to move this
drive to a different machine,

156
00:07:03,682 --> 00:07:07,665
how am I going to be able to get back in
that drive if I've lost that password?

157
00:07:07,665 --> 00:07:09,998
So I'm just gonna quickly
save this to a file.

158
00:07:09,998 --> 00:07:14,131
You get several different options,
you can print it out,

159
00:07:14,131 --> 00:07:16,249
you can send it to a USB drive.

160
00:07:16,249 --> 00:07:18,053
In a corporate environment,

161
00:07:18,053 --> 00:07:21,594
I might even store that recovery
key in Active Directory.

162
00:07:21,594 --> 00:07:22,284
So I'll go ahead.

163
00:07:22,284 --> 00:07:25,182
>> Be really careful with that though,
because if somebody gets ahold of your

164
00:07:25,182 --> 00:07:27,219
recovery key,
they can decrypt your data, right?

165
00:07:27,219 --> 00:07:29,064
That's like the key to your house.

166
00:07:29,064 --> 00:07:30,303
You don't just leave it laying around.

167
00:07:30,303 --> 00:07:31,519
Make sure you put it somewhere safe.

168
00:07:31,519 --> 00:07:32,318
>> Absolutely.

169
00:07:32,318 --> 00:07:34,918
And also not a good idea to keep it on
the same computer that you're enabling

170
00:07:34,918 --> 00:07:35,465
BitLocker on.

171
00:07:35,465 --> 00:07:37,309
>> [LAUGH]
>> Which I'm doing here.

172
00:07:37,309 --> 00:07:38,629
Not a real good example, but

173
00:07:38,629 --> 00:07:41,662
you would want to make sure you
had it external from this machine.

174
00:07:41,662 --> 00:07:44,130
All right.
So I've taking care of my recovery key.

175
00:07:44,130 --> 00:07:45,350
I'll click Next.

176
00:07:45,350 --> 00:07:48,485
And it asks me am I ready to encrypt
this drive, and I'll go ahead and

177
00:07:48,485 --> 00:07:49,697
click Start Encrypting.

178

00:01:13,280 --> 00:01:16,860
Secure Socket Layer, what that's going

There's several companies out

So if I want to run a website and

>> [LAUGH]
>> And nobody likes writing checks.

515
00:26:19,470 --> 00:26:20,590
All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,

516
00:26:20,590 --> 00:26:23,720
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode
as much as we did filming it.

517
00:26:23,720 --> 00:26:26,000
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

518
00:26:26,000 --> 00:26:27,230
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

519
00:26:27,230 --> 00:26:28,346
>> And we'll see you next time.

520
00:26:28,346 --> 00:26:33,900
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss reconnaissance attacks. They focus on port scans, describe how they work and what information is exposed as the result of being scanned.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance Attacks
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,012 --> 00:00:03,111
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03,111 --> 00:00:11,186
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11,186 --> 00:00:15,400
All right, welcome back to another
action packed episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15,400 --> 00:00:19,120
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:19,120 --> 00:00:19,840
How's it going, Mike?

6
00:00:19,840 --> 00:00:20,760
>> Fantastic, Don.

7
00:00:20,760 --> 00:00:23,430
Excited for another episode
of our Security Fundamentals.

8
00:00:23,430 --> 00:00:27,060
And today we're gonna be talking
about our reconnaissance attacks.

9
00:00:27,060 --> 00:00:28,140
And reconnaissance attacks,

10
00:00:28,140 --> 00:00:31,530
these are kinds of attacks where the bad
guys are doing reconnaissance, right?

11
00:00:31,530 --> 00:00:36,460
They're going to be doing things like
scanning your system or scanning a machine

12
00:00:36,460 --> 00:00:40,460
looking for vulnerabilities, looking for
ways that they can attack or

13
00:00:40,460 --> 00:00:44,660
infect or do some other malicious
activity on your machine.

14
00:00:44,660 --> 00:00:49,400
And, Don, this is a type of attack
that occurs all the time, right?

15
00:00:49,400 --> 00:00:54,360
>> Yeah, if you were to take a computer
and plug it directly into the Internet,

16
00:00:54,360 --> 00:00:57,800
like you take a cable modem or DSL and
plug it right in the back of the computer

17
00:00:57,800 --> 00:01:03,420
and run like a traffic monitor,
you'll see that your computer gets scanned

18
00:01:03,420 --> 00:01:08,570
not just like once a day or
once an hour, even once a minute.

19
00:01:08,570 --> 00:01:13,020
Your computer's getting scanned thousands
upon thousands of times per hour just all

20
00:01:13,020 --> 00:01:18,050
throughout the day and that's because this
is really the first stage of an attack.

21
00:01:18,050 --> 00:01:21,290
When somebody's going to break into a
network, they don't just jump right in and

22
00:01:21,290 --> 00:01:22,380
start breaking in.

23
00:01:22,380 --> 00:01:24,670
They do reconnaissance,
they learn about the network.

24
00:01:24,670 --> 00:01:28,340
And there's automated tools that
are running that are constantly scanning

25
00:01:28,340 --> 00:01:30,440
the Internet and
that puts your systems at risk.

26
00:01:30,440 --> 00:01:33,260
That's why it's important to understand
what this type of attack is and

27
00:01:33,260 --> 00:01:34,510
what we can do to prevent it.

28
00:01:34,510 --> 00:01:38,090
>> Exactly, so when we talk about scanning
your system, what do we mean by that?

29
00:01:38,090 --> 00:01:42,180
Well, we look at the way a computer works
and the way it sends and receives data.

30
00:01:42,180 --> 00:01:44,370
It creates what we call a socket.

31
00:01:44,370 --> 00:01:48,860
And your computer has 65 thousand plus

32
00:01:48,860 --> 00:01:51,620
ports that it can use to
establish these sockets.

33
00:01:51,620 --> 00:01:53,571
So you can think about it,
it's just different connection points.

34
00:01:53,571 --> 00:01:56,410
Your computer can have all these
different connections going on for

35
00:01:56,410 --> 00:01:58,970
different protocols and
different services.

36
00:01:58,970 --> 00:02:04,000
There are some of these ports that are
assigned particular protocols or services.

37
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:06,910
Some of them are dynamic and
can be used by anything.

38
00:02:06,910 --> 00:02:10,760
But for us, what it means is,
the bad guy's scanning all those ports.

39
00:02:10,760 --> 00:02:13,370
And from the information that he gathers,
looking at those and

40
00:02:13,370 --> 00:02:16,990
determining whether or not the port
is open, meaning that it's listening,

41
00:02:16,990 --> 00:02:19,940
that it's waiting for
another machine machine to connect to and

42
00:02:19,940 --> 00:02:23,880
if somebody tries to connect to that
particular port number, it'll allow it.

43
00:02:23,880 --> 00:02:27,760
Or whether that port is closed,
meaning that that machine, your machine is

44
00:02:27,760 --> 00:02:31,410
not going to accept any connections
on that particular port number.

45
00:02:31,410 --> 00:02:35,910
Remember, I said there's
65,535 of these guys.

46
00:02:35,910 --> 00:02:38,000
So we run things like firewalls.

47
00:02:38,000 --> 00:02:39,680
We talked about that in another episode.

48
00:02:39,680 --> 00:02:41,410
If you've missed it, go check it out.

49
00:02:41,410 --> 00:02:44,760
And our firewalls typically
block all these ports, and

50
00:02:44,760 --> 00:02:49,850
then we can pick and choose which
ones we allow, which ones we open up.

51
00:02:49,850 --> 00:02:51,550
But to run certain services,

52
00:02:51,550 --> 00:02:56,080
to run certain applications,
we've got to open some of these.

53
00:02:56,080 --> 00:03:00,485
And what the bad guy does is he scans,
looks for which ones are open and

54
00:03:00,485 --> 00:03:03,385
from that information he can
start to determine things like

55
00:03:03,385 --> 00:03:07,725
what applications you're running, what
services might be running on your machine,

56
00:03:07,725 --> 00:03:10,685
maybe even what operating
system you're running.

57
00:03:10,685 --> 00:03:14,390
So there's a lot of information they
can gain from running these scans.

58
00:03:14,390 --> 00:03:17,220
>> Yeah, and it's one of those things
where it's like the double edged sword of

59
00:03:17,220 --> 00:03:18,900
how powerful a computer is.

60
00:03:18,900 --> 00:03:20,880
If we were to put it in human terms,

61
00:03:20,880 --> 00:03:25,010
if I want to exchange information
with Mike, I just talk.

62
00:03:25,010 --> 00:03:25,790
He's standing right next to me.

63
00:03:25,790 --> 00:03:26,437
He's gonna hear me, right?

64
00:03:26,437 --> 00:03:27,525
So hey, Mike, how you doing?

65
00:03:27,525 --> 00:03:28,218
>> Unless I ignore him.

66
00:03:28,218 --> 00:03:31,507
[CROSSTALK]
>> Well, it'd be kind of like a firewall,

67
00:03:31,507 --> 00:03:32,303
right, reject it.

68
00:03:32,303 --> 00:03:34,277
So you just have a conversation, but

69
00:03:34,277 --> 00:03:38,620
imagine if there were five people
here all talking to Mike at once.

70
00:03:38,620 --> 00:03:41,359
It just all blends together,
and he can't properly answer,

71
00:03:41,359 --> 00:03:43,220
there's too much going on at once.

72
00:03:43,220 --> 00:03:46,070
Well, computers are great multitaskers.

73
00:03:46,070 --> 00:03:48,345
They can do any number of things at once.

74
00:03:48,345 --> 00:03:50,535
And so all they do is, they say, okay,

75
00:03:50,535 --> 00:03:52,625
I've got five people
talking to me at once.

76
00:03:52,625 --> 00:03:54,695
I'm gonna assign each one a number, right.

77
00:03:54,695 --> 00:03:57,525
And I'm gonna assign each one
to these different ports.

78
00:03:57,525 --> 00:04:00,165
And when they talk to me, they'll have
these port numbers associated, and

79
00:04:00,165 --> 00:04:04,075
that's how I can tell them apart and I can
respond to them and keep it all straight.

80
00:04:04,075 --> 00:04:08,565
But attackers can take advantage of that
by recognizing what are called well-known

81
00:04:08,565 --> 00:04:09,085
port numbers.

82
00:04:09,085 --> 00:04:12,710
Now, Mike, you mentioned,
there's 65,000 ports.

83
00:04:12,710 --> 00:04:15,310
I know a lot of those are randomly
chosen at conversation time,

84
00:04:15,310 --> 00:04:16,750
but not all of them are, right?

85
00:04:16,750 --> 00:04:18,500
>> Exactly,
a lot of them are what we know, or

86
00:04:18,500 --> 00:04:22,660
actually the first 1,024
are known as our well-known ports.

87
00:04:22,660 --> 00:04:25,300
And these are ports that
have been registered for

88
00:04:25,300 --> 00:04:29,000
particular services that are important
that all these machines use.

89
00:04:29,000 --> 00:04:34,040
These vendors can get a port assigned
to them by the IA, NA or ICANN.

90
00:04:34,040 --> 00:04:35,700
For example, web traffic,

91
00:04:35,700 --> 00:04:39,810
all web traffic by default is
gonna flow across port number 80.

92
00:04:39,810 --> 00:04:44,290
So if I scan a machine, and I see that
port 80 is open and listening and

93
00:04:44,290 --> 00:04:48,410
waiting for connections, there's a really
good chance that that machine is a web

94
00:04:48,410 --> 00:04:50,180
server that is providing web services.

95
00:04:50,180 --> 00:04:51,930
And you think, well, okay, big deal.

96
00:04:51,930 --> 00:04:54,130
What is that going to do for the bad guy?

97
00:04:54,130 --> 00:04:57,000
Well, now I know it's a web server and
I can start to look at

98
00:04:57,000 --> 00:05:01,310
different types of attacks that
focus on those web server services.

99
00:05:01,310 --> 00:05:03,670
I know what you might be vulnerable to.

100
00:05:03,670 --> 00:05:07,950
If I scan your machine and
I see that port 3389 is open, for example,

101
00:05:07,950 --> 00:05:13,310
that's a port number that's been assigned
to Remote Desktop in a Microsoft world.

102
00:05:13,310 --> 00:05:14,590
So that tells me a couple things.

103
00:05:14,590 --> 00:05:18,150
One, that you're accepting
Remote Desktop requests and

104
00:05:18,150 --> 00:05:21,070
you're probably running
a Microsoft operating system.

105
00:05:21,070 --> 00:05:23,240
So these are the kind of the things
that the bad guys are doing.

106
00:05:23,240 --> 00:05:27,352
They're scanning machines, looking at
these and trying to figure out what they

107
00:05:27,352 --> 00:05:31,414
can do, what types of attacks are going
to be successful against your machine.

108
00:05:31,414 --> 00:05:34,604
>> Yeah, if they just try to start
doing attacks right off the bat,

109
00:05:34,604 --> 00:05:37,571
they might be throwing Windows
attacks on a Linux machine.

110
00:05:37,571 --> 00:05:39,135
And they're not going to work,
it's a waste of time.

111
00:05:39,135 --> 00:05:42,485
They wanna be efficient with their time,
they want to compromise as much as they

112
00:05:42,485 --> 00:05:44,750
can, so
they're gonna be a lot more focused.

113
00:05:44,750 --> 00:05:48,710
And the other thing is a lot of people
will run services and not realize it.

114
00:05:48,710 --> 00:05:51,360
Maybe you just installed some random
software on your computer that brought up

115
00:05:51,360 --> 00:05:56,290
a web server, and now you're listening
on port 80, but you never realize that.

116
00:05:56,290 --> 00:05:59,140
And an attacker scans the network,
they see this web server that you

117
00:05:59,140 --> 00:06:02,740
don't necessarily even remember you have,
and they start to exploit it.

118
00:06:02,740 --> 00:06:05,740
These are the risks that we have when
we install third party software on

119
00:06:05,740 --> 00:06:06,310
our machines.

120
00:06:06,310 --> 00:06:08,670
We really need to know
what that software does.

121
00:06:08,670 --> 00:06:11,670
So there's ways that we can
safeguard against that,

122
00:06:11,670 --> 00:06:16,160
that we can close off these ports and one
of the best ways is a firewall like you

123
00:06:16,160 --> 00:06:17,710
talk about in the other episode,
right Mike?

124
00:06:17,710 --> 00:06:22,550
>> Exactly, and if you enable a firewall,
now that's gonna close all those ports and

125
00:06:22,550 --> 00:06:24,800
then just open up the ones you're using.

126
00:06:24,800 --> 00:06:25,930
Now those ports are still open.

127
00:06:25,930 --> 00:06:28,525
If you are running a web server,
you have to open up port 80.

128
00:06:28,525 --> 00:06:30,605
That port's still going to
accept connections, but

129
00:06:30,605 --> 00:06:33,865
at least all 65,000 of
those ports aren't open.

130
00:06:33,865 --> 00:06:36,765
So you're making it a little
more difficult for the bad guy.

131
00:06:36,765 --> 00:06:37,705
It's also a good idea.

132
00:06:37,705 --> 00:06:41,025
I'm going to show you in a minute here
a tool that you can use that the bad guys

133
00:06:41,025 --> 00:06:45,030
use, but as sysadmins or
just as an end user, you can use as well

134
00:06:45,030 --> 00:06:48,680
to scan your own machines on your
network and find out what's listening.

135
00:06:48,680 --> 00:06:51,810
Cuz as Don said, you might have installed
something that opened up a couple of

136
00:06:51,810 --> 00:06:53,350
ports, and you didn't know it.

137
00:06:53,350 --> 00:06:56,710
And those aren't necessary and you want to
close them, but If you didn't know they

138
00:06:56,710 --> 00:06:59,820
were open, then you wouldn't know
to go to look and close them.

139
00:06:59,820 --> 00:07:03,220
So by running these tools,
we can find out what ports are open.

140
00:07:03,220 --> 00:07:06,860
We can see what the bad guys are seeing
and maybe we can do something about it.

141
00:07:06,860 --> 00:07:08,510
We go into our firewall and

142
00:07:08,510 --> 00:07:11,400
we decide to remove that exception
that one of those programs made.

143
00:07:11,400 --> 00:07:13,690
Or we decide that we don't
use Remote Desktop, so

144
00:07:13,690 --> 00:07:16,050
we're going to block that particular port.

145
00:07:16,050 --> 00:07:20,000
So by scanning your machine with one of
these tools, you can see what the bad guys

146
00:07:20,000 --> 00:07:23,610
are seeing and maybe do something
about it before they find it, right?

147
00:07:24,690 --> 00:07:25,480
>> Yeah, absolutely, and

148
00:07:25,480 --> 00:07:29,560
these tools, like we talk about the tools
attackers use, they're not hard to use.

149
00:07:29,560 --> 00:07:31,100
Most of them are pretty easy to use.

150
00:07:31,100 --> 00:07:35,580
Anybody with a few minutes of time
on Google can find these tools,

151
00:07:35,580 --> 00:07:37,880
find how to use them, and
start to scan a network.

152
00:07:37,880 --> 00:07:40,050
Now what you do after
that's kind of up to you,

153
00:07:40,050 --> 00:07:44,880
but network scans are, they're a force for
evil and they're a force for good.

154
00:07:44,880 --> 00:07:48,720
We can use them to scan our own network
to locate systems that might be weak.

155
00:07:48,720 --> 00:07:51,391
So, having a basic knowledge of
these tools is pretty handy.

156
00:07:51,391 --> 00:07:54,822
For our fundamental show we don't
necessarily sweat that too much but

157
00:07:54,822 --> 00:07:56,751
it is great to be able to jump in and see.

158
00:07:56,751 --> 00:07:58,211
Exactly how one of these works.

159
00:07:58,211 --> 00:08:00,351
What the attacker is going to have.

160
00:08:00,351 --> 00:08:00,951
>> Exactly.

161
00:08:00,951 --> 00:08:02,970
So let's take a look at my screen here.

162
00:08:02,970 --> 00:08:05,820
And what I've got is
a program called Nmap.

163
00:08:05,820 --> 00:08:08,800
And it's a very common scanning utility.

164
00:08:08,800 --> 00:08:10,870
It's one of the most popular ones.

165
00:08:10,870 --> 00:08:15,500
And this particular one is Zenmap
which is their Windows GUI version.

166
00:08:15,500 --> 00:08:20,130
Normally this type of tool is gonna be run
from that black and white command prompt.

167
00:08:20,130 --> 00:08:22,010
For the show I wanted to kind
of show you a little more, so

168
00:08:22,010 --> 00:08:24,780
I've got the GUI version
where I can click on things.

169
00:08:24,780 --> 00:08:27,060
And we could just see
the results in a pretty format.

170
00:08:27,060 --> 00:08:32,230
Now I've already run a scan against my
own machine from a virtual machine.

171
00:08:32,230 --> 00:08:33,320
Because the scan, if I do,

172
00:08:33,320 --> 00:08:37,450
and you can, there's different
types of scans you can do.

173
00:08:37,450 --> 00:08:39,960
Do I want to scan all 65,535 ports?

174
00:08:39,960 --> 00:08:41,020
Maybe I do.

175
00:08:41,020 --> 00:08:43,250
But if I've got a particular
attack in mind, or

176
00:08:43,250 --> 00:08:47,120
if I'm just trying to scan my system,
maybe I just want to scan the most

177
00:08:47,120 --> 00:08:50,810
common ports, just to see what services
are running so you can limit it.

178
00:08:50,810 --> 00:08:54,470
I went ahead and ran what they call
an intense scan on my machine here,

179
00:08:54,470 --> 00:08:56,160
which doesn't try to be stealthy at all.

180
00:08:56,160 --> 00:09:02,070
If I was a bad guy, they might slow
these attacks down or these scans down.

181
00:09:02,070 --> 00:09:04,640
But this still took quite
a few minutes to run.

182
00:09:04,640 --> 00:09:08,240
So I got that run ahead of time, and
we're just now looking at the results.

183
00:09:08,240 --> 00:09:11,080
All I did with this tool, though,
the icon here on my desktop,

184
00:09:11,080 --> 00:09:12,990
I installed it a little bit ago.

185
00:09:12,990 --> 00:09:13,930
And once I open it up,

186
00:09:13,930 --> 00:09:18,320
I typed in the IP address of
the machine that I wanted to scan.

187
00:09:18,320 --> 00:09:21,690
You can use the IP address or
you can use the name of the computer,

188
00:09:21,690 --> 00:09:24,040
depending on how your network is set up.

189
00:09:24,040 --> 00:09:27,660
And then over here, I've got
the types of scans that I can run.

190
00:09:27,660 --> 00:09:29,340
And I clicked Scan.

191
00:09:29,340 --> 00:09:31,470
And like I said,
it took a few minutes to run.

192
00:09:31,470 --> 00:09:33,430
And here's my results.

193
00:09:33,430 --> 00:09:38,750
As I scroll down here, I start seeing
things like discovered open ports.

194
00:09:38,750 --> 00:09:43,360
So these are port numbers that my
machine is currently listening on.

195
00:09:43,360 --> 00:09:49,200
So for example, 135, which I wanna say it
NetBIOS of TCP IP if I remember correctly.

196
00:09:49,200 --> 00:09:51,760
There's a bunch of the dynamic
ports in there, but

197
00:09:51,760 --> 00:09:55,010
I've got quite a few ports opened up here.

198
00:09:55,010 --> 00:09:58,020
And as we scroll down below this,

199
00:09:58,020 --> 00:10:04,050
even more than the open ports it also
tried to do some OS detection, right?

200
00:10:04,050 --> 00:10:07,260
Which means it's trying to figure out
what operating system I'm running.

201
00:10:07,260 --> 00:10:11,437
Now as I click through these other tabs,
here's an actual screen shot again,

202
00:10:11,437 --> 00:10:16,102
those are the ports that I have opened up,
so there's that 139 which is my Net BIOS.

203
00:10:16,102 --> 00:10:18,900
I can go over here to host details, and

204
00:10:18,900 --> 00:10:22,180
I can see that it's tried to guess
what operating system I have.

205
00:10:22,180 --> 00:10:27,490
This one says 2008 R2,
which this is really running Windows 8.1.

206
00:10:27,490 --> 00:10:31,580
But it's the same base kernel there,
so it's going to.

207
00:10:31,580 --> 00:10:35,520
Sometimes it's difficult for
it to detect the exact operating system.

208
00:10:35,520 --> 00:10:38,340
What it's doing is it's
looking at the responses.

209
00:10:38,340 --> 00:10:42,580
Different operating systems respond
differently if the port is closed.

210
00:10:42,580 --> 00:10:46,490
And so when it does the scan it
looks at those responses and

211
00:10:46,490 --> 00:10:48,570
it tries to make a best guess.

212
00:10:48,570 --> 00:10:51,680
And in this case, at least I can
see that it's running Windows.

213
00:10:51,680 --> 00:10:56,980
In fact, if I look at the detailed
report back over here, I can scroll

214
00:10:56,980 --> 00:11:01,610
down just a little bit, and you'll see
the OS, it's detecting it as 2008 R2, or

215
00:11:01,610 --> 00:11:07,580
Windows 7, or Windows 8, or Windows CPE,
or Server, blah, blah, blah, etc., etc.

216
00:11:07,580 --> 00:11:11,270
So like I said, it's come close
to figuring out what it wants.

217
00:11:11,270 --> 00:11:13,920
And as a bad guy, that's a good step,

that are available for that.

447
00:22:03,010 --> 00:22:05,830
I think it's, what,
NetStat-N is a good one.

448
00:22:05,830 --> 00:22:10,140
That are command line utilities
you can run that will show you

449
00:22:10,140 --> 00:22:14,020
the ports that are open on your system,
but those tools are a little hard to use.

450
00:22:14,020 --> 00:22:17,020
The firewall table that Mike went to,
that's the easiest way.

451
00:22:17,020 --> 00:22:20,370
You can see what's allowed right there,
and you just check to turn them off and

452
00:22:20,370 --> 00:22:21,440
it's knocked out.

453
00:22:21,440 --> 00:22:23,920
>> And we probably should throw in
a little bit of a disclaimer here, Don,

454
00:22:23,920 --> 00:22:24,730
at this point.

455
00:22:24,730 --> 00:22:26,770
We're talking about using
these scanning tools.

456
00:22:26,770 --> 00:22:30,560
And one thing you wanna keep in mind,
if you're on your corporate network,

457
00:22:30,560 --> 00:22:35,350
you want to make sure it's
okay to run one of these

458
00:22:36,510 --> 00:22:38,340
tools, cuz you could
do a couple of things.

459
00:22:38,340 --> 00:22:42,040
One, you could set off your own
company's intrusion detection systems.

460
00:22:42,040 --> 00:22:44,080
If they're running them,
they're gonna trace it back to you.

461
00:22:44,080 --> 00:22:47,947
The thing about these scans is that they
can make a little noise if you're not

462
00:22:47,947 --> 00:22:48,860
careful with it.

463
00:22:48,860 --> 00:22:50,875
In other words,
they're sending out a lot of packets.

464
00:22:50,875 --> 00:22:55,140
If you scan all 65,535 ports on a machine.

465
00:22:55,140 --> 00:22:57,390
I mean it does it in a matter
of a couple of minutes.

466
00:22:57,390 --> 00:23:00,020
That's a lot of traffic
hitting that network.

467
00:23:00,020 --> 00:23:03,840
If you're doing that ping sweep,
these intrusion detection systems can see

468
00:23:03,840 --> 00:23:06,530
every IP address getting
pinged one at a time.

469
00:23:06,530 --> 00:23:08,400
They can detect that kind of behavior.

470
00:23:08,400 --> 00:23:10,790
They know it's typically
something malicious.

471
00:23:10,790 --> 00:23:13,910
And it will set off an alert,
and you can get in trouble.

472
00:23:13,910 --> 00:23:17,000
It's most likely in your acceptable use

473
00:23:17,000 --> 00:23:20,680
policy at work that you're not
allowed to run tools like these.

474
00:23:20,680 --> 00:23:25,330
A lot of your ISPs will also have clauses
in their EULAs that you've signed and

475
00:23:25,330 --> 00:23:30,510
never read, those things, that say
you're not allowed to do ping sweeps.

476
00:23:30,510 --> 00:23:32,370
Technically, at this point, the law,

477
00:23:32,370 --> 00:23:37,330
there's really nothing illegal about
it because you're not breaking in.

478
00:23:37,330 --> 00:23:41,230
It's like walking down
a row of a strip mall and

479
00:23:41,230 --> 00:23:44,270
pulling out all the front doors
to see if they're open or not.

480
00:23:44,270 --> 00:23:45,880
Well you're not actually breaking in,
right?

481
00:23:45,880 --> 00:23:48,360
So there's really nothing illegal.

482
00:23:48,360 --> 00:23:50,800
But what were you gonna do if
you found an open door, right?

483
00:23:50,800 --> 00:23:51,740
You were probably gonna go in.

484
00:23:51,740 --> 00:23:56,290
They can't arrest you on intent and
we can't get you on those ping sweeps,

485
00:23:56,290 --> 00:23:59,290
but if your EULA says you're not
supposed to be doing them, so

486
00:23:59,290 --> 00:24:01,980
you could end of getting
a nasty gram From your ISP.

487
00:24:01,980 --> 00:24:04,570
Hey look, we see you running ping sweeps.

488
00:24:04,570 --> 00:24:07,090
If you don't cease and
desist we're gonna cut off your service.

489
00:24:07,090 --> 00:24:09,140
So, keep that in mind.

490
00:24:09,140 --> 00:24:13,260
On your home network, a little test
network or something, that's fine.

491
00:24:13,260 --> 00:24:16,500
If you don't, do it at work unless
you get the appropriate permissions.

492
00:24:16,500 --> 00:24:17,070
>> Yeah.

493
00:24:17,070 --> 00:24:18,440
And I've heard about people doing that.

494
00:24:18,440 --> 00:24:20,340
They say oh, I wanna try this myself.

495
00:24:20,340 --> 00:24:24,010
Let me go and scan Facebook, or
scan Google or whatever, and you do it.

496
00:24:24,010 --> 00:24:27,390
Your scan might work and
your ISP then shuts off your service.

497
00:24:27,390 --> 00:24:28,720
So that is kind of where that goes.

498
00:24:28,720 --> 00:24:31,130
Yeah, you do have to scan responsibly.

499
00:24:31,130 --> 00:24:32,240
>> Exactly, exactly.

500
00:24:32,240 --> 00:24:33,930
Keep it in a little sandbox environment or

501
00:24:33,930 --> 00:24:37,060
in your home is a great place to
play with these kind of tools.

502
00:24:37,060 --> 00:24:37,749
>> All right.
Well, Mike,

503
00:24:37,749 --> 00:24:39,685
I think is a pretty good rundown
of reconnaissance tools.

504
00:24:39,685 --> 00:24:43,395
We've seen what they are and how
the reconnaissance attack is pulled off.

505
00:24:43,395 --> 00:24:44,345
It is a real danger.

506
00:24:44,345 --> 00:24:46,183
It is the first sign of an attack.

507
00:24:46,183 --> 00:24:48,092
It's that first stage
an attacker goes through.

508
00:24:48,092 --> 00:24:50,785
So, definitely something we wanna
watch out for and protect from.

509
00:24:51,870 --> 00:24:53,120
We didn't really tackle it.

510
00:24:53,120 --> 00:24:55,850
We cover it more in the social
engineering show about how

511
00:24:55,850 --> 00:24:57,520
that's kind of part of reconnaissance too.

512
00:24:57,520 --> 00:24:59,130
So, there's other things that tie into it.

513
00:24:59,130 --> 00:25:00,940
But this is a pretty good overview,
I think.

514
00:25:00,940 --> 00:25:02,580
Have anything else to tack on there?

515
00:25:02,580 --> 00:25:03,230
>> I don't think so,

516
00:25:03,230 --> 00:25:07,450
other than knowing what's running on your
own system is a big part of security.

517
00:25:07,450 --> 00:25:12,360
You can help protect your network, protect
your own system if you just look and

518
00:25:12,360 --> 00:25:14,955
see what's going on and
not just assume everything is

519
00:25:14,955 --> 00:25:18,280
okay until the bad guy finds it for
you and takes advantage of it.

520
00:25:19,560 --> 00:25:21,910
>> All right, well ladies gentlemen
this is a pretty good spot for

521
00:25:21,910 --> 00:25:22,700
us to wrap it up.

522
00:25:22,700 --> 00:25:24,420
I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

523
00:25:24,420 --> 00:25:26,600
Signing off for ITProTV I'm Don Pezet.

524
00:25:26,600 --> 00:25:27,770
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

525
00:25:27,770 --> 00:25:29,317
>> And we'll see you next time.

526
00:25:29,317 --> 00:25:35,000
[SOUND].

episodes.title: Firewalls
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,937
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,937 --> 00:00:11,537
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11,537 --> 00:00:14,691
Greetings, and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,691 --> 00:00:16,900
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrey.

5
00:00:16,900 --> 00:00:19,200
Here with me today is none
other than Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:19,200 --> 00:00:20,101
How you doing today, Mike?

7
00:00:20,101 --> 00:00:21,451
>> I'm doing fantastic, Daniel.

8
00:00:21,451 --> 00:00:25,930
We've got another great show coming your
way in our Security Fundamentals series.

9
00:00:25,930 --> 00:00:28,990
And in this one we're gonna
be talking about Firewalls.

10
00:00:28,990 --> 00:00:35,080
Now a firewall is simply a way that I can
protect my network and/or my computers.

11
00:00:35,080 --> 00:00:37,650
We'll talk about where
we place these firewalls

12
00:00:37,650 --> 00:00:40,150
from traffic that I don't want, right?

13
00:00:40,150 --> 00:00:43,920
When we look at a way a computer
communicates it sends data out across

14
00:00:43,920 --> 00:00:45,530
a network and that data and

15
00:00:45,530 --> 00:00:48,360
then there's data that comes
back to my computer as well.

16
00:00:48,360 --> 00:00:53,050
And a firewall is a way that I can
block certain types of traffic.

17
00:00:53,050 --> 00:00:57,980
Maybe I don't want, for example, remote
desktop traffic coming into my computer,

18
00:00:57,980 --> 00:01:01,295
well, my firewall Firewall will allow me
to block that type of traffic, right?

19
00:01:01,295 --> 00:01:05,115
There's a lot of bad guys out there that
are using different protocols to connect

20
00:01:05,115 --> 00:01:06,615
or attempt to connect to your computer.

21
00:01:06,615 --> 00:01:09,575
And that firewall really is our
first line of defense, right?

22
00:01:09,575 --> 00:01:11,715
>> Yeah, it really acts like
a gatekeeper if you would.

23
00:01:11,715 --> 00:01:15,460
It's kind of the bouncer at your
local club or something like that.

24
00:01:15,460 --> 00:01:18,080
He's got the list, and who's on the list,
if you're on the list,

25
00:01:18,080 --> 00:01:19,410
well, you're not getting in.

26
00:01:19,410 --> 00:01:20,650
That's basically what he's doing.

27
00:01:20,650 --> 00:01:24,590
He's checking all the traffic that might
want to come through there to make sure

28
00:01:24,590 --> 00:01:27,675
that it's actually traffic that
you want or need or whatever, and

29
00:01:27,675 --> 00:01:32,105
it's not just some person out there, or
maybe one of these malicious guys Mike was

30
00:01:32,105 --> 00:01:37,645
talking about, that's attempting to gain
access maliciously without authorization.

31
00:01:37,645 --> 00:01:42,885
So that firewall is really
a very important part of our day

32
00:01:42,885 --> 00:01:47,100
to day computing systems, because without
it we'd have all sorts of compromises.

33
00:01:47,100 --> 00:01:50,970
>> Absolutely, and we want to look at
the technical side just for a second.

34
00:01:50,970 --> 00:01:56,250
There are really 65,535 ports or

35
00:01:56,250 --> 00:01:58,961
entryways into your system, right?

36
00:01:58,961 --> 00:02:01,550
That's 65,000 ports plus.

37
00:02:01,550 --> 00:02:02,060
>> That's a lot.

38
00:02:02,060 --> 00:02:04,720
>> Yes, that's a lot and
that's what that firewall's gonna do.

39
00:02:04,720 --> 00:02:06,430
That firewall's gonna say, you know what?

40
00:02:06,430 --> 00:02:07,300
I'm gonna close them all.

41
00:02:07,300 --> 00:02:10,573
I'm gonna shut them all down,
and then we're gonna pick and

42
00:02:10,573 --> 00:02:12,316
choose which ones we want open.

43
00:02:12,316 --> 00:02:16,738
Now we don't really have to understand
what all 65,000 ports are for, and

44
00:02:16,738 --> 00:02:18,631
because of our firewall, right?

45
00:02:18,631 --> 00:02:19,996
He goes and shut them down.

46
00:02:19,996 --> 00:02:23,780
The only ones we really have to understand
are the ones that we want to allow

47
00:02:23,780 --> 00:02:25,000
through.

48
00:02:25,000 --> 00:02:26,660
For example, like web traffic.

49
00:02:26,660 --> 00:02:28,440
If I'm running a web server,

50
00:02:28,440 --> 00:02:32,290
then the port number that's associated
with web traffic is Port 80.

51
00:02:32,290 --> 00:02:35,860
So if I'm a business and I'm running
a firewall at the edge of our corporate

52
00:02:35,860 --> 00:02:40,130
network and I want people from the outside
to be able to come into my network,

53
00:02:40,130 --> 00:02:45,120
connect to my web server, and buy my
product, then I need to open up Port 80.

54
00:02:45,120 --> 00:02:47,330
To let that traffic through, right?

55
00:02:47,330 --> 00:02:52,010
Now we can have firewall sitting at
the network edge and we almost always do.

56
00:02:52,010 --> 00:02:56,350
We can also run firewalls on
the individual host as well.

57
00:02:56,350 --> 00:02:59,240
Giving us another layer of security.

58
00:02:59,240 --> 00:02:59,900
All right?

59
00:02:59,900 --> 00:03:03,120
Now, at the enterprise level,
well, let me back up.

60
00:03:03,120 --> 00:03:07,920
We've got hardware based firewalls and
we also have software based firewalls.

61
00:03:07,920 --> 00:03:12,860
A hardware based firewall is a device, a
physical thing that I can go and purchase.

62
00:03:12,860 --> 00:03:17,040
And say if I'm an IT person, I put this
in my rack in my server closet and

63
00:03:17,040 --> 00:03:19,700
I route all that traffic through there,
right?

64
00:03:19,700 --> 00:03:24,510
These are things like Cisco or
Juniper or even pfSense.

65
00:03:24,510 --> 00:03:28,890
In fact I can show you a quick screenshot
here, or a little image of pfSense.

66
00:03:28,890 --> 00:03:32,820
I'm on their website, and I can go in down
here and I can click on their products.

67
00:03:34,470 --> 00:03:36,840
And I can see they've got
the option to either buy.

68
00:03:36,840 --> 00:03:41,205
Now things like Cisco and Jupiter,
those guys are proprietary, right?

69
00:03:41,205 --> 00:03:45,550
You've gotta pay good money to buy those
devices, you've got to buy licenses for

70
00:03:45,550 --> 00:03:48,620
each person typically that's gonna
connect through that firewall.

71
00:03:48,620 --> 00:03:50,550
So if I'm an enterprise, that's okay.

72
00:03:50,550 --> 00:03:55,260
If I'm a small business or
maybe a so-ho, a home office or

73
00:03:55,260 --> 00:03:57,930
something like that if I don't
want to spend that much money.

74
00:03:57,930 --> 00:04:00,710
Some of these other solutions
like PFSense, for example,

75
00:04:00,710 --> 00:04:05,020
you can buy a hardware device from
them with their firewall loaded on it.

76
00:04:05,020 --> 00:04:09,050
You can even download their firewall
software and build your own device.

77
00:04:09,050 --> 00:04:12,540
Maybe you've got an old computer all
you need to basically and Intel Atom or

78
00:04:12,540 --> 00:04:15,780
about processor and
you could build your own firewall.

79
00:04:15,780 --> 00:04:16,560
>> Yeah that's really cool.

80
00:04:16,560 --> 00:04:19,810
That you can just reclamate maybe some
old equipment save yourself a little

81
00:04:19,810 --> 00:04:20,910
bit of coin.

82
00:04:20,910 --> 00:04:25,480
And that you can take this software
firewall, install it on a piece of

83
00:04:25,480 --> 00:04:28,480
old hardware, and then you've kind of
got the best of both worlds, right?

84
00:04:28,480 --> 00:04:32,120
And you can even run their software
firewall on your own desktop if

85
00:04:32,120 --> 00:04:33,565
you want it as well.

86
00:04:33,565 --> 00:04:36,520
The pfSence we do endorse
them a lot around here

87
00:04:36,520 --> 00:04:40,080
just because of the ease of use and
it does a really good job.

88
00:04:40,080 --> 00:04:41,880
But for us as an end user for

89
00:04:41,880 --> 00:04:45,610
a home user something like that
that might be a little too much.

90
00:04:45,610 --> 00:04:48,780
So we need we want take a look at
some other solutions as well in fact.

91
00:04:48,780 --> 00:04:52,790
Most of you are probably running
a firewall and you don't even know it.

92
00:04:52,790 --> 00:04:56,790
Either it's built into your operating
system, or if you're at home and you've

93
00:04:56,790 --> 00:05:00,440
got one of those little wireless access
points which almost everybody has, right.

94
00:05:00,440 --> 00:05:05,110
You got that cable connection coming in or
that Internet connection coming in

95
00:05:05,110 --> 00:05:09,020
it hits a modem and then it splits off and
your little wireless access point.

96
00:05:09,020 --> 00:05:12,450
Well built into most of
those devices is a firewall,

97
00:05:12,450 --> 00:05:16,380
that allows me to control again that
traffic that's coming into my network.

98
00:05:16,380 --> 00:05:19,310
Because my home is connected
to the Internet and

99
00:05:19,310 --> 00:05:21,300
think of all the bad people out there.

100
00:05:21,300 --> 00:05:25,600
I don't want them connecting to my devices
on my internal network at my house.

101
00:05:25,600 --> 00:05:29,210
So I wanna show you a quick example here
because when you look at these devices,

102
00:05:29,210 --> 00:05:33,330
like those wireless access points,
some of them don't call it a firewall.

103
00:05:33,330 --> 00:05:34,220
Right, Daniel?

104
00:05:34,220 --> 00:05:38,750
Like, when we look here, this is
a little Cisco wireless access point.

105
00:05:38,750 --> 00:05:43,600
And if I look at my tabs I don't
see firewall anywhere on here.

106
00:05:43,600 --> 00:05:48,050
But if I go to application in gaming,
this is where I

107
00:05:48,050 --> 00:05:51,900
can see these are basically my firewall
settings for this particular device.

108
00:05:51,900 --> 00:05:54,130
Now each one, a D-link,
or anything like that,

109
00:05:54,130 --> 00:05:57,410
these are gonna be slightly different so
you have to look at your instructions for

110
00:05:57,410 --> 00:06:00,340
that particular device or
go out there and search on the Internet.

111
00:06:00,340 --> 00:06:05,360
But here if I want to allow a port through
my wireless access point I can come

112
00:06:05,360 --> 00:06:11,080
over here and I can give it a name
maybe I call it something like R.D.P.

113
00:06:11,080 --> 00:06:13,710
for remote desktop or something like that.

114
00:06:13,710 --> 00:06:15,740
And then I can choose the port.

115
00:06:15,740 --> 00:06:20,720
In our example 3389 is my
remote desktop port number, and

116
00:06:20,720 --> 00:06:22,670
I can go from 3389 to 3389.

117
00:06:22,670 --> 00:06:25,590
I can choose both UDP and TCP,

118
00:06:25,590 --> 00:06:30,480
and I can tell the IP address
that I want to port that on too.

119
00:06:31,770 --> 00:06:33,600
And I'm just making something up.

120
00:06:33,600 --> 00:06:35,490
This is just a little simulation.

121
00:06:35,490 --> 00:06:37,435
And I'll enable that rule.

122
00:06:40,379 --> 00:06:42,370
Motor IP of the,
I guess that was the IP address.

123
00:06:42,370 --> 00:06:44,330
>> Yeah, the broadcast address.

124
00:06:44,330 --> 00:06:46,190
>> We'll say 33 there.

125
00:06:46,190 --> 00:06:48,890
>> Yeah, you do need to actually give
the host that you're looking for.

126
00:06:48,890 --> 00:06:51,340
We're just doing a testing thing so
it's not that big of a deal.

127
00:06:51,340 --> 00:06:52,130
But if you were at home,

128
00:06:52,130 --> 00:06:55,390
you would actually put the IP
address of the computer that

129
00:06:55,390 --> 00:06:58,240
you would want to connect with and
that's what would go there.

130
00:06:58,240 --> 00:07:02,920
>> Exactly, I click save my changes, and
I click continue and now I've got, and

131
00:07:02,920 --> 00:07:04,270
again, this is a simulation, so

132
00:07:04,270 --> 00:07:07,090
it doesn't look like it's actually
saving my changes or anything.

133
00:07:07,090 --> 00:07:09,000
But that's how I would
enable an exception.

134
00:07:09,000 --> 00:07:11,650
So if I needed to allow
a particular protocol through,

135
00:07:11,650 --> 00:07:15,660
then I would just find my configuration
page for my wireless access point.

136
00:07:15,660 --> 00:07:19,140
So this would be data or
traffic that's coming from the outside,

137
00:07:19,140 --> 00:07:20,400
from the Internet.

138
00:07:20,400 --> 00:07:22,590
Coming back into my home network.

139
00:07:22,590 --> 00:07:24,400
So if I want to sit at work and

140
00:07:24,400 --> 00:07:27,300
I want to be able to remote
into my computer at home.

141
00:07:27,300 --> 00:07:30,820
Well that firewall's gonna be blocking
the ports associated with that remote

142
00:07:30,820 --> 00:07:31,910
desktop protocol.

143
00:07:31,910 --> 00:07:35,500
Maybe you've gone out and
bought something like PC anywhere or

144
00:07:35,500 --> 00:07:38,790
one of those programs they'll let you
know what ports you need to enable.

145
00:07:38,790 --> 00:07:40,870
You don't have to go out, and
you have to know all these.

146
00:07:40,870 --> 00:07:43,960
That program, they should tell you
what ports you need to enable.

147
00:07:43,960 --> 00:07:47,240

00:15:59,086 --> 00:16:00,223
so I click on that.

313
00:16:00,223 --> 00:16:01,503
And there's my Windows Update.

314
00:16:01,503 --> 00:16:04,703
Now, I could,
mine is set to automatically scan.

315
00:16:04,703 --> 00:16:08,522
Every night at 3:00 in the morning my
system reaches out to Microsoft to find

316
00:16:08,522 --> 00:16:10,175
out if there's any new updates for

317
00:16:10,175 --> 00:16:13,065
this particular version
of the operating system.

318
00:16:13,065 --> 00:16:17,395
And I can see that it says, there aren't
any updates that download automatically.

319
00:16:17,395 --> 00:16:18,525
I could click Check now.

320
00:16:18,525 --> 00:16:20,725
I could go ahead and say,
you know what, I don't trust it or

321
00:16:20,725 --> 00:16:24,385
I just wanna see and I could go ahead and
click Check now and it would go out there.

322
00:16:24,385 --> 00:16:27,705
I'm not gonna do that, it would take
a little too long for our show.

323
00:16:27,705 --> 00:16:31,850
But I am gonna click View details because
I know that I'm setting my machine

00:16:31,850 --> 00:16:34,540
to only get the critical
updates automatically.

00:16:34,540 --> 00:16:37,950
All of the optional updates, Microsoft
classifies their updates as either

00:16:37,950 --> 00:16:41,450
critical, the security related ones,
or optional.

00:16:41,450 --> 00:16:46,065
Optionals, might be things like
my touchpad or my touch screen or

00:16:46,065 --> 00:16:49,975
something like that where if I use
the touch pad it could be very important

329
00:16:49,975 --> 00:16:52,215
to me, if I don't use the touch pad,
not so important.

330
00:16:52,215 --> 00:16:55,705
So they're saying that it's optional, you

00:16:55,705 --> 00:17:00,592
in fact I can see here that I I have

00:17:00,592 --> 00:17:02,882
Yay, cuz everybody, Don likes Silverlight.

00:17:18,810 --> 00:17:24,140

00:17:25,640 --> 00:17:29,620

Install updates automatically.

00:17:29,620 --> 00:17:32,310

00:17:32,310 --> 00:17:36,340

I'll let you know when I'm

install them.

00:17:44,000 --> 00:17:47,230
I'll decide when to download them,
I'll decide when to install them.

00:17:47,230 --> 00:17:48,660
Or I could tell it to never check and

349
00:17:48,660 --> 00:17:50,800
obviously that is a not
recommended option.

350
00:17:50,800 --> 00:17:53,990
And that's because it goes back to

351
00:17:53,990 --> 00:17:56,900
You might think, Oh, I don't want to
do it automatically, it's in my way,

352
00:17:56,900 --> 00:18:01,235
it's very inconvenient, but
the problem is, we forget, right.

353
00:18:01,235 --> 00:18:03,775
And then we go weeks without
getting our updates, and

354
00:18:03,775 --> 00:18:08,565
there's security related updates are
available that we should have and there's

355
00:18:08,565 --> 00:18:12,927
no reason, the only reason we don't
have them is cuz we forgot to go check.

356
00:18:12,927 --> 00:18:16,417
I can also see it gave me the recommended
updates the same way I received important

357
00:18:16,417 --> 00:18:19,147
updates, which I could've
sworn I unchecked, because I

358
00:18:19,147 --> 00:18:22,747
don't want their recommended updates
the way I get the important updates.

359
00:18:22,747 --> 00:18:25,988
And then Microsoft has other
products I can obtain updates for,

360
00:18:25,988 --> 00:18:27,528
through their same systems.

361
00:18:27,528 --> 00:18:30,618
So instead of having to go to two
different places, I can get updates for

362
00:18:30,618 --> 00:18:35,928
Office and Internet Explorer, as well
as the operating system through here.

363
00:18:35,928 --> 00:18:39,478
So that's how I can set that up and
once I've set it up, and that's it.

364
00:18:39,478 --> 00:18:40,028
I really don't know.

365
00:18:40,028 --> 00:18:44,038
If I choose the option install and
download automatically, I'm done.

366
00:18:44,038 --> 00:18:47,148
Every night at 3 o'clock,
it goes out, it downloads them and

367
00:18:47,148 --> 00:18:50,760
it schedules the install, usually picks
an inopportune time to do it, but

368
00:18:50,760 --> 00:18:54,610
that's just one of the evils
of the whole system.

369
00:18:54,610 --> 00:18:56,730
So that's an example on a Windows machine,
and then Don,

370
00:18:56,730 --> 00:18:58,990
you've got an example on
a Mac operating system?

371
00:18:58,990 --> 00:18:59,550
>> Sure.

372
00:18:59,550 --> 00:19:02,280
You know, in Mac OS,
the newer versions of Mac OS,

373
00:19:02,280 --> 00:19:05,180
they just use the Apple App Store
to do their updates.

374
00:19:05,180 --> 00:19:07,600
So here I am in
the Apple App Store on my system.

375
00:19:07,600 --> 00:19:09,890
And you'll see, right up here at the top,
it's already checking for me,

376
00:19:09,890 --> 00:19:10,980
it's got Updates 1.

377
00:19:10,980 --> 00:19:13,190
I can see there's an update for something.

378
00:19:13,190 --> 00:19:15,030
Now, the cool thing
about the App Store is,

379
00:19:15,030 --> 00:19:20,000
it'll do updates to the operating system,
so Mac OS, as well as any apps,

380
00:19:20,000 --> 00:19:23,230
whether they're Apple or not, as long as
they were installed through the App Store.

381
00:19:23,230 --> 00:19:26,150
So I don't have any updates available for
my Mac itself.

382
00:19:26,150 --> 00:19:28,130
You see down here,
these are all updates for

383
00:19:28,130 --> 00:19:30,730
my Mac itself that were all
installed in the last 30 days.

384
00:19:30,730 --> 00:19:33,500
Safari, Remote Desktop Client,
Yosemite, right?

385
00:19:33,500 --> 00:19:37,210
Those are big updates that came through,
it's already applied those.

386
00:19:37,210 --> 00:19:40,570
But I've got an update right now for
the Microsoft Remote Desktop client that I

387
00:19:40,570 --> 00:19:45,590
installed from the App Store and so
it's gonna see that and apply that update.

388
00:19:45,590 --> 00:19:48,100
Now, we can do it manually,
like I'm doing right here.

389
00:19:48,100 --> 00:19:51,960
You come to the App Store,
you hit Update All, it's gonna do it or

390
00:19:51,960 --> 00:19:54,670
we can do it automatically and
that's how mine is normally set,

391
00:19:54,670 --> 00:19:57,180
that these'll just come in and
automatically update.

392
00:19:57,180 --> 00:20:01,730
If I go into my System Preferences and
I go into my App Store settings,

393
00:20:01,730 --> 00:20:03,860
you'll see the option right here,
Automatically check for

394
00:20:03,860 --> 00:20:08,410
updates and Install app updates,
Install OS X updates, right.

395
00:20:08,410 --> 00:20:11,370
We kind of pick and choose those
options based on what we want and

396
00:20:11,370 --> 00:20:15,170
if we choose to be automatic, then this
screen here will automatically go and

397
00:20:15,170 --> 00:20:17,660
do updates, and now we're up to date.

398
00:20:17,660 --> 00:20:18,670
Right?
I've got that nice little

399
00:20:18,670 --> 00:20:20,450
Microsoft Remote Desktop installed.

400
00:20:20,450 --> 00:20:23,990
It's done, I'm up to date,
the system is free and clear.

401
00:20:23,990 --> 00:20:28,020
With Apple systems, it's really important
you do these updates, because on an Apple

402
00:20:28,020 --> 00:20:31,600
system, we don't normally install
antivirus or anti-malware software, right,

403
00:20:31,600 --> 00:20:34,940
because there's no viruses for Mac,
which is not a true statement.

404
00:20:34,940 --> 00:20:37,020
But there are viruses for Mac, and

405
00:20:37,020 --> 00:20:41,340
there is malware for Mac but
Apple is really proactive about it.

406
00:20:41,340 --> 00:20:44,290
They push out updates to protect it,
so you don't have to worry about it.

407
00:20:44,290 --> 00:20:46,090
That's why we don't need anti virus or

408
00:20:46,090 --> 00:20:50,240
anti malware on these systems,
as long as we do our updates, right?

409
00:20:50,240 --> 00:20:52,900
If I don't do my updates,
then how can Apple protect me?

410
00:20:52,900 --> 00:20:54,050
And if Apple's not protecting me,

411
00:20:54,050 --> 00:20:57,950
then I'm vulnerable to get those
infections just like any other system.

412
00:20:57,950 --> 00:21:02,160
So there is a bit of a myth out there
about how Macs you don't need antivirus,

413
00:21:02,160 --> 00:21:05,150
you don't need anti-malware,
and you don't worry about them.

414
00:21:05,150 --> 00:21:06,340
But you do need to worry about that,

415
00:21:06,340 --> 00:21:09,970
you at least need to enable your auto
updates to let Apple do their job and

416
00:21:09,970 --> 00:21:12,510
help to make sure it's not
something you have to worry about.

417
00:21:12,510 --> 00:21:14,000
Automatic updates are important.

418
00:21:14,000 --> 00:21:15,460
Same thing under Linux systems,

419
00:21:15,460 --> 00:21:19,220
like if you're running Debian or
Ubuntu systems which are pretty common.

420
00:21:19,220 --> 00:21:21,360
They have, it's called Aptitude,

421
00:21:21,360 --> 00:21:24,540
a little software update manager they run,
sent to us.

422
00:21:24,540 --> 00:21:27,230
Red Hat, they all have them too and
they just run in the background.

423
00:21:27,230 --> 00:21:28,720
They automatically do the updates.

424
00:21:28,720 --> 00:21:33,320
There is very, very little
reason to turn that off, right?

425
00:21:33,320 --> 00:21:37,770
You might have some software, that gets
affected by an update and stops working,

426
00:21:37,770 --> 00:21:41,840
so you might wanna do a little bit of
testing before you roll an update out, but

427
00:21:41,840 --> 00:21:44,700
typically there's no reason
to not apply an update.

428
00:21:44,700 --> 00:21:46,810
>> Yeah.
Don't be fooled in the whole your system

429
00:21:46,810 --> 00:21:49,730
is gonna run so
much better if you stop the updates.

430
00:21:49,730 --> 00:21:53,040
People will tell you if you turn that off
it'll be much better on your computer,

431
00:21:53,040 --> 00:21:56,889
cuz it's, it's going out and checking
all the time [INAUDIBLE] and it's not.

432
00:21:56,889 --> 00:22:00,660
Now different applications on your system
might be checking at different times,

433
00:22:00,660 --> 00:22:03,210
but it's not like Microsoft for
example those windows updates,

434
00:22:03,210 --> 00:22:05,532
it's not taking every hour,
it's once a night.

435
00:22:05,532 --> 00:22:06,270
You know.

436
00:22:06,270 --> 00:22:09,230
Java is a little bit over the top.

437
00:22:09,230 --> 00:22:11,510
It seems to always have
an update available, and

438
00:22:11,510 --> 00:22:15,210
you can turn the automatic updates off,
and somehow it gets turned back on and

439
00:22:15,210 --> 00:22:17,250
it tells you, hey,
there's an update available.

440
00:22:17,250 --> 00:22:19,920
Or it wants to check for updates,
but don't be fooled in that,

441
00:22:19,920 --> 00:22:21,900
don't turn those off,
adjust your settings.

442
00:22:21,900 --> 00:22:24,130
Right?
If you don't want the optional updates,

443
00:22:24,130 --> 00:22:27,050
if you wanna avoid some of those,
fine, turn those off, but

444
00:22:27,050 --> 00:22:30,100
let it automatically get those
security related updates.

445
00:22:30,100 --> 00:22:33,300
And in some situations you might
not be able to turn it off.

446
00:22:33,300 --> 00:22:35,400
If you go and look at those settings
that we're showing you here,

447
00:22:35,400 --> 00:22:37,150
like in a corporate environment.

448
00:22:37,150 --> 00:22:41,380
Your system might not be going out
to say Microsoft to get the updates.

449
00:22:41,380 --> 00:22:46,640
Companies now will run their own local
update server and it works the same way.

450
00:22:46,640 --> 00:22:49,890
Your computer's still gonna go out,
in a Microsoft world for example,

451
00:22:49,890 --> 00:22:53,140
your computer's still gonna go out in the
middle of the night and check for updates.

452
00:22:53,140 --> 00:22:57,230
But instead of going out to Microsoft
it's actually going to go to a server run

453
00:22:57,230 --> 00:23:02,190
by your IT department there in house or
somewhere on your corporate network.

454
00:23:02,190 --> 00:23:04,260
And the reason they do this is because,

455
00:23:04,260 --> 00:23:07,980
as Don was saying, sometimes
these updates can cause problems.

456
00:23:07,980 --> 00:23:12,254
In our home systems, it's usually not that
big of a deal, but when I've got 500,

457
00:23:12,254 --> 00:23:15,910
a thousand or a hundred thousand clients
to support, if I have enough data comes

458
00:23:15,910 --> 00:23:20,120
out that clashes with one of our custom
pieces of software, and all of a sudden

459
00:23:20,120 --> 00:23:24,410
I've got 5,000 machines that are unusable
and I've gotta fix it, that's a big deal.

460
00:23:24,410 --> 00:23:27,400
So I don't want them going
out directly to Microsoft and

461
00:23:27,400 --> 00:23:29,140
getting every update available.

462
00:23:29,140 --> 00:23:32,220
As in a company,
I wanna be able to test those updates so

463
00:23:32,220 --> 00:23:34,470
that I can make sure they're
not gonna cause a problem,

464
00:23:34,470 --> 00:23:38,070
on a small subgroup of computers, and then
once I'm sure they're not going to cause

465
00:23:38,070 --> 00:23:41,110
a problem then I can deploy them
out to the rest of the network.

466
00:23:41,110 --> 00:23:43,830
So if you're on your system and
you look at your update settings and

467
00:23:43,830 --> 00:23:47,870
it won't let you change them, if it says
no control by the system administrator or

468
00:23:47,870 --> 00:23:49,145
something like that.

469
00:23:49,145 --> 00:23:49,665
Don't panic.

470
00:23:49,665 --> 00:23:54,235
That probably means your company is
using an in-house update server so

471
00:23:54,235 --> 00:23:57,645
that it'll give them a little more
control over that update process

472
00:23:59,265 --> 00:24:00,795
>> And that's an important thing,

473
00:24:00,795 --> 00:24:05,205
because there are times where
updates do conflict with software,

474
00:24:05,205 --> 00:24:07,000
where you've got to do some testing.

475
00:24:07,000 --> 00:24:08,730
But, I mean you've really
got to have a team.

476
00:24:08,730 --> 00:24:12,720
You have to have staff that's dedicated
that to make sure the updates do go out,

477
00:24:12,720 --> 00:24:14,780
you definitely don't
want to miss an update.

478
00:24:14,780 --> 00:24:15,980
>> Exactly.

479
00:24:15,980 --> 00:24:19,660
So, Don, I think that kind of covers
our updates from top to bottom.

480
00:24:19,660 --> 00:24:21,430
Is there anything else we need to?

481
00:24:21,430 --> 00:24:22,160
>> No, that's it.
You know,

482
00:24:22,160 --> 00:24:26,450
the moral of the story is,
update and update often, right.

483
00:24:26,450 --> 00:24:29,010
Make sure you do those,
it is really important.

484
00:24:29,010 --> 00:24:31,860
Don't push them off, a lot of people do,
and it's a big mistake.

485
00:24:31,860 --> 00:24:32,550
So definitely do that.

486
00:24:32,550 --> 00:24:35,240
And if you're having problems on your
computer, one of the first troubleshooting

487
00:24:35,240 --> 00:24:37,780
steps you should take is to apply
whatever updates are available.

488
00:24:37,780 --> 00:24:39,580
So your network's not working right?

489
00:24:39,580 --> 00:24:41,260
Go see if there's an update for
your network card driver.

490
00:24:41,260 --> 00:24:42,960
See if there's an update for your router.

491
00:24:42,960 --> 00:24:45,800
And a lot of times those'll fix your
problems and save you a tech support

492
00:24:45,800 --> 00:24:50,000
call or an expensive visit from
a tech to your home or wherever.

493
00:24:50,000 --> 00:24:50,940
>> So absolutely.

494
00:24:50,940 --> 00:24:51,950
>> Definitely make sure you do that.

495
00:24:52,960 --> 00:24:55,890
All right so this episode we got a chance
to talk about updates, what they are,

496
00:24:55,890 --> 00:24:58,030
seeing how they apply,
and all that good stuff,

497
00:24:58,030 --> 00:25:00,110
really important information to have.

498
00:25:00,110 --> 00:25:01,990
We hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

499
00:25:01,990 --> 00:25:04,180
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

500
00:25:04,180 --> 00:25:05,270
>> I'm Mike Rodrick.

501
00:25:05,270 --> 00:25:06,395
>> And we'll see you next time.

502
00:25:06,395 --> 00:25:12,450
