484
00:24:23,880 --> 00:24:26,330
the applications,
you would need something like that.

485
00:24:26,330 --> 00:24:32,070
Because the file history, like on Windows
and that Time Machine on a Mac OS X,

486
00:24:32,070 --> 00:24:36,040
that's not backing up your applications,
and your operating system, right?

487
00:24:36,040 --> 00:24:38,890
That's just backing up the files that
are important to you, and that's okay.

488
00:24:38,890 --> 00:24:43,890
For most end users, if my operating
system dies, I'm just gonna reinstall it,

489
00:24:43,890 --> 00:24:45,250
and reinstall the applications.

490
00:24:45,250 --> 00:24:48,390
The main thing is,
I still have my kids' pictures for

491
00:24:48,390 --> 00:24:49,830
my grandma, and things like that.

492
00:24:49,830 --> 00:24:51,570
I've gotta make sure I have that.

493
00:24:51,570 --> 00:24:54,610
I'm not too worried about
the actual operating system.

494
00:24:54,610 --> 00:24:55,770
But like I said, there are out there.

495
00:24:55,770 --> 00:24:59,820
You can do a Google search over a backup
and you can find things like Norton Ghost

496
00:24:59,820 --> 00:25:04,800
or Acronis True Image, or
we've used Altiris around here.

497
00:25:04,800 --> 00:25:09,940
Paragon is another one that has
a good drive backup software.

498
00:25:09,940 --> 00:25:13,613
And we would be remiss if we didn't
mention the whole new thing, right,

499
00:25:13,613 --> 00:25:15,251
the big buzzword's the cloud.

500
00:25:15,251 --> 00:25:16,910
We got to bring that in here as well.

501
00:25:16,910 --> 00:25:17,591
>> Yeah, that's right.

502
00:25:17,591 --> 00:25:21,560
We live in a modern day and age and
we have cloud services available to us.

503
00:25:21,560 --> 00:25:25,720
If you haven't checked those out,
we also have a couple of episodes on cloud

504
00:25:25,720 --> 00:25:29,780
services, so very good stuff that will
help you understand that a little better.

505
00:25:29,780 --> 00:25:33,660
But basically,
I'm shoving my files up to somebody else,

506
00:25:33,660 --> 00:25:36,542
letting them use their storage, use that.

507
00:25:36,542 --> 00:25:40,000
And I just pay for the service,
very easy, very nice.

508
00:25:40,000 --> 00:25:40,610
>> Absolutely.

509
00:25:40,610 --> 00:25:42,670
Rick had mentioned another
good point in there.

510
00:25:42,670 --> 00:25:44,490
He's talking about offsite.

511
00:25:44,490 --> 00:25:46,390
One of the things we do have
to think about, more so

512
00:25:46,390 --> 00:25:49,240
in the corporate environment
than the home environment, but

513
00:25:49,240 --> 00:25:51,240
it's still something you
might wanna think about.

514
00:25:51,240 --> 00:25:55,110
If you've backed up your computer to this
little portable drive and the computer and

515
00:25:55,110 --> 00:25:57,560
that drive are sitting
in your office at home.

516
00:25:57,560 --> 00:26:01,063
And somebody comes in and
steals your computer and that drive,

517
00:26:01,063 --> 00:26:04,051
you've lost your computer and
your back up, right?

518
00:26:04,051 --> 00:26:07,291
Or if your, God forbid, your house
burns down or something like that,

519
00:26:07,291 --> 00:26:08,751
you have some type of disaster.

520
00:26:08,751 --> 00:26:12,797
We might want to consider having
an offsite storage for the home user,

521
00:26:12,797 --> 00:26:17,270
the end user that might not be as easy
until now, until the cloud, all right?

522
00:26:17,270 --> 00:26:20,270
Cuz now, as Daniel said, I can just
send this stuff up to the cloud.

523
00:26:20,270 --> 00:26:23,520
We attach little balloons to our data and
they float away up.

524
00:26:23,520 --> 00:26:24,152
That's not the cloud.

525
00:26:24,152 --> 00:26:24,882
>> [LAUGH] Not that type of cloud.

526
00:26:24,882 --> 00:26:27,893
>> No, okay, yeah,
there's several different services.

527
00:26:27,893 --> 00:26:30,670
And if we wanna pull up my screen,
I've got one for example here.

528
00:26:30,670 --> 00:26:32,050
This is Carbonite.

529
00:26:32,050 --> 00:26:33,890
It's a very popular one.

530
00:26:33,890 --> 00:26:36,900
You can go through here take a look
at some of their pricing plans.

531
00:26:36,900 --> 00:26:40,771
But you basically try to find how
much space you're going to need.

532
00:26:40,771 --> 00:26:42,540
Like here's personal plans.

533
00:26:42,540 --> 00:26:43,760
So I can click on Learn more.

534
00:26:44,800 --> 00:26:49,310
Well, they got 30% off right now,
so they got a good deal going.

535
00:26:49,310 --> 00:26:52,171
And they'll talk about how it works and
give you all this information.

536
00:26:52,171 --> 00:26:56,131
But as Daniel said, you typically run
a little client on your computer.

537
00:26:56,131 --> 00:27:00,084
And instead of storing those backups on
that little USB hard drive like I've got

538
00:27:00,084 --> 00:27:03,640
here, it's gonna send them out to
their servers and store it up there.

539
00:27:03,640 --> 00:27:05,440
And they'll give you so much space, and

540
00:27:05,440 --> 00:27:09,000
again, as you use that space up,
first in first out.

541
00:27:09,000 --> 00:27:12,110
But now if something
happens to my house or

542
00:27:12,110 --> 00:27:16,420
my computer at home, I still have my
backup up there in the cloud, right?

543
00:27:16,420 --> 00:27:19,610
And I can basically get to it from
anywhere I've got Internet access.

544
00:27:19,610 --> 00:27:23,110
And Carbonite's not the only one.

545
00:27:23,110 --> 00:27:26,530
There's IDrive, is another popular
one that I've seen people use, and

546
00:27:26,530 --> 00:27:28,600
they've got some pretty good prices.

547
00:27:28,600 --> 00:27:34,090
Heck, your ISP most likely gives you some
storage space that you could use for

548
00:27:34,090 --> 00:27:36,440
backing up photos and
videos and things like that.

549
00:27:37,470 --> 00:27:40,330
So lots of different options
when it comes to the cloud.

550
00:27:40,330 --> 00:27:42,190
>> Yeah, speaking of those photos,

551
00:27:42,190 --> 00:27:46,750
Flickr gives you a free terabyte
of storage to upload photos to.

552
00:27:46,750 --> 00:27:50,950
So that's a lot for
a little, no money actually.

553
00:27:50,950 --> 00:27:51,860
That's a really good deal.

554
00:27:51,860 --> 00:27:55,247
So many ways in which we should be and
can be doing this so

555
00:27:55,247 --> 00:27:58,501
definitely something we
should take advantage of.

556
00:27:58,501 --> 00:28:00,370
>> And there's one thing I
think I failed to mention too.

557
00:28:00,370 --> 00:28:06,580
I was talking about that software
like Acronis and Norton Ghost and

558
00:28:06,580 --> 00:28:07,090
things like that.

559
00:28:07,090 --> 00:28:10,330
Those are paid, there are some
free ones you can get as well.

560
00:28:10,330 --> 00:28:11,670
There's some open source ones.

561
00:28:11,670 --> 00:28:13,910
I think one of them was Syncthing.

562
00:28:13,910 --> 00:28:16,160
That was one I found from
a company called Source Force so

563
00:28:16,160 --> 00:28:18,100
don't think you have to pay for it.

564
00:28:18,100 --> 00:28:22,190
Although you get a lot more features
typically with those paid versions, and

565
00:28:22,190 --> 00:28:24,100
they're really not that expensive.

566
00:28:24,100 --> 00:28:26,580
So, lots of options when it
comes to backing up your data.

567
00:28:26,580 --> 00:28:29,490
The most important thing is
that you do back up your data,

568
00:28:29,490 --> 00:28:31,660
that you figure out what's best for you.

569
00:28:31,660 --> 00:28:34,630
Do I want to use what's built
into my operating system and

570
00:28:34,630 --> 00:28:36,360
just do my file history?

571
00:28:36,360 --> 00:28:39,210
Because that's gonna keep track of my
documents and pictures and music and

572
00:28:39,210 --> 00:28:40,420
things like that.

573
00:28:40,420 --> 00:28:41,430
Then, I'm good to go.

574
00:28:41,430 --> 00:28:44,300
I just need to know where in my
operating system to turn it on.

575
00:28:44,300 --> 00:28:47,390
I've gotta give it a location of
where to store that information.

576
00:28:47,390 --> 00:28:49,990
Or do I want more of an IT style backup?

577
00:28:49,990 --> 00:28:55,160
Do I wanna go out and buy a Paragon Drive
backup where I can do a full system image.

578
00:28:55,160 --> 00:28:59,640
That way, if my hard drive fails, I can
get my computer right back the way it was,

579
00:28:59,640 --> 00:29:02,270
including the operating system or
the applications.

580
00:29:02,270 --> 00:29:03,590
Or do I not wanna fool with it all?

581
00:29:03,590 --> 00:29:06,260
Maybe I wanna pay a monthly or
yearly subscription and

582
00:29:06,260 --> 00:29:08,690
just back my stuff up to the cloud and
send it up there.

583
00:29:08,690 --> 00:29:11,026
That way,
they've got redundant hardware, right.

584
00:29:11,026 --> 00:29:13,270
If their server fails,
they've got multiple copies.

585
00:29:13,270 --> 00:29:15,060
We don't have to worry about that.

586
00:29:15,060 --> 00:29:17,241
So, I just send it up there,
and I know it's safe.

587
00:29:17,241 --> 00:29:19,190
And I can get to it from any machine.

588
00:29:19,190 --> 00:29:23,815
So the biggest thing though is to
understand why you need to do a backup,

589
00:29:23,815 --> 00:29:25,535
because I need to keep my data safe.

590
00:29:25,535 --> 00:29:28,385
There's all kinds of things
that can happen to it, and

591
00:29:28,385 --> 00:29:32,885
where I can go to turn it on in my OS, or
do I need to go out and buy something.

592
00:29:32,885 --> 00:29:34,910
Or do I wanna use one of
these new cloud services?

593
00:29:34,910 --> 00:29:37,346
>> Yeah, well that's awesome stuff.

594
00:29:37,346 --> 00:29:40,626
Hopefully you guys have learned a lot
about why we should be backing stuff up

595
00:29:40,626 --> 00:29:41,887
and how we can be backing up.

596
00:29:41,887 --> 00:29:44,780
Super easy, so
definitely take advantage of that.

597
00:29:44,780 --> 00:29:48,600
That being said, I think we've wrapped
it up nicely with a little bow for you.

598
00:29:48,600 --> 00:29:50,630
Come to the end of another great episode.

599
00:29:50,630 --> 00:29:54,000
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

600
00:29:54,000 --> 00:29:54,880
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

601
00:29:54,880 --> 00:29:55,909
>> And we'll see you next time.

602
00:29:55,909 --> 00:29:56,490
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss data backups. They cover the different types of backups, media options and the restoration process.
episodes.title: Hardware Redundancy
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11,130 --> 00:00:11,841
All right, everyone.

3
00:00:11,841 --> 00:00:15,020
Greetings, and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15,020 --> 00:00:16,730
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:16,730 --> 00:00:19,310
And here with me today is
none other than Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:19,310 --> 00:00:20,310
How are you doing today Mike?

7
00:00:20,310 --> 00:00:21,820
>> I'm doing fantastic, Daniel.

8
00:00:21,820 --> 00:00:22,685
Like you said,

9
00:00:22,685 --> 00:00:27,430
we've got another great episode of
security fundamentals coming your way.

10
00:00:27,430 --> 00:00:31,490
And this one, we're gonna be
talking about hardware redundancy.

11
00:00:31,490 --> 00:00:34,790
Now, we're gonna be looking at this
from the end user's perspective.

12
00:00:34,790 --> 00:00:36,310
From the IT side of things,

13
00:00:36,310 --> 00:00:40,670
you know hardware redundancy usually means
having multiple pieces of equipment.

14
00:00:40,670 --> 00:00:44,860
Like if that switch fails I've got
an extra switch to put back in its place.

15
00:00:44,860 --> 00:00:46,820
I don't have to wait to order one or

16
00:00:46,820 --> 00:00:51,160
having redundant power supplies on
our servers and things like that.

17
00:00:51,160 --> 00:00:54,520
Multiple paths, multiple routers,
just redundancy so

18
00:00:54,520 --> 00:00:58,580
that if something fails,
I've got a replacement for it, right?

19
00:00:58,580 --> 00:01:00,270
That's called fault tolerance.

20
00:01:00,270 --> 00:01:04,760
And I wanna be able to survive
small predictable failures.

21
00:01:04,760 --> 00:01:06,540
From an end user's perspective, though,

22
00:01:06,540 --> 00:01:10,895
it really takes on a little bit
different perspective, I guess.

23
00:01:10,895 --> 00:01:12,145
Cuz we don't have the same.

24
00:01:12,145 --> 00:01:12,945
We're not gonna go out and

25
00:01:12,945 --> 00:01:16,785
have a second computer sitting there
waiting in case the first one fails.

26
00:01:16,785 --> 00:01:21,835
I can't put two, typically, I can't
put two power supplies in my laptop.

27
00:01:21,835 --> 00:01:22,705
And things like that.

28
00:01:22,705 --> 00:01:26,525
So, when we talk about hardware
redundancy from the end user perspective,

29
00:01:26,525 --> 00:01:31,170
we're really talking about is, well,
we're gonna talk about power and disks.

30
00:01:31,170 --> 00:01:34,970
Those are the two big things I think
that as an end user we can provide

31
00:01:34,970 --> 00:01:36,040
that redundancy form.

32
00:01:36,040 --> 00:01:38,530
Now what we'll start with, power.

33
00:01:38,530 --> 00:01:43,340
And as I said I can't really squeeze
another power supply into my laptop.

34
00:01:43,340 --> 00:01:45,540
If you've got a tower
computer at your desk or

35
00:01:45,540 --> 00:01:48,810
at home, you might be able to shoehorn
another power supply in there.

36
00:01:48,810 --> 00:01:51,190
But they're really not meant for
that right?

37
00:01:51,190 --> 00:01:53,670
So how do we provide redundant power?

38
00:01:53,670 --> 00:01:55,040
And why would I need it?

39
00:01:55,040 --> 00:01:57,000
Well, because we have power failures,
right?

40
00:01:57,000 --> 00:01:57,990
Especially here in Florida.

41
00:01:57,990 --> 00:02:01,560
In fact, yesterday, for example, we had
a major thunderstorm roll through, and

42
00:02:01,560 --> 00:02:02,670
the power flickered.

43
00:02:02,670 --> 00:02:04,680
It didn't stay off for long, but

44
00:02:04,680 --> 00:02:08,850
it was long enough to reboot everybody's
machines and a couple of the servers here.

45
00:02:08,850 --> 00:02:12,790
And the problem is if I'm in the middle of
a document that I've been working on and

46
00:02:12,790 --> 00:02:16,330
haven't been doing my Ctrl+S or
my Save every so

47
00:02:16,330 --> 00:02:19,630
often, I could have lost
a whole lot of work.

48
00:02:19,630 --> 00:02:24,665
So what we can do is we can provide
power for a brief period of time

49
00:02:24,665 --> 00:02:29,325
to allow us to continue to work
through those small outages.

50
00:02:29,325 --> 00:02:31,585
Or even just through some brown edges.

51
00:02:31,585 --> 00:02:34,285
Like some sags or some spikes.

52
00:02:34,285 --> 00:02:38,815
And we do that via something called
an uninterruptible power supply.

53
00:02:38,815 --> 00:02:42,655
These are small devices that
we will plug into the wall and

54
00:02:42,655 --> 00:02:45,528
then we can plug the other
end into our computer.

55
00:02:45,528 --> 00:02:49,260
And what will happen is it'll monitor
the power on our computer and

56
00:02:49,260 --> 00:02:54,290
if it detects a sag or
a spike it can filter that out.

57
00:02:54,290 --> 00:02:59,085
If the power goes out, I've got enough
power on this UPS to run my system for

58
00:02:59,085 --> 00:03:02,665
a little while longer, so
that I can save everything and

59
00:03:02,665 --> 00:03:05,040
go through a proper shutdown.

60
00:03:05,040 --> 00:03:06,500
Otherwise if you have a power failure,

61
00:03:06,500 --> 00:03:08,724
it's like unplugging the computer
from the wall, right?

62
00:03:08,724 --> 00:03:12,460
Everything that you're in the middle of
that you haven't saved is gonna be gone.

63
00:03:12,460 --> 00:03:17,100
>> Now Mike, you say that it supplies
power, but how the heck does it do that?

64
00:03:17,100 --> 00:03:19,140
As you said, it's plugged into the wall.

65
00:03:19,140 --> 00:03:23,460
And then, it's plugged in the computer,
and in between there, what's it doing?

66
00:03:23,460 --> 00:03:25,080
I've got my computer plugged into that.

67
00:03:25,080 --> 00:03:26,250
How is it providing that power?

68
00:03:26,250 --> 00:03:27,420
>> That's a good question.

69
00:03:27,420 --> 00:03:31,715
And what it is, it's got some batteries
in there that are going to charge up,

70
00:03:31,715 --> 00:03:33,835
just like you would your laptop battery.

71
00:03:33,835 --> 00:03:38,245
So when you plug a device into the wall,
the electricity is coming into the device,

72
00:03:38,245 --> 00:03:39,625
it's doing two things.

73
00:03:39,625 --> 00:03:43,415
On that device is a plug
to plug your computer into.

74
00:03:43,415 --> 00:03:48,070
And so there's power coming from the wall
through the device into your computer.

75
00:03:48,070 --> 00:03:51,940
It's also being routed to
the batteries to charge those.

76
00:03:51,940 --> 00:03:55,360
And it's got this circuitry inside that as
soon as it detects that the power is no

77
00:03:55,360 --> 00:03:59,640
longer coming from the wall, it switches
your computer to the batteries.

78
00:03:59,640 --> 00:04:01,450
And it does it within a few milliseconds.

79
00:04:01,450 --> 00:04:04,740
I think 30 milliseconds,
depending on how much you wannna spend.

80
00:04:04,740 --> 00:04:08,850
And that's quick enough to where
the computer really won't notice

81
00:04:08,850 --> 00:04:10,380
that power failure.

82
00:04:10,380 --> 00:04:13,220
And it allows me to continue
to run that machine.

83
00:04:13,220 --> 00:04:14,860
Now you do have to have it
plugged into the device.

84
00:04:14,860 --> 00:04:19,630
If I have external devices like
a printer and things like that.

85
00:04:19,630 --> 00:04:22,510
If they're not plugged into UPS
they're not going to have any

86
00:04:22,510 --> 00:04:24,810
power when the power goes out, all right?

87
00:04:24,810 --> 00:04:28,270
So everything that you need
is gonna be plugged into that

88
00:04:28,270 --> 00:04:30,160
uninterruptible power supply.

89
00:04:30,160 --> 00:04:32,140
But I don't want to give
you the wrong impression.

90
00:04:32,140 --> 00:04:35,850
You don't plug everything on
your desk into this device.

91
00:04:35,850 --> 00:04:39,900
And when the power goes out you continue
to work, and you continue to play your

92
00:04:39,900 --> 00:04:43,270
video game or your YouTube videos or
whatever the case may be.

93
00:04:43,270 --> 00:04:44,340
That's not what this is for.

94
00:04:44,340 --> 00:04:46,870
We're not talking about
a full blown generator that's

95
00:04:46,870 --> 00:04:48,900
kicking out unlimited amounts of power.

96
00:04:48,900 --> 00:04:50,070
There's a battery in there.

97
00:04:50,070 --> 00:04:52,720
It only store so much energy.

98
00:04:52,720 --> 00:04:55,440
And once that power from the wall stops,

99
00:04:55,440 --> 00:04:57,960
everything is being fed
off of those batteries.

100
00:04:57,960 --> 00:05:00,090
And they're gonna drain pretty quickly,

101
00:05:00,090 --> 00:05:02,330
depending on what what you're
running in that machine.

102
00:05:02,330 --> 00:05:06,270
>> Yeah, typically, I've worked a lot
with these small units that would go to

103
00:05:06,270 --> 00:05:08,230
a desktop or a laptop environment.

104
00:05:08,230 --> 00:05:12,370
And typically, depending on what
you have actually connected to it,

105
00:05:12,370 --> 00:05:15,620
the load will last for about,
anywhere between 10, maybe 15 minutes.

106
00:05:15,620 --> 00:05:20,100
If it's just a laptop, if it's just a
computer, you might get more out of there.

107
00:05:20,100 --> 00:05:22,160
20, 25, maybe even 30 minutes out of that.

108
00:05:22,160 --> 00:05:26,890
But, then most people have a docking
station, and speakers, and a printer, and

109
00:05:26,890 --> 00:05:30,150
a bunch of other peripherals that
they're also plugging into that.

110

But now I'm up to 30 minutes
on my runtime required.

333
00:17:31,722 --> 00:17:33,730
We wait for
it to do its magic in the background.

334
00:17:35,440 --> 00:17:42,870
And now my best price is more than the
best performance was on the five minutes.

335
00:17:42,870 --> 00:17:48,700
And you see my best performance is up
to almost $600 US for that device.

336
00:17:48,700 --> 00:17:52,700
So again, if this is not something
that you buy typically so

337
00:17:52,700 --> 00:17:56,720
that I can continue to work through
a power failure where they've cut the line

338
00:17:56,720 --> 00:17:59,895
it's gonna be three hours before
they get the power back on, or

339
00:17:59,895 --> 00:18:02,230
hurricane's come through and
taken out power.

340
00:18:02,230 --> 00:18:03,410
That's not what these are for,

341
00:18:03,410 --> 00:18:07,670
that's generators that you have to run
to provide you that kind of power.

342
00:18:07,670 --> 00:18:10,693
These things are giving you the ability
to shut that thing down gracefully.

343
00:18:10,693 --> 00:18:13,800
And if you need more than five minutes,
you're gonna pay for it,

344
00:18:13,800 --> 00:18:15,940
the price starts going up tremendously.

345
00:18:15,940 --> 00:18:17,830
>> Yeah, and
Mike hit the nail on the head.

346
00:18:17,830 --> 00:18:21,479
If you really need more power than that
and you're like, I cannot go offline,

347
00:18:21,479 --> 00:18:23,490
generators are gonna
be the way you can go.

348
00:18:23,490 --> 00:18:27,280
Even with a small business like a SOHO,
not a big deal.

349
00:18:27,280 --> 00:18:30,170
You can go to Home Depot or
Lowe's if you're in America.

350
00:18:30,170 --> 00:18:31,440
I don't know if they have those in other,

351
00:18:31,440 --> 00:18:34,710
any hardware store should
have generators for sale.

352
00:18:34,710 --> 00:18:35,770
Fill the thing full of gas,

353
00:18:35,770 --> 00:18:38,720
it's gonna give you a few
hours of uninterrupted power.

354
00:18:38,720 --> 00:18:40,890
So if you need that,
you can go that route.

355
00:18:40,890 --> 00:18:42,220
These are just so

356
00:18:42,220 --> 00:18:46,030
that you can actually gracefully shut
your machine down, save your work.

357
00:18:46,030 --> 00:18:49,040
That's the kind of thing we're
talking about when it comes to a UPS.

358
00:18:49,040 --> 00:18:51,770
Not that they don't get pretty expensive,
I've seen big dogs.

359
00:18:51,770 --> 00:18:56,450
I've seen battery banks of
thousands of 12-volt batteries, and

360
00:18:56,450 --> 00:19:02,200
then diesel generators with enough diesel
fuel to power a building for a month.

361
00:19:02,200 --> 00:19:05,241
Plenty of power there, but
probably not what you're gonna go for.

362
00:19:05,241 --> 00:19:07,310
[LAUGH]
>> No, no, typically enough for

363
00:19:07,310 --> 00:19:09,421
your home or small office or
something like that.

364
00:19:09,421 --> 00:19:10,138
>> Unless you're Bill Gates.

365
00:19:10,138 --> 00:19:11,311
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

366
00:19:11,311 --> 00:19:14,310
[LAUGH] All right, so
that's redundancy power-wise.

367
00:19:14,310 --> 00:19:16,092
Again, we're not talking about
redundant power supplies.

368
00:19:16,092 --> 00:19:20,835
Just giving us enough power to last
through a sag or something like that so

369
00:19:20,835 --> 00:19:23,135
that my computer doesn't shut down,
I don't lose anything.

370
00:19:23,135 --> 00:19:24,975
Or if it's a complete power failure,

371
00:19:24,975 --> 00:19:29,785
I've got enough time to do that graceful
shutdown so I don't lose any of my work.

372
00:19:29,785 --> 00:19:33,545
Another common item that we're gonna
provide redundancy for in a home or

373
00:19:33,545 --> 00:19:36,850
small office would be our disks, right?

374
00:19:36,850 --> 00:19:39,700
Now in a corporate environment
in our server closet

375
00:19:39,700 --> 00:19:42,010
we've got massive storage area networks.

376
00:19:42,010 --> 00:19:46,486
We've got these SAN devices that have
banks of hard drives in there and we're

377
00:19:46,486 --> 00:19:50,670
running RAID 10 or something like that
where I've got really good redundancy.

378
00:19:50,670 --> 00:19:53,880
If a drive fails we pop that drive out,
we throw another one in.

379
00:19:53,880 --> 00:19:57,790
There is very little downtime,
it just has to rebuild, we're good to go.

380
00:19:57,790 --> 00:20:02,040
But for my desktop, I don't have
a full blown SAN sitting there,

381
00:20:02,040 --> 00:20:06,250
I can't put ten more hard
drives into my little laptop.

382
00:20:06,250 --> 00:20:09,360
So how do I provide redundancy for that?

383
00:20:09,360 --> 00:20:13,617
And one of the easiest ways to do it
is something known as network-attached

384
00:20:13,617 --> 00:20:14,290
storage.

385
00:20:14,290 --> 00:20:19,560
And all it is is a box, typically,
that has a few hard drives in there,

386
00:20:19,560 --> 00:20:22,810
and it's connected to your network
just like any other device.

387
00:20:22,810 --> 00:20:27,347
And then you can store your data on that
device, and that device is running some

388
00:20:27,347 --> 00:20:30,741
type of software that's gonna
provide that redundancy.

389
00:20:30,741 --> 00:20:33,438
So that if one of those drives fails,

390
00:20:33,438 --> 00:20:37,973
I can still replace that drive and
maintain access to my data.

391
00:20:37,973 --> 00:20:42,292
>> Yeah, I love these types of devices
because it's basically like having a nice

392
00:20:42,292 --> 00:20:44,200
little file server at your house.

393
00:20:44,200 --> 00:20:46,980
And all you do is you plug it
in the wall and give it power.

394
00:20:46,980 --> 00:20:48,800
You plug into the network, and

395
00:20:48,800 --> 00:20:52,190
it shows up like any other
device on your home network.

396
00:20:52,190 --> 00:20:53,585
It just looks like another computer.

397
00:20:53,585 --> 00:20:56,870
You have a nice drive there and
you map that down to your computer.

398
00:20:56,870 --> 00:20:59,430
Start shoving files up to it and
you're good to go.

399
00:20:59,430 --> 00:21:00,570
Very simple.

400
00:21:00,570 --> 00:21:02,330
>> Yeah, and
it's got a lot of benefits to it.

401
00:21:02,330 --> 00:21:06,910
Not only is it giving me redundancy for my
data, because it's attached to the network

402
00:21:06,910 --> 00:21:10,500
that means I can get to that storage from
any one of the machines on my network.

403
00:21:10,500 --> 00:21:13,707
So if you're like me and
you've got a desktop in your office,

404
00:21:13,707 --> 00:21:17,841
you've got a laptop that you use out in
the living room, you've got your Roku or

405
00:21:17,841 --> 00:21:19,528
something hooked up to your TV.

406
00:21:19,528 --> 00:21:22,870
I can connect all those, they can all
see that network-attached storage.

407
00:21:22,870 --> 00:21:28,050
And I can pull data so you can basically
share that data across those devices and

408
00:21:28,050 --> 00:21:28,709
you're getting the redundancy.

409
00:21:29,790 --> 00:21:32,700
We've talked about it, there's another
episode where we talked about backups,

410
00:21:32,700 --> 00:21:35,990
and this doesn't replace the need for
backups, but

411
00:21:35,990 --> 00:21:39,730
it can make it where I don't need
to rely on the backups as much.

412
00:21:39,730 --> 00:21:43,960
I still wanna do a backup, cuz corrupt
data or deleted data is still corrupt or

413
00:21:43,960 --> 00:21:46,730
deleted, right,
whether I've got redundancy or not.

414
00:21:46,730 --> 00:21:51,160
But now if I have disk failure, I can pull
one of those disks out and replace it.

415
00:21:51,160 --> 00:21:54,250
There's a bunch of different ways
you can go about setting up a NAS.

416
00:21:54,250 --> 00:21:56,580
You can go buy these things out there,

417
00:21:56,580 --> 00:21:59,060
you can create your own
with the right software.

418
00:21:59,060 --> 00:22:00,980
I'll show you a couple examples.

419
00:22:00,980 --> 00:22:06,350
Buffalo is one that we used here
a couple of times at our work and

420
00:22:06,350 --> 00:22:09,390
you can see they've got
a couple of options.

421
00:22:09,390 --> 00:22:13,900
It's really, what you spend on
these is gonna be based on how much

422
00:22:13,900 --> 00:22:18,070
storage space they give you and what type
of network adapters are built into them.

423
00:22:18,070 --> 00:22:23,780
If they've got multiple network adapters,
or if you want gigabit versus 100MB,

424
00:22:23,780 --> 00:22:27,310
or if you wanted to go fiber, some of
them will offer you a fiber module.

425
00:22:27,310 --> 00:22:31,390
Those can affect the cost, as well as
the number of drives that are in there and

426
00:22:31,390 --> 00:22:34,150
the total amount of storage space.

427
00:22:34,150 --> 00:22:35,360
Like here they've got a couple.

428
00:22:35,360 --> 00:22:41,090
They've got their LinkStation 400, which
has, it's one to two diskless enclosure.

429
00:22:41,090 --> 00:22:44,850
So that means if I buy this,
it's just the box,

430
00:22:44,850 --> 00:22:48,670
there is no hard drives in there, I'm
going to have to fill the hard drives up.

431
00:22:48,670 --> 00:22:51,970
Something to keep in mind when you go buy
them, I had people say, I bought this NAS,

432
00:22:51,970 --> 00:22:53,960
I only spent a couple hundred bucks on it.

433
00:22:53,960 --> 00:22:54,680
Like, really?

434
00:22:54,680 --> 00:22:55,710
That's a good price.

435
00:22:55,710 --> 00:22:58,620
They get it in, and
it's just the box and the software.

436
00:22:58,620 --> 00:22:59,740
There's no hard drives in there.

437
00:22:59,740 --> 00:23:02,460
They have to go and then buy
the hard drives to put in there, and

438
00:23:02,460 --> 00:23:05,870
now they're right up to the same price
as if they hadn't bought the thing.

439
00:23:05,870 --> 00:23:07,670
But Buffalo makes a few of them.

440
00:23:07,670 --> 00:23:09,600
Another one is Drobo.

441
00:23:09,600 --> 00:23:11,670
This is a really popular one.

442
00:23:11,670 --> 00:23:13,990
They've got some really nice features.

443
00:23:13,990 --> 00:23:17,510
Again, you can choose different sizes,
different capabilities.

444
00:23:17,510 --> 00:23:23,100
But what these guys do is, internally they
run software that's very similar to RAID.

445
00:23:23,100 --> 00:23:25,640
The redundant array of inexpensive disk,

446
00:23:25,640 --> 00:23:31,100
which is just a way that I can take that
data and spread it across multiple drives.

447
00:23:31,100 --> 00:23:34,890
That way if any one drive fails,
I don't lose all my data.

448
00:23:34,890 --> 00:23:38,530
All I have to do is pull that drive out,
replace the drive.

449
00:23:38,530 --> 00:23:41,470
It can figure out from what's
left on the other drives,

450
00:23:41,470 --> 00:23:44,320
it can figure out what's missing,
and it can put it back.

451
00:23:44,320 --> 00:23:48,120
It's really impressive stuff, but
it's all behind the scenes to us.

452
00:23:48,120 --> 00:23:51,210
All we do is we buy one of these devices,
we fill it with hard drives,

453
00:23:51,210 --> 00:23:54,540
we plug it into our network, and
we start storing data on there.

454
00:23:54,540 --> 00:23:56,525
And they make life really nice.

455
00:23:56,525 --> 00:24:00,440
>> Yeah, that's the really important
feature here that we're talking about.

456
00:24:00,440 --> 00:24:03,350
With these types of devices
they're basically plug and play.

457
00:24:03,350 --> 00:24:05,980
You just plug them in, you turn them on,
and they start to work.

458
00:24:05,980 --> 00:24:09,792
You don't have to know everything about
RAID and which RAID version should you be,

459
00:24:09,792 --> 00:24:13,059
RAID 0, RAID 1, RAID 5, RAID 10,
all the other RAIDs there are,

460
00:24:13,059 --> 00:24:14,800
it's not a big deal for you.

461
00:24:14,800 --> 00:24:17,680
All you need to know is,
plug it, in turn it on.

462
00:24:17,680 --> 00:24:23,220
I see it in my list of attached devices
and I can start uploading files.

463
00:24:23,220 --> 00:24:28,050
I install some software that allows me to
see it, makes things really, really easy.

464
00:24:28,050 --> 00:24:30,828
So having one of these at home or
in a small business,

465
00:24:30,828 --> 00:24:33,427
these are these are perfect for
small business.

466
00:24:33,427 --> 00:24:38,125
Because I've got probably three or
four end users, maybe five to ten for

467
00:24:38,125 --> 00:24:40,050
the small business.

468
00:24:40,050 --> 00:24:43,910
And they all have a nice,
large disk that's being,

469
00:24:43,910 --> 00:24:46,817
it actually has some redundancy to it.

470
00:24:46,817 --> 00:24:49,960
It's not a single point of failure
even though it's a single device.

471
00:24:49,960 --> 00:24:53,130
It's got those multiple disks
in there providing that service,

472
00:24:53,130 --> 00:24:56,980
allowing you to have that redundancy,
and they upload their files to it.

473
00:24:56,980 --> 00:24:58,950
They come back to work, or hey, so and

474
00:24:58,950 --> 00:25:01,560
so, check out the file I've
been working on, right?

475
00:25:01,560 --> 00:25:04,560
They open the file up,
there it is for them as well.

476
00:25:04,560 --> 00:25:05,491
Not a big deal.

477
00:25:05,491 --> 00:25:07,440
Very, very helpful, very simple to use.

478
00:25:07,440 --> 00:25:08,470
>> Absolutely.

479
00:25:08,470 --> 00:25:12,410
And if you wanna go the open source route,
if you don't wanna spend as much money on

480
00:25:12,410 --> 00:25:14,150
one of these,
there's options out there as well.

481
00:25:14,150 --> 00:25:16,980
I know David in our chat
room had mentioned FreeNAS,

482
00:25:16,980 --> 00:25:19,335
this is an open source software.

483
00:25:19,335 --> 00:25:22,650
Now, you're gonna have to build your
own device, but a lot of you might have

484
00:25:22,650 --> 00:25:25,880
a case laying around from
a computer that's no good anymore,

485
00:25:25,880 --> 00:25:27,885
it's a little older or slower.

486
00:25:27,885 --> 00:25:30,830
Maybe you wanna take that case and
throw a few hard drives in there and

487
00:25:30,830 --> 00:25:32,180
make your own NAS, right?

488
00:25:32,180 --> 00:25:36,308
You can download this software that'll
allow you to do almost all the same things

489
00:25:36,308 --> 00:25:39,587
that those Drobos and
those Buffalo TeraStations would do, and

490
00:25:39,587 --> 00:25:40,997
do it on the cheap, right.

491
00:25:40,997 --> 00:25:45,267
So it's not your only solution,
you can do the less, I won't say free,

492
00:25:45,267 --> 00:25:46,880
the less expensive route.

493
00:25:46,880 --> 00:25:50,090
Cuz you have to have the case,
you still have to have the drives.

494
00:25:50,090 --> 00:25:51,660
But you can obtain the software and

495
00:25:51,660 --> 00:25:54,098
you can set up your own
network-attached stores.

496
00:25:54,098 --> 00:25:56,450
So lots of different options for
you out there.

497
00:25:56,450 --> 00:25:59,030
>> So, Mike,
I think that we've basically covered all

498
00:25:59,030 --> 00:26:02,620
the foundational knowledge that you would
need to know about redundant power,

499
00:26:02,620 --> 00:26:06,120
redundant hardware, especially when
it comes to those disks and storage.

500
00:26:06,120 --> 00:26:07,850
Very helpful stuff.

501
00:26:07,850 --> 00:26:11,120
That being said, I guess we've
wrapped up another great episode.

502
00:26:11,120 --> 00:26:12,880
Time to sign off for ITProTV.

503
00:26:12,880 --> 00:26:14,940
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

504
00:26:14,940 --> 00:26:15,850
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

505
00:26:15,850 --> 00:26:17,700
>> And we'll see you next time.

506
00:26:17,700 --> 00:26:22,420
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Physical Security
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,012 --> 00:00:02,873
[SOUND]

2
00:00:02,873 --> 00:00:10,414
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10,414 --> 00:00:11,600
All right everyone.

4
00:00:11,600 --> 00:00:13,900
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:13,900 --> 00:00:15,640
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowery.

6
00:00:15,640 --> 00:00:17,590
Here with me today is Mike Rogers.

7
00:00:17,590 --> 00:00:18,430
How you doing today, Mike?

8
00:00:18,430 --> 00:00:19,920
>> I'm doing fantastic, Daniel.

9
00:00:19,920 --> 00:00:23,240
We are getting ready to do another
episode of our Security Fundamentals.

10
00:00:23,240 --> 00:00:26,240
And in this one we're gonna be
talking about physical security.

11
00:00:26,240 --> 00:00:29,950
It's one of those parts of security
that sometimes gets overlooked.

12
00:00:29,950 --> 00:00:33,240
We like to focus on
the electronic solutions and

13
00:00:33,240 --> 00:00:37,020
things I can do to my computer and things
like that, but when it comes down to it,

14
00:00:37,020 --> 00:00:41,810
physical security is a very important
part of our overall security package.

15
00:00:41,810 --> 00:00:45,102
>> Yeah, I guess there's something to be
said about locking the old door behind

16
00:00:45,102 --> 00:00:45,860
you [LAUGH].

17
00:00:45,860 --> 00:00:50,220
>> Microsoft, a long time ago, put out
these ten immutable laws of security.

18
00:00:50,220 --> 00:00:53,895
And one of my favorite ones in there
was if I can touch your computer,

19
00:00:53,895 --> 00:00:56,099
it's no longer your computer, right?

20
00:00:56,099 --> 00:00:58,967
And that's basically because
there's too many things,

21
00:00:58,967 --> 00:01:02,827
I'm not saying I'm a genius or anything,
but there's too many things I can do

22
00:01:02,827 --> 00:01:05,890
if I can get access,
physical access to the machine, right?

23
00:01:05,890 --> 00:01:09,733
I can take another operating system
that I have on a thumb drive, and

24
00:01:09,733 --> 00:01:13,690
I can try to boot your computer
to that other operating system.

25
00:01:13,690 --> 00:01:17,650
Or I can just steal your computer and take
it home with me and try something there.

26
00:01:17,650 --> 00:01:23,040
Or steal the hard drive out
of that laptop, for example.

27
00:01:23,040 --> 00:01:27,020
So physical security,
if I can get access to that keyboard,

28
00:01:27,020 --> 00:01:30,330
that's a big part of it, and
we've got to make sure that we're.

29
00:01:30,330 --> 00:01:34,270
And that's not the only part of physical
security, that's just one aspect of it.

30
00:01:34,270 --> 00:01:38,370
Physical security does encompass a lot of
different things, but it is, like I said,

31
00:01:38,370 --> 00:01:42,060
one of those things that sometimes
gets a little bit overlooked.

32
00:01:42,060 --> 00:01:42,600
>> Yeah.

33
00:01:42,600 --> 00:01:46,020
I worked in enterprise
computing solutions or

34
00:01:46,020 --> 00:01:48,980
whatever you want to call it a lot, and
I used to tell people, they'd call and

35
00:01:48,980 --> 00:01:53,260
say, I've locked myself out of a computer
and of course they're off the network.

36
00:01:53,260 --> 00:01:56,210
I said, well, if you bring it in I
can break into it and then we can get

37
00:01:56,210 --> 00:01:58,830
you back going, but other than that
it's gonna be a hard thing to do.

38
00:01:58,830 --> 00:02:00,680
They could bring me that computer,

39
00:02:00,680 --> 00:02:02,590
I could, nine times out of ten
I can get into that thing.

40
00:02:02,590 --> 00:02:03,600
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

41
00:02:03,600 --> 00:02:06,170
All right, so
when we talk about physical security,

42
00:02:06,170 --> 00:02:08,220
first off, what is it,
what does it involve?

43
00:02:08,220 --> 00:02:10,659
What are we trying to do
with physical security?

44
00:02:10,659 --> 00:02:12,120
And there's a couple of concepts here.

45
00:02:12,120 --> 00:02:14,780
One, just preventing unauthorized access,

46
00:02:14,780 --> 00:02:18,830
whether that's to the facilities or
to an equipment room,

47
00:02:18,830 --> 00:02:24,050
like a server closet or something like
that, just gaining access to a facility.

48
00:02:24,050 --> 00:02:26,470
That's a physical intrusion.

49
00:02:26,470 --> 00:02:28,740

>> Yeah it is kind of funny how a lot of

502
00:25:44,550 --> 00:25:48,980
a private industry can affect
the entirety of the country.

503
00:25:48,980 --> 00:25:50,890
We have power grids here in United States.

504
00:25:50,890 --> 00:25:55,080
We've seen that kind of problem before
where there was an issue with, well I

505
00:25:55,080 --> 00:25:59,820
think was a few years ago, there was one
of the power plants in the mid-north,

506
00:25:59,820 --> 00:26:03,660
and it went out and, basically, the top

507
00:26:03,660 --> 00:26:07,580
quarter of the United States was without
power until that grid came back on.

508
00:26:07,580 --> 00:26:08,890
It was really hard.

509
00:26:08,890 --> 00:26:10,180
People in New York, they lost power.

510
00:26:10,180 --> 00:26:11,900
People in Chicago, they lost power.

511
00:26:11,900 --> 00:26:15,850
All these people were without power
because they didn't do something that they

512
00:26:15,850 --> 00:26:18,830
were supposed to do, and that's why
they have these type of regulations.

513
00:26:18,830 --> 00:26:22,000
To make sure you are following
safe procedure because

514
00:26:22,000 --> 00:26:23,430
you don't just affect you, right?

515
00:26:23,430 --> 00:26:27,380
It doesn't just affect your profits
because you were horrible and

516
00:26:27,380 --> 00:26:29,840
didn't follow the right procedure and
everybody lost power.

517
00:26:29,840 --> 00:26:34,160
It affects everyone if our government
systems are on this type of power.

518
00:26:34,160 --> 00:26:38,120
If we don't have backup against
this type of power loss,

519
00:26:38,120 --> 00:26:39,270
we would be in a lot of trouble.

520
00:26:39,270 --> 00:26:41,260
So you've gotta watch out for
these things.

521
00:26:41,260 --> 00:26:43,270
And if you're in those kind of businesses,

522
00:26:43,270 --> 00:26:45,520
you're gonna run up
into these stuff a lot.

523
00:26:45,520 --> 00:26:48,190
Especially the HIPAA kind,
they don't play around with that.

524
00:26:48,190 --> 00:26:50,440
>> They do not.
All right, so

525
00:26:50,440 --> 00:26:52,760
again to break physical
security down again,

526
00:26:52,760 --> 00:26:57,040
we wanna just make sure we understand
physical security is not just a fence.

527
00:26:57,040 --> 00:27:02,890
But physical security is designed to
prevent access to your facilities and

528
00:27:02,890 --> 00:27:07,840
to your resources, and prevent damage
to my facilities, my resources,

529
00:27:07,840 --> 00:27:10,470
and us being a resource as well.

530
00:27:10,470 --> 00:27:13,920
And I've got different types of
controls that we can put in place.

531
00:27:13,920 --> 00:27:17,730
We can categorize those controls
as either being preventative,

532
00:27:17,730 --> 00:27:19,860
trying to prevent the event
in the first place.

533
00:27:19,860 --> 00:27:21,240
They can be detective.

534
00:27:21,240 --> 00:27:23,800
They can detect the event
as it's occurring.

535
00:27:23,800 --> 00:27:25,250
Or they can be corrective.

536
00:27:25,250 --> 00:27:28,530
They can try to fix something
after the event has occurred.

537
00:27:28,530 --> 00:27:32,210
And as we saw, they can also fall into
more than one of those categories, right?

538
00:27:32,210 --> 00:27:37,760
Cameras for example, can be preventative
as well as detective, right?

539
00:27:37,760 --> 00:27:40,640
>> Always better to be proactive
instead of reactive if you can

540
00:27:40,640 --> 00:27:42,060
possibly get away with that.

541
00:27:42,060 --> 00:27:46,800
>> Exactly, and then we gave you a whole
list of examples of different types of

542
00:27:46,800 --> 00:27:51,680
physical security controls, and
what categories they fell under so.

543
00:27:51,680 --> 00:27:56,502
Then Daniel, I think there's a real good
look at what physical security involves.

544
00:27:56,502 --> 00:27:59,528
>> Mm-hm.
>> And it's an important part of security

545
00:27:59,528 --> 00:28:03,412
that we cannot underestimate or
take for granted.

546
00:28:03,412 --> 00:28:07,582
And we've got to realize that you and
I, the every day end-user,

547
00:28:07,582 --> 00:28:09,380
are a big part of it, right?

548
00:28:09,380 --> 00:28:12,890
We're not talking to the IT guys and
gals, and things like that.

549
00:28:12,890 --> 00:28:14,790
Talking about everybody is a part of it.

550
00:28:14,790 --> 00:28:17,920
Physical security is one of those things
where we've all gotta pitch in and help.

551
00:28:17,920 --> 00:28:18,680
>> Yep.
Well said, Mike.

552
00:28:18,680 --> 00:28:19,500
Well said.

553
00:28:19,500 --> 00:28:21,920
Hopefully you guys learned
a lot watching this video.

554
00:28:21,920 --> 00:28:23,260
We sure hope you did.

555
00:28:23,260 --> 00:28:25,460
We sure had a lot of fun times making it.

556
00:28:25,460 --> 00:28:29,060
That being said, we have come to
the end of another great episode, and

557
00:28:29,060 --> 00:28:30,130
it is time to sign off.

558
00:28:30,130 --> 00:28:32,240
I've been you're host Daniel Lowrie.

559
00:28:32,240 --> 00:28:33,020
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

560
00:28:33,020 --> 00:28:33,912
>> And we'll see you next time.

561
00:28:33,912 --> 00:28:40,090
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Risk Assessment
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,861
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,861 --> 00:00:13,442
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13,442 --> 00:00:16,950
I'm gonna be your host, Mike Rodrick,
and with me today is Mr. Don Pezet.

4
00:00:16,950 --> 00:00:18,030
How you doing, Don?

5
00:00:18,030 --> 00:00:19,260
>> I'm doing great Mike.

6
00:00:19,260 --> 00:00:23,306
In this episode we're gonna move
into a commonly misunderstood topic,

7
00:00:23,306 --> 00:00:24,841
which is risk assessment.

8
00:00:24,841 --> 00:00:29,470
And really when you're talking about IT
security and really just a fundamental

9
00:00:29,470 --> 00:00:33,073
practice in security,
risk assessment is a big part of that.

10
00:00:33,073 --> 00:00:36,337
So we're going to spend some time
talking about how risk collection works,

11
00:00:36,337 --> 00:00:38,540
how you analyze risk and
determine your solution.

12
00:00:38,540 --> 00:00:40,300
What you're gonna do about
the risks that you find.

13
00:00:40,300 --> 00:00:41,600
So it's pretty good stuff.

14
00:00:41,600 --> 00:00:44,150
>> Yeah because we really got to
understand what it is we're dealing

15
00:00:44,150 --> 00:00:44,730
with right.

16
00:00:44,730 --> 00:00:46,659
If we want to protect our systems,

17
00:00:46,659 --> 00:00:49,993
we've got to understand what
threats face those systems.

18
00:00:49,993 --> 00:00:52,992
And we're got to decide how much we're
willing to spend to protect those kind of

19
00:00:52,992 --> 00:00:55,860
things, and that's really what
risk management is all about.

20
00:00:55,860 --> 00:00:58,980
>> Yeah, it really is, and
I say it's misunderstood.

21
00:00:58,980 --> 00:01:01,180
Risk is just a really big field.

22
00:01:01,180 --> 00:01:03,440
There's so
much stuff that falls under risk.

23
00:01:03,440 --> 00:01:06,230
Most of the universities
here in the United States,

24
00:01:06,230 --> 00:01:08,680
you can actually get a master's
degree in risk management.

25
00:01:08,680 --> 00:01:12,238
It's that big of a topic,
so there's a lot to it.

26
00:01:12,238 --> 00:01:16,955
As a IT security person, or just
somebody who uses computers in general,

27
00:01:16,955 --> 00:01:20,011
you know that your data's
at risk all the time.

28
00:01:20,011 --> 00:01:22,983
And that means that there's outside forces
that might be trying to gain access to

29
00:01:22,983 --> 00:01:23,780
your systems.

30
00:01:23,780 --> 00:01:27,620
There's accidents that you could make
that expose data even if people weren't

31
00:01:27,620 --> 00:01:28,432
looking for it.

32
00:01:28,432 --> 00:01:32,252
And then there's just random occurrences
that can happen, things like

33
00:01:32,252 --> 00:01:37,080
natural disasters, earthquakes,
hurricanes, floods, stuff of that nature.

34
00:01:37,080 --> 00:01:41,440
Those are all things that could
occur that could impact the security

35
00:01:41,440 --> 00:01:42,880
of your environment.

36
00:01:42,880 --> 00:01:46,310
And so we've gotta have a good
understanding of what's out there so

37
00:01:46,310 --> 00:01:48,530
we can determine a plan.

38
00:01:48,530 --> 00:01:51,560
That's part of what information
security is all about, is not so

39
00:01:51,560 --> 00:01:56,420
much reacting to what's going on,
but being proactive and

40
00:01:56,420 --> 00:02:02,270
having plans in place to stop or be able
to handle issues when they do occur.

41
00:02:02,270 --> 00:02:04,860
And that all starts with risk analysis.

42
00:02:05,910 --> 00:02:10,145
Now with risk analysis, we basically look
at what's out there in the environment,

43
00:02:10,145 --> 00:02:13,385
and we try and figure out what
our risks are, right, Mike?

44
00:02:13,385 --> 00:02:16,915
>> Exactly, so things like hurricanes,
for example, here in Florida,

45
00:02:16,915 --> 00:02:18,345
that could be a very big risk.

46
00:02:18,345 --> 00:02:21,925
If I live up in northern Canada,
maybe not so much of a risk.

47
00:02:21,925 --> 00:02:23,085
Is that we're talking about here?

48
00:02:23,085 --> 00:02:24,725
>> Yeah, absolutely.

49
00:02:24,725 --> 00:02:26,485
Everybody has different risks.

50
00:02:26,485 --> 00:02:29,610
I can't give you guys a list, like,
here you go, these are your risks.

51
00:02:29,610 --> 00:02:31,780
There's some that we all have in common,
right?

52
00:02:31,780 --> 00:02:36,140
If your company is connected to
the Internet, you've got a common risk,

53
00:02:36,140 --> 00:02:37,820
the same risk we have here at ITProTV.

54
00:02:37,820 --> 00:02:39,180
That outside people,

55
00:02:39,180 --> 00:02:42,990
unauthorized personnel, could break
into your network and access your data.

56
00:02:42,990 --> 00:02:45,730
But even that common risk is different.

57
00:02:45,730 --> 00:02:51,120
Here at ITProTV, if somebody were to break
into our network they'd get our episodes.

58
00:02:51,120 --> 00:02:53,330
We don't have any customer
data here in the building,

59
00:02:53,330 --> 00:02:54,980
we don't have any financial data.

60
00:02:56,060 --> 00:02:59,850
We all might have credit cards in our own
wallets, but not on our computer systems.

61
00:02:59,850 --> 00:03:04,534
So the risk for us is there but
what's called the impact, right.

62
00:03:04,534 --> 00:03:06,892
The impact is how damaging
that risk could be.

63
00:03:06,892 --> 00:03:08,930
The impact for us is very minimal.

64
00:03:08,930 --> 00:03:13,160
But if you're a hospital or
a financial institution like a bank and

65
00:03:13,160 --> 00:03:17,830
somebody breaks into your network and gets
those records, well, that's a big deal.

66
00:03:17,830 --> 00:03:20,800
You've got to disclose that, you've got to
let your people know, your customers know,

67
00:03:20,800 --> 00:03:24,040
that their data was compromised,
and it's a huge PR debacle.

68
00:03:24,040 --> 00:03:29,740
So when we take a look at a risk, it's not
just identifying that the risk exists,

69
00:03:29,740 --> 00:03:32,500
but figuring out
the characteristics of that risk.

70
00:03:32,500 --> 00:03:36,040
And in the risk world,
there's two words we have to remember, and

71
00:03:36,040 --> 00:03:39,090
it's probability and impact.

72
00:03:39,090 --> 00:03:41,790
Every risk has a probability, right?

73
00:03:41,790 --> 00:03:44,410
What are the odds of that risk occurring?

74
00:03:44,410 --> 00:03:46,600
And then there's the impact.

75
00:03:46,600 --> 00:03:50,020
If that risk does occur,
what impact does it have on our company?

76
00:03:50,020 --> 00:03:53,130
And so, that's what your security
professionals are doing at your company,

77
00:03:53,130 --> 00:03:57,100
is they're building up what
are called risk responses that say,

78
00:03:57,100 --> 00:03:59,350
if this risk occurs here's
what we're going to do.

79
00:03:59,350 --> 00:04:02,230
And they're categorizing those and
ranking them and doing all of this work.

80
00:04:02,230 --> 00:04:05,170
And so in this episode I want to give
you guys kind of a preview of what

81
00:04:05,170 --> 00:04:05,990
that's like.

82
00:04:05,990 --> 00:04:09,207
I don't want to go through the whole
bureaucratic paperwork side of things.

83
00:04:09,207 --> 00:04:12,673
I just want to show you what's going
through the minds of the security

84
00:04:12,673 --> 00:04:14,227
personnel at your company, so

85
00:04:14,227 --> 00:04:17,296
that you have a better idea of
why it is they have these plans.

86
00:04:17,296 --> 00:04:20,304
And what is you're supposed to
do when something does go wrong,

87
00:04:20,304 --> 00:04:24,160
which we'll talk more about in
our business resumption episode.

88
00:04:24,160 --> 00:04:27,950
But for right now, let's look at just
some of these little characteristics.

89
00:04:27,950 --> 00:04:30,640
So Mike, if you work for an IT company,

90
00:04:30,640 --> 00:04:33,400
what are some common risks
that you'd have to plan for?

91
00:04:33,400 --> 00:04:36,210
>> The first thing I think about
is like power outages, right?

92
00:04:36,210 --> 00:04:38,880
Because everything I do,
my network relies on power.

93
00:04:38,880 --> 00:04:42,700
All my routers, my switches,
my end systems, and things like that.

94
00:04:42,700 --> 00:04:44,810
>> All right, so what I'm going to
do is I'm going to start writing

95
00:04:44,810 --> 00:04:45,670
some of these down.

96
00:04:46,720 --> 00:04:50,110
When somebody's doing risk analysis, they
build a document called a risk register,

97
00:04:50,110 --> 00:04:53,260
and I've got an example of
a risk register right here.

98
00:04:53,260 --> 00:04:56,680
In the first stages of risk analysis,
you just sit around and

99
00:04:56,680 --> 00:04:58,490
you talk about what's out there.

100
00:04:58,490 --> 00:04:59,560
What are the possibilities?

101
00:04:59,560 --> 00:05:04,260
So my first risk, the one that Mike
just mentioned, was power failure, okay?

102
00:05:04,260 --> 00:05:07,480
So I'm just gonna kinda catalog
that power failure, all right, or

103
00:05:07,480 --> 00:05:08,840
some other risk that we have.

104
00:05:08,840 --> 00:05:12,981
I mentioned natural disaster, right, we'll
do a hurricane, which I think I can spell.

105
00:05:12,981 --> 00:05:13,581
Is it two Rs?

106
00:05:13,581 --> 00:05:16,002
Yeah, I guess so, so
we'll do the hurricane.

107
00:05:16,002 --> 00:05:16,562
What are some other ones?

108
00:05:16,562 --> 00:05:18,241
>> Some fire maybe.

109
00:05:18,241 --> 00:05:19,601
>> Fire.

110
00:05:19,601 --> 00:05:20,320
>> Let's see, what else?

111
00:05:20,320 --> 00:05:21,190
We got flood damage.

112
00:05:22,820 --> 00:05:25,070
That might go along with hurricane though,
or something.

113
00:05:25,070 --> 00:05:27,650
>> Yeah, and let's throw some
technical ones in here, right?

114
00:05:27,650 --> 00:05:29,370
Let's pump a few other things out.

115
00:05:29,370 --> 00:05:31,440
So we've got like,
power failure, hurricane.

116
00:05:31,440 --> 00:05:35,901
We'll throw in hardware failure, right?

117
00:05:35,901 --> 00:05:39,345
You might have a hard drive or
power supply die, a motherboard might die.

118
00:05:39,345 --> 00:05:43,344
>> ISP failure.
>> We might have an intrusion.

119
00:05:43,344 --> 00:05:45,190
Yeah we might have an ISP failure.

120
00:05:45,190 --> 00:05:46,640
Right, so you wanna make a list.

121
00:05:46,640 --> 00:05:49,680
And I've got enough room here for
five, so I'll stop at five.

122
00:05:49,680 --> 00:05:54,050
But it could be that you've got 100,
that you've got 1,000, right?

123
00:05:54,050 --> 00:05:55,990
Your risk register could be very,
very big but for

124
00:05:55,990 --> 00:05:59,070
the sake of simplicity I'll
keep this one kind of small.

125
00:05:59,070 --> 00:06:03,080
But yeah, absolutely,
you could have break-ins and theft,

126
00:06:03,080 --> 00:06:07,570
you could have simple things like
employee calls in sick, right?

127
00:06:07,570 --> 00:06:08,630
Take this show for example.

128
00:06:08,630 --> 00:06:11,130
So, Mike and I, we're here,
we're on the show.

129
00:06:11,130 --> 00:06:13,700
If Mike were to call in sick today,
what would happen to the show?

130
00:06:13,700 --> 00:06:14,490
It would derail it.

131
00:06:14,490 --> 00:06:16,390
I need some kind of plan in place.

132
00:06:16,390 --> 00:06:17,950
Who's going to come in and
stand in for Mike.

133
00:06:17,950 --> 00:06:21,550
Who has as good hair as Mike, that could
come over here and be on the show.

134
00:06:21,550 --> 00:06:23,481
So, it's hard to line
somebody up like that.

135
00:06:23,481 --> 00:06:25,822
>> [LAUGH] Thanks Don, I appreciate that.

136
00:06:25,822 --> 00:06:29,740
>> So, these are the things that we have
to plan for when we do risk analysis.

137
00:06:29,740 --> 00:06:32,290
Now, it can even be things that
are a little more outlandish.

138
00:06:32,290 --> 00:06:33,808
I'm gonna add here, for risk five.

139
00:06:33,808 --> 00:06:37,470
Meteor impact, right?

140
00:06:37,470 --> 00:06:39,540
Meteor impact, that's a big deal.

141
00:06:39,540 --> 00:06:41,910
>> There's definitely a possibility,
and if that did occur,

142
00:06:41,910 --> 00:06:43,880
I can imagine that would
do a lot of damage.

143
00:06:43,880 --> 00:06:47,400
>> And with each of these risks
we're trying to think of two

144
00:06:47,400 --> 00:06:50,850
characteristics of each one,
the probability and the impact.

145
00:06:50,850 --> 00:06:53,170
Probability is how likely
it's going to occur and

146
00:06:53,170 --> 00:06:55,360
the impact is how much damage it'll do.

147
00:06:55,360 --> 00:06:57,880
Now damage is typically measured in money.

148
00:06:57,880 --> 00:07:01,910
So in terms of dollar signs,
how much money is this gonna cost you?

149
00:07:01,910 --> 00:07:04,180
For us here at ITProTV,

150
00:07:05,240 --> 00:07:09,200
we don't have any of our streaming servers
right here in the building with us.

151
00:07:09,200 --> 00:07:10,660
So when you're watching this episode,

152
00:07:10,660 --> 00:07:13,200
you're actually not talking
to our building at all.

153
00:07:13,200 --> 00:07:16,890
So if our building were to lose power,
the website would still be up,

154
00:07:16,890 --> 00:07:20,140
you could access the video on demand,
things like that, but other things,

155
00:07:20,140 --> 00:07:22,148
like our live feed might be down.

156
00:07:22,148 --> 00:07:24,780
You might not be able watch us live,
but you'd be able to watch us recorded.

157
00:07:24,780 --> 00:07:28,880
So there's a small impact created there,
but it's not that big.

158
00:07:28,880 --> 00:07:32,700
Most of our customers won't be impacted,
it's really not a big deal.

159
00:07:32,700 --> 00:07:37,430
So we take something like power failure
for us, the impact might only be a 1.

160
00:07:37,430 --> 00:07:39,120
And I'm doing this on a scale of 1 to 5.

161
00:07:39,120 --> 00:07:41,160
You can use whatever scale you want.

162
00:07:41,160 --> 00:07:45,070
I find a scale of 1 to 5 is
the easiest to get good answers.

163
00:07:45,070 --> 00:07:46,320
The bigger your scale,

164
00:07:46,320 --> 00:07:49,000
the more difficult it is to like
actually assign a number to something.

165
00:07:49,000 --> 00:07:52,198
So I'm just saying, on a scale of 1 to 5,
a power failure for

166
00:07:52,198 --> 00:07:53,620
us would be an impact of 1.

167
00:07:55,280 --> 00:07:57,493
Other things though, like a hurricane.

168
00:07:57,493 --> 00:07:59,605
A hurricane here in Florida is a big deal.

169
00:07:59,605 --> 00:08:00,778
It can cause power outages.

170
00:08:00,778 --> 00:08:02,015
It can cause floods.

171
00:08:02,015 --> 00:08:03,850
