And they get in.

406
00:18:30,890 --> 00:18:33,150
And now you've got to do a risk response,
right?

407
00:18:33,150 --> 00:18:35,270
You've gotta react and
it takes some action.

408
00:18:35,270 --> 00:18:38,900
But mitigating is trying to prevent the
risk from happening in the first place.

409
00:18:38,900 --> 00:18:42,190
>> So really we're reducing that
possibility is what we're ending up doing.

410
00:18:42,190 --> 00:18:44,340
>> That's exactly it,
you reduce the probability and

411
00:18:44,340 --> 00:18:46,400
that changes that risk's characteristics.

412
00:18:47,590 --> 00:18:51,090
You can also do the next one,
which is risk avoidance.

413
00:18:51,090 --> 00:18:54,320
Where we say, okay, if I'm worried
about a hacker on the Internet getting

414
00:18:54,320 --> 00:18:56,810
into my system,
I just won't plug into the Internet.

415
00:18:56,810 --> 00:19:00,330
If I'm not plugged into the Internet
they can't get in that way,

416
00:19:00,330 --> 00:19:02,460
I just avoided the risk.

417
00:19:02,460 --> 00:19:05,770
I didn't reduce the probability,
I eliminated the probability,

418
00:19:05,770 --> 00:19:08,195
it's not going to happen, right?

419
00:19:08,195 --> 00:19:11,590
And when it's something like a,
I use an example of an outdoor wedding.

420
00:19:11,590 --> 00:19:15,230
I'm gonna have an outdoor wedding,
well it might rain, that's a risk.

421
00:19:15,230 --> 00:19:18,811
All right, well forget that, I'll have
an indoor wedding, we just avoided it.

422
00:19:18,811 --> 00:19:22,171
>> But if your heart was set on
having that outdoor wedding,

423
00:19:22,171 --> 00:19:24,912
which I wouldn't
necessarily care about it.

424
00:19:24,912 --> 00:19:27,951
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if your heart was set on Internet

425
00:19:27,951 --> 00:19:31,138
service, I wanna host a website,
then is saying I'm gonna,

426
00:19:31,138 --> 00:19:35,420
that you're gonna disconnect from
the Internet, is that even a possibility?

427
00:19:35,420 --> 00:19:37,000
>> It's not really gonna work
out too well for you is it?

428
00:19:37,000 --> 00:19:37,990
>> It isn't.

429
00:19:37,990 --> 00:19:40,810
So, risk avoidance doesn't always work,
right?

430
00:19:40,810 --> 00:19:42,790
It's just not always possible.

431
00:19:42,790 --> 00:19:46,798
So, while it's great, it's 100% guaranteed
that risk is not going to occur,

432
00:19:46,798 --> 00:19:48,161
it's not always an option.

433
00:19:49,761 --> 00:19:52,840
Risk transference is another one.

434
00:19:52,840 --> 00:19:57,020
Transference is you say, okay, look,
I don't know to handle this risk.

435
00:19:57,020 --> 00:19:59,800
I know it's there,
I just don't have the means or whatever.

436
00:19:59,800 --> 00:20:03,010
So instead, I'm gonna transfer
the risk to somebody else.

437
00:20:03,010 --> 00:20:06,180
Instead of me dealing with it, I'm gonna
get them to deal with it, all right?

438
00:20:06,180 --> 00:20:09,070
Now I know that sounds like,
who would let you do that?

439
00:20:09,070 --> 00:20:11,310
Well, it's these people
called insurance companies.

440
00:20:11,310 --> 00:20:13,090
>> Yeah, there's people out
there that do that for us.

441
00:20:13,090 --> 00:20:16,051
That's their whole job,
is to take that risk from us.

442
00:20:16,051 --> 00:20:18,635
>> And while it sounds risky for
them to do that,

443
00:20:18,635 --> 00:20:20,770
boy do they make some money, right.

444
00:20:20,770 --> 00:20:21,710
Yes they do.

445
00:20:21,710 --> 00:20:25,073
Insurance companies make tons of money
because they look at the odds and

446
00:20:25,073 --> 00:20:27,640
they say, okay, I'm going to insure you.

447
00:20:27,640 --> 00:20:32,515
If hackers break into your system,
I'm gonna give you a $5 million bond,

448
00:20:32,515 --> 00:20:35,800
and if they break in,
I'll give you $5 million.

449
00:20:35,800 --> 00:20:39,930
And you can use that to wage a PR campaign
to get your company back in a better

450
00:20:39,930 --> 00:20:43,190
lights and beef up your security
to do all this stuff if it occurs.

451
00:20:43,190 --> 00:20:43,920
If it doesn't occur,

452
00:20:43,920 --> 00:20:49,080
though, you're paying that insurance
policy month after month after month, and

453
00:20:49,080 --> 00:20:52,410
when it doesn't occur, insurance companies
are just sticking that in their pocket.

454
00:20:52,410 --> 00:20:53,750
Ad that's money they made.

455
00:20:53,750 --> 00:20:57,200
They make that money because
they're assuming the risk from you.

456
00:20:57,200 --> 00:20:58,430
Right, that's the trade-off.

457
00:20:58,430 --> 00:21:00,780
We do this with car insurance and
medical insurance.

458
00:21:00,780 --> 00:21:03,780
You're saying, I don't know if I'm
going to get hurt anytime soon.

459
00:21:03,780 --> 00:21:07,650
Well, they're like, I haven't had to go to
the doctor in probably three years now, so

460
00:21:07,650 --> 00:21:11,340
for the last three years I've been
paying for medical insurance.

461
00:21:11,340 --> 00:21:12,540
Never used it, not a single time.

462
00:21:12,540 --> 00:21:15,510
The insurance company puts
that in their pockets, right.

463
00:21:15,510 --> 00:21:19,600
But somewhere out there is
somebody who got sick, and

464
00:21:19,600 --> 00:21:21,760
they were in the hospital for weeks.

465
00:21:21,760 --> 00:21:24,850
And they racked up more medical bills
than the interest they'd paid in

466
00:21:24,850 --> 00:21:26,060
their entire life.

467
00:21:26,060 --> 00:21:30,140
And so the insurance company lost money
on them, but they made money on me.

468
00:21:30,140 --> 00:21:31,430
And that's how insurance companies work.

469
00:21:31,430 --> 00:21:33,350
So that's why we're
able to transfer risks.

470
00:21:33,350 --> 00:21:37,560
And risk transference is almost
always in the form of insurance.

471
00:21:37,560 --> 00:21:40,660
But it could also be in the form
of contracting, we do that, right?

472
00:21:40,660 --> 00:21:43,170
Our website could get hacked into.

473
00:21:43,170 --> 00:21:44,610
That's a real problem, right?

474
00:21:44,610 --> 00:21:47,840
Well, if Mike and
I had had time to sit down and

475
00:21:47,840 --> 00:21:52,840
just be IT security guys, we'd be
able to secure the site pretty well.

476
00:21:52,840 --> 00:21:54,300
But the reality is we don't have time for
that, right?

477
00:21:54,300 --> 00:21:55,740
We're here on the show and so

478
00:21:55,740 --> 00:21:58,500
somebody could be breaking in
right now and we're distracted.

479
00:21:59,600 --> 00:22:03,230
So instead, we contract that out
to a company called Security.

480
00:22:03,230 --> 00:22:05,875
And they manage the security
of our web site.

481
00:22:05,875 --> 00:22:09,385
They filter all the access and
make sure that we don't get broken into.

482
00:22:09,385 --> 00:22:11,915
We've transferred that risk over to them,
all right?

483
00:22:11,915 --> 00:22:14,835
And if a compromise were to occur,
they take care of it.

484
00:22:14,835 --> 00:22:16,705
They do the risk response, they handle it.

485
00:22:16,705 --> 00:22:18,015
We've transferred it over to them.

486
00:22:18,015 --> 00:22:19,165
We pay them money, right?

487
00:22:19,165 --> 00:22:20,930
So, just like an insurance company,

488
00:22:20,930 --> 00:22:24,030
we pay them,
they'll handle the event when it occurs.

489
00:22:24,030 --> 00:22:28,120
So that's an important part
of dealing with a risk.

490
00:22:28,120 --> 00:22:29,885
>> And then there's one more
we've got to deal with.

491
00:22:29,885 --> 00:22:31,640
[LAUGH]
>> That's my favorite one

492
00:22:31,640 --> 00:22:32,840
which is acceptance.

493
00:22:32,840 --> 00:22:33,915
>> I like this one too, it's pretty easy.

494
00:22:33,915 --> 00:22:35,580
[LAUGH]
>> We've reached acceptance.

495
00:22:35,580 --> 00:22:39,620
Risk acceptance is where you do nothing,
you just say whatever yeah,

496
00:22:39,620 --> 00:22:40,280
that might happen.

497
00:22:40,280 --> 00:22:41,430
I'm okay with that.

498
00:22:41,430 --> 00:22:43,640
>> Don, that doesn't sound
like a very good choice.

499
00:22:43,640 --> 00:22:45,780
Is that ever actually one we use?

500
00:22:45,780 --> 00:22:46,445
>> We use it here.

501
00:22:46,445 --> 00:22:50,550
>> [LAUGH]
>> We do not have meteor impact insurance.

502
00:22:50,550 --> 00:22:52,510
I can tell you that right now.

503
00:22:52,510 --> 00:22:55,110
Our insurance policy for
the company, for the building,

504
00:22:55,110 --> 00:22:58,325
it all reads that it
excludes force majeure.

505
00:22:58,325 --> 00:23:02,090
>> [LAUGH]
>> Acts of God or even acts of war,

506
00:23:02,090 --> 00:23:03,990
things like that get kind of left out.

507
00:23:03,990 --> 00:23:09,260
But with meteor impact it's so
unlikely that it's going to occur.

508
00:23:09,260 --> 00:23:12,910
I mean, it's really about the same odds of
a tyrannosaurus attacking the building.

509
00:23:12,910 --> 00:23:14,270
It's almost the same.

510
00:23:14,270 --> 00:23:19,820
So, because it's so unlikely,
you don't bother planning for it.

511
00:23:19,820 --> 00:23:25,030
Any money you put forth to your meteor
defense plan or whatever, it's a waste.

512
00:23:25,030 --> 00:23:28,020
>> We could go out and try to find
insurance against meteors, and pay

513
00:23:28,020 --> 00:23:31,140
a pretty penny for that, or start building
some shield around the building, right?

514
00:23:31,140 --> 00:23:31,950
We could take from this.

515
00:23:31,950 --> 00:23:35,550
>> We could buy a shuttle and
get Bruce Willis and Ben Affleck, and

516
00:23:35,550 --> 00:23:37,680
maybe even Steve Buscemi, and get this up.

517
00:23:37,680 --> 00:23:39,630
It'd cost a lot of money and
we'd never use it.

518
00:23:39,630 --> 00:23:41,658
They'd sit around bored all
day telling funny stories.

519
00:23:41,658 --> 00:23:44,720
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's the kind of thing

520
00:23:44,720 --> 00:23:49,150
is you have to recognize when a risk is
not worth planning for and there are some.

521
00:23:49,150 --> 00:23:52,202
Now there are times where
companies do risk acceptance when

522
00:23:52,202 --> 00:23:53,492
it's a real risk right?

523
00:23:53,492 --> 00:23:58,380
And these are the horror stories that
we hear of like when a car manufacturer

524
00:23:58,380 --> 00:24:00,173
finds a flaw in a seat belt.

525
00:24:00,173 --> 00:24:03,871
And they determine that the recall would
cost more than just settling the lawsuits

526
00:24:03,871 --> 00:24:06,605
that happen because of the flaws,
so they accept the risk and

527
00:24:06,605 --> 00:24:09,850
they let it ride and they just
pay out on those lawsuits, right?

528
00:24:09,850 --> 00:24:11,020
That's really negative.

529
00:24:11,020 --> 00:24:14,090
That's not what good people do, right?

530
00:24:14,090 --> 00:24:16,370
But there are mathematics involved, right?

531
00:24:16,370 --> 00:24:21,170
We have to look at the financial
impact versus the cost of insuring.

532
00:24:21,170 --> 00:24:26,700
And just a general rule of thumb but
most people use is 15 to 20%.

533
00:24:26,700 --> 00:24:31,390
When you have an impact that's going
to cost you x amount of dollars,

534
00:24:31,390 --> 00:24:37,020
you should spend 15 to 20% of
that value to prevent that loss.

535
00:24:37,020 --> 00:24:41,270
So if I'm worried about power outages and
I know that a power outage is gonna impact

536
00:24:41,270 --> 00:24:46,160
my company, and it might cost us say
$2,000 per hour that we're down.

537
00:24:46,160 --> 00:24:48,060
Then I might look at that and say well,

538
00:24:48,060 --> 00:24:49,960
15 to 20% of that is
about 200 bucks per hour.

539
00:24:49,960 --> 00:24:53,860
So I'm going to go ahead or
is it 400 bucks per hour?

540
00:24:53,860 --> 00:24:55,120
>> Eh, the math has got to be close.

541
00:24:55,120 --> 00:24:57,030
>> No, 200 bucks,
I was right in the first place, so

542
00:24:57,030 --> 00:25:01,490
I might spend $200 to protect for
that power outage.

543
00:25:01,490 --> 00:25:05,240
And $200, that will get you a UPS for your
critical system in your router maybe, and

544
00:25:05,240 --> 00:25:08,540
that's enough to keep you up
during that power outage.

545
00:25:08,540 --> 00:25:09,580
It's definitely based on money.

546
00:25:09,580 --> 00:25:11,210
If you're a company like Amazon.

547
00:25:11,210 --> 00:25:13,770
I read once in one of their quarterly
earnings reports where they were talking

548
00:25:13,770 --> 00:25:14,950
about their earnings.

549
00:25:14,950 --> 00:25:18,590
And how they have over $2
million in sales per hour.

550
00:25:18,590 --> 00:25:19,560
>> Wow.

551
00:25:19,560 --> 00:25:23,140
>> So if their website were to go down,
those are sales they wouldn't be getting.

552
00:25:23,140 --> 00:25:24,140
That's a big deal.

553
00:25:24,140 --> 00:25:27,810
So they're going to spend hundreds
of thousands probably millions,

554
00:25:27,810 --> 00:25:29,900
really, in preventing
that type of failure.

555
00:25:31,120 --> 00:25:34,210
So that's all part of risk analysis and

556
00:25:34,210 --> 00:25:36,980
I know, if you ever talk to
somebody who does risk analysis,

557
00:25:36,980 --> 00:25:40,090
they talk about how it's boring, it's
a lot of paperwork and stuff like that.

558
00:25:40,090 --> 00:25:43,500
But it is really important work,
right, cuz there's so much risk.

559
00:25:43,500 --> 00:25:46,750
>> Yeah, if you don't know where to spend
your resources, you can end up taking

560
00:25:46,750 --> 00:25:49,650
your company's money and spending
all of your time in your effort and

561
00:25:49,650 --> 00:25:52,163
your money trying to protect
against things like meteors.

562
00:25:52,163 --> 00:25:56,066
And if I didn't have that matrix, if I
didn't have a way to visualize which one

563
00:25:56,066 --> 00:25:59,793
was gonna have that bigger overall impact,
I could be spending my money and

564
00:25:59,793 --> 00:26:01,560
wasting my time.

565
00:26:01,560 --> 00:26:02,790
>> Absolutely.

566
00:26:02,790 --> 00:26:03,310
All right, well Mike.

567
00:26:03,310 --> 00:26:05,290
I think that's a pretty good
rundown of risk analysis.

568
00:26:05,290 --> 00:26:06,840
Just for that for the average person,

569
00:26:06,840 --> 00:26:11,010
again if you are a risk analyst,
obviously there is a ton more to it.

570
00:26:11,010 --> 00:26:11,750
It's a whole art.

571
00:26:11,750 --> 00:26:13,380
There's a lot information out there.

572
00:26:13,380 --> 00:26:15,530
But I think having a basic
understanding of risk and

573
00:26:15,530 --> 00:26:17,500
how we handle that is important for
every employee.

574
00:26:17,500 --> 00:26:18,780
>> Absolutely, all right.

575
00:26:18,780 --> 00:26:20,460
Well, we appreciate you guys tuning in.

576
00:26:20,460 --> 00:26:23,831
We hope you enjoyed watching as
much as we did shooting this.

577
00:26:23,831 --> 00:26:25,952
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

578
00:26:25,952 --> 00:26:33,920
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

episodes.title: Business Resumption/Recovery
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:02,841
[SOUND]

2
00:00:02,841 --> 00:00:10,628
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10,628 --> 00:00:13,110
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:13,110 --> 00:00:15,010
I'm your host, Mike Broderick.

5
00:00:15,010 --> 00:00:16,600
And with me today is Mr. Don Pizet.

6
00:00:16,600 --> 00:00:17,690
How you doing, Don?

7
00:00:17,690 --> 00:00:19,060
>> I'm doing great, Mike.

8
00:00:19,060 --> 00:00:22,380
We're coming back to you with another
episode of Security Fundamentals.

9
00:00:22,380 --> 00:00:26,163
And in this video we're going to be
talking about business resumption and

10
00:00:26,163 --> 00:00:27,110
recovery.

11
00:00:27,110 --> 00:00:31,460
These are important concepts that really
every company should have a plan for,

12
00:00:31,460 --> 00:00:33,460
should have some documents in place.

13
00:00:33,460 --> 00:00:36,890
And what we wanna do is cover what
they are, what these concepts are, and

14
00:00:36,890 --> 00:00:39,610
how they impact you,
the average employee in a company.

15
00:00:39,610 --> 00:00:43,230
And really what, well why would
we even care about these things?

16
00:00:43,230 --> 00:00:45,230
>> So with business resumption recovery,

17
00:00:45,230 --> 00:00:48,020
it kinda makes me assume that
something bad has happened.

18
00:00:48,020 --> 00:00:52,690
Something has gone wrong, and
we're trying to get back.

19
00:00:52,690 --> 00:00:53,750
>> Absolutely, yeah.

20
00:00:53,750 --> 00:00:55,860
And you know you'll hear a couple
of terms that refer to this,

21
00:00:55,860 --> 00:00:57,380
and they do get a little confusing.

22
00:00:57,380 --> 00:00:59,500
You'll hear some people talk
about disaster recovery,

23
00:00:59,500 --> 00:01:03,810
and you hear people talk about business
resumption, or business recovery.

24
00:01:03,810 --> 00:01:06,690
Now these terms, they're pretty similar.

25
00:01:06,690 --> 00:01:08,980
A lot of people use them interchangeably,
but

26
00:01:08,980 --> 00:01:10,710
they do actually mean different things.

27
00:01:10,710 --> 00:01:12,930
Right.
So disaster recovery,

28
00:01:12,930 --> 00:01:16,300
like the name implies,
there's been a disaster.

29
00:01:16,300 --> 00:01:18,830
Something really bad has happened, and

30
00:01:18,830 --> 00:01:24,230
that something bad is is typically an
entire data center winks out of existence.

31
00:01:24,230 --> 00:01:27,790
Or you know a fire, hurricane, explosion.

32
00:01:27,790 --> 00:01:29,740
Maybe it's the Internet connection fails,
and

33
00:01:29,740 --> 00:01:31,900
it's completely severed from the Internet.

34
00:01:31,900 --> 00:01:35,320
Something of that nature that makes that
whole data center just not available.

35
00:01:35,320 --> 00:01:37,880
That's a disaster, right?

36
00:01:37,880 --> 00:01:41,990
Versus business resumption where
we're really just talking about

37
00:01:41,990 --> 00:01:44,620
any little thing that
might interrupt service.

38
00:01:44,620 --> 00:01:48,680
So maybe a hard drive fails in a server,
and the server stops responding.

39
00:01:48,680 --> 00:01:50,420
Your other servers are still up,
your network is up.

40
00:01:50,420 --> 00:01:52,440
It's just this one point of impact, right?

41
00:01:52,440 --> 00:01:54,290
This one point of failure that's happened.

42
00:01:54,290 --> 00:01:56,670
That's where we need business resumption.

43
00:01:56,670 --> 00:01:59,550
Now, business resumption can
encompass disaster recovery.

44
00:01:59,550 --> 00:02:02,970
They can be grouped together, and
that's what a lot of companies do.

45
00:02:02,970 --> 00:02:06,980
Because what normally happens
is business resumption

46
00:02:06,980 --> 00:02:11,330
is a plan that your company has that says,
when a failure happens or

47
00:02:11,330 --> 00:02:15,530
when something happens that impacts my
company doing business, here's the bare

48
00:02:15,530 --> 00:02:20,790
minimum I need to do to get my
company back to doing business again.

49
00:02:20,790 --> 00:02:22,840
We won't be,
like let's say we measured health in 100%.

50
00:02:22,840 --> 00:02:27,214
So when our company was completely
healthy, it was at 100% capacity.

51
00:02:27,214 --> 00:02:30,260
And then I have a failure,
and I drop to 0%.

52
00:02:30,260 --> 00:02:31,960
I'm at no capacity.

53
00:02:31,960 --> 00:02:35,700
Well, business resumption gets us just
enough to be at acceptable levels.

54
00:02:35,700 --> 00:02:39,460
So maybe we're 50, 60% of what we
used to be, but at least we're up and

55
00:02:39,460 --> 00:02:40,770
doing business again.

56
00:02:40,770 --> 00:02:41,930
Right?

57
00:02:41,930 --> 00:02:42,580
But we're not 100%.

58
00:02:42,580 --> 00:02:45,630
And with disaster recovery that's
getting us the rest of that way.

59
00:02:45,630 --> 00:02:47,000
Getting us all the way back up to 100%,

60
00:02:47,000 --> 00:02:50,730
so we're back to the way that we
used to be before the disaster.

61
00:02:50,730 --> 00:02:51,510
Right?

62
00:02:51,510 --> 00:02:55,320
So as an example, I used to work for
a bank, and at the bank,

63
00:02:55,320 --> 00:02:58,130
if we had an outage,
like if our primary data center went down,

64
00:02:59,170 --> 00:03:04,340
all the branch offices, they'd lose their
connectivity back to our banking system.

65
00:03:04,340 --> 00:03:08,110
So if a customer walked up to that teller
and said, hey, I'd like to withdraw $100.

66
00:03:08,110 --> 00:03:10,060
The teller would say oh,
I'm sorry my computer system's down.

67
00:03:11,120 --> 00:03:15,130
And the customer would look at them and
say well, I need my money.

68
00:03:15,130 --> 00:03:15,855
I've gotta have my money.

69
00:03:15,855 --> 00:03:18,247
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Sometimes they get irate,

70
00:03:18,247 --> 00:03:19,320
right?

71
00:03:19,320 --> 00:03:21,410
They expect that access to their funds.

72
00:03:21,410 --> 00:03:24,670
And there's a lot of
other things that we did.

73
00:03:24,670 --> 00:03:27,910
We had email servers and
a website and so on.

74
00:03:27,910 --> 00:03:29,820
But if our email went down,
if our website went down,

75
00:03:29,820 --> 00:03:31,800
our customers didn't
really care about that.

76
00:03:31,800 --> 00:03:35,260
They wanted their money,
that's just what a bank is all about.

77
00:03:35,260 --> 00:03:39,510
So we had a business resumption
plan that said look, if

78
00:03:39,510 --> 00:03:44,310
you lose connectivity to the primary data
center, then here's how you handle this.

79
00:03:44,310 --> 00:03:46,370
You can give customers up to a $1,000 and

80
00:03:46,370 --> 00:03:50,960
just do it on paper instead
of on the computer.

81
00:03:50,960 --> 00:03:53,760
And then, once the computer systems are
back up, we can go to log those entries.

82
00:03:53,760 --> 00:03:56,660
And if they withdrew more than a thousand
dollars, and we'll treat as a line of

83
00:03:56,660 --> 00:03:59,710
credit you know if they drew
more out than they actually had.

84
00:03:59,710 --> 00:04:01,790
We'll treat it as a line of credit,
and we'll collect that way.

85
00:04:01,790 --> 00:04:05,030
But if they had it within their account,
then we just remove that and

86
00:04:05,030 --> 00:04:06,310
that's the end of it.

87
00:04:06,310 --> 00:04:07,970
We were able to limp by and

88
00:04:07,970 --> 00:04:11,620
do business until we were able to
actually recover from the failure.

89
00:04:11,620 --> 00:04:14,300
That's what business
resumption is all about.

90
00:04:14,300 --> 00:04:15,640
It's basically a plan B.

91
00:04:15,640 --> 00:04:18,310
Plan A is things are working great
the way they're supposed to.

92
00:04:18,310 --> 00:04:22,140
Plan B is what do we do when plan
A is not working out so well.

93
00:04:22,140 --> 00:04:24,528
>> And it's really important this
is done ahead of time, right?

94
00:04:24,528 --> 00:04:28,638
We don't wanna wait until the disaster or
the small failure has occurred, and

95
00:04:28,638 --> 00:04:30,953
try to figure out what
it is we're gonna do.

96
00:04:30,953 --> 00:04:32,140
>> Yeah.

97
00:04:32,140 --> 00:04:34,660
When you're under pressure,
when an event is occurring.

98
00:04:34,660 --> 00:04:36,680
You've got customers
that are lining up here.

99
00:04:36,680 --> 00:04:39,890
Your public relations team is going crazy.

100
00:04:39,890 --> 00:04:41,690
Your site's down.

101
00:04:41,690 --> 00:04:43,720
That's not the moment you wanna
be coming up with solutions.

102
00:04:43,720 --> 00:04:45,610
When you're under that kind of pressure.

103
00:04:45,610 --> 00:04:49,320
You'd rather do it ahead of time when
you get your team together, and you

104
00:04:49,320 --> 00:04:53,530
have a conversation like, hey Mike, what
are some of the different options we have

105
00:04:53,530 --> 00:04:57,070
if we need to get this web server back up,
and you know that that's a good one,

106
00:04:57,070 --> 00:05:00,790
but let's call those guys and see if
we get some better information on that.

107
00:05:00,790 --> 00:05:04,460
You can do that if we have time,
when you can plan for it, right.

108
00:05:04,460 --> 00:05:06,410
That's why you want to
do this ahead of time.

109
00:05:06,410 --> 00:05:09,500
And that's why most
companies will draft up

110
00:05:09,500 --> 00:05:13,880
what's called a Business Resumption Plan,
or a BRP document.

111
00:05:13,880 --> 00:05:18,760
Now if you're an IT employee, or
if you're an IT Security Officer,

112
00:05:18,760 --> 00:05:22,070
then the odds are, you are involved
in the crafting of that BRP.

113
00:05:23,120 --> 00:05:27,060
If you're not in the IT department,
you may still have been involved.

114
00:05:27,060 --> 00:05:29,800
Your department that you're in,
let's say you're an insurance company, and

115
00:05:29,800 --> 00:05:31,620
you're in the underwriting department.

116
00:05:31,620 --> 00:05:34,230
Then the senior employees in
the underwriting department

117
00:05:34,230 --> 00:05:35,780
would have participated in the BRP,

118
00:05:35,780 --> 00:05:40,230
cuz they have to say here's the systems
we need to do our jobs, right?

119
00:05:40,230 --> 00:05:42,690
I worked for
an insurance company back in the day, and

120
00:05:42,690 --> 00:05:46,700
I still to this moment don't understand
how underwriters do what they do.

121
00:05:46,700 --> 00:05:47,420
Right?

122
00:05:47,420 --> 00:05:50,510
But I understand they need their
computers, they need their data, and

123
00:05:50,510 --> 00:05:54,280
somehow they make a decision as to whether
somebody should be insured or not.

124
00:05:54,280 --> 00:05:58,220
Well, they can tell me, well, Don,
you don't need to know how we do it,

125
00:05:58,220 --> 00:06:01,840
but here's the systems that we need
to make sure we can do our job.

126
00:06:01,840 --> 00:06:05,290
And then I know, in the BRP,
these are the systems they need.

127
00:06:05,290 --> 00:06:06,860
Right?
They don't actually need email to

128
00:06:06,860 --> 00:06:07,430
do their job.

129
00:06:07,430 --> 00:06:09,400
They don't need internet
access to do their job.

130
00:06:09,400 --> 00:06:11,890
But they do need the statistical
analysis software.

131
00:06:11,890 --> 00:06:13,910
They do need to be able
to run credit reports.

132
00:06:13,910 --> 00:06:17,080
So how can I provide that in a failure?

133
00:06:17,080 --> 00:06:18,670
And that's what we put in our BRP.

134
00:06:18,670 --> 00:06:22,920
How do we provide those critical systems
to keep those employees working?

135
00:06:22,920 --> 00:06:27,060
>> So then as an end user I might help
create this document by providing

136
00:06:27,060 --> 00:06:30,380
the information they need to make
the proper plan and decisions.

137
00:06:30,380 --> 00:06:32,180
I should also be familiar with the plan,

138
00:06:32,180 --> 00:06:36,480
because I might have a role to play in
the process of resuming our business.

139
00:06:36,480 --> 00:06:37,430
>> Yeah.

140
00:06:37,430 --> 00:06:41,360
Even if you weren't involved
in creating the plan, even if

141
00:06:41,360 --> 00:06:45,700
you were just hired on to the company,
and it's your first day at work, right?

142
00:06:45,700 --> 00:06:47,270
You still need to be
familiar with the BRP,

143
00:06:47,270 --> 00:06:50,400
because if a failure
happens what do you do?

144
00:06:50,400 --> 00:06:54,000
And you might just have one thing to do,
listen to your boss.

145
00:06:54,000 --> 00:06:55,590
It might be as simple as that.

146
00:06:55,590 --> 00:06:57,190
But sometimes it's very detailed.

147
00:06:57,190 --> 00:07:00,300
So for example,
at the bank we have where if our if our

148
00:07:00,300 --> 00:07:04,400
primary data center was destroyed,
where do the employees go?

149
00:07:04,400 --> 00:07:08,130
Because we had over thousand employees
that were right there in the headquarters.

150
00:07:08,130 --> 00:07:10,020
Where do they go if
the building's destroyed?

151
00:07:10,020 --> 00:07:11,580
Well, the surviving employees.

152
00:07:11,580 --> 00:07:13,070
The others don't really worry about it.

153
00:07:13,070 --> 00:07:14,970
But the ones that survive,
they know where to go.

154
00:07:14,970 --> 00:07:19,510
In the BRP, it said employees from these
departments will go to branch number 17,

155
00:07:19,510 --> 00:07:22,500
and employees in these other departments
will go to branch number 21.

156
00:07:22,500 --> 00:07:27,020
And so they had branches assigned that
they would go to that would be set up for

157
00:07:27,020 --> 00:07:28,230
them to do their job.

158
00:07:28,230 --> 00:07:30,670
If they went to a different branch,
it wouldn't be set up for

159
00:07:30,670 --> 00:07:31,410
them to do their job.

160
00:07:31,410 --> 00:07:36,160
Or if they stayed home, and they didn't
know, then then they were in the dark.

161
00:07:36,160 --> 00:07:41,410
So every single employee had instructions
in that BRP, not specifically.

162
00:07:41,410 --> 00:07:43,760
It didn't say, Mike Roderick,
you need to do this.

163
00:07:43,760 --> 00:07:47,180
It's all built around roles,
your have a job role.

164
00:07:47,180 --> 00:07:51,298
So if Mike is an IT Security Officer, he's
gonna have several roles throughout that

165
00:07:51,298 --> 00:07:53,852
BRP where it'll say
IT Security Officer does this.

166
00:07:53,852 --> 00:07:55,608
IT Security Officer does that.

167
00:07:55,608 --> 00:08:01,151
Or bank tellers from, you know, they
handle this department, go to branch 17.

168
00:08:01,151 --> 00:08:04,690
And it's based on roles, so that as you
add new employees or employees leave

169
00:08:04,690 --> 00:08:09,440
the company, that you don't have to go and
update the BRP every time that happens.

170
00:08:09,440 --> 00:08:11,140
>> Yeah, true, and
then it's a point of contact.

171
00:08:11,140 --> 00:08:12,960
There's gonna be another thing
that's gonna be listed in there,

172
00:08:12,960 --> 00:08:17,790
who I'm supposed to talk to in
the event of a business failure.

173
00:08:17,790 --> 00:08:22,780
>> Yeah, it's it's kind of like
the old phone tree system, right,

174
00:08:22,780 --> 00:08:27,260
where if something happened,
like a gossip tree.

175
00:08:27,260 --> 00:08:32,290
Where if something happened in a town,
one person would call two people.

176
00:08:32,290 --> 00:08:34,610
And those two people would
each call two people.

177
00:08:34,610 --> 00:08:37,150
And those people would reach out and
call two people each.

178
00:08:37,150 --> 00:08:39,650
And it branches out and spreads and
communicates to everybody.

179
00:08:39,650 --> 00:08:42,610
Well, in your BRP, you'll have
a communication plan like that because

180
00:08:42,610 --> 00:08:45,120
your normal means of
communications may not work.

181
00:08:45,120 --> 00:08:47,320
If your email server is down and

182
00:08:47,320 --> 00:08:51,850
that's your primary way of notifying all
employees, you got to have an alternative.

183
00:08:51,850 --> 00:08:55,080
And to have one person call every
single employee, that's not realistic.

184
00:08:55,080 --> 00:08:56,581
So you set up a phone tree.

185
00:08:56,581 --> 00:09:01,241
And Mike knows when a disaster
occurs he needs to call me and Tim.

186
00:09:01,241 --> 00:09:04,341
And then Tim and
I know that when a disaster happens,

187
00:09:04,341 --> 00:09:08,440
I need to call Vivian and Peter and
Tim needs to call Denise and Angie.

188
00:09:08,440 --> 00:09:10,560
They each know who to call.

189
00:09:10,560 --> 00:09:12,270
And then it starts to
branch out from there,

190
00:09:12,270 --> 00:09:16,160
and we get that notification even though
our normal communication means is down.

191
00:09:16,160 --> 00:09:16,700
>> Nice, nice.

192
00:09:16,700 --> 00:09:21,230
So it really does give us a plan of
action, what to do so that in the time of

193
00:09:21,230 --> 00:09:26,890
crisis or during the event, we don't have
to stop and think, we can just follow it.

194
00:09:26,890 --> 00:09:30,640
And these should be practiced,
we should probably put test these out.

195
00:09:30,640 --> 00:09:31,690
>> Oh yeah, yeah.

196
00:09:31,690 --> 00:09:32,600
When you draft a BRP,

197
00:09:32,600 --> 00:09:36,780
there's two main things you've got to
remember, it's kinda like having a pet.

198
00:09:36,780 --> 00:09:39,140
You can't just buy it and
stick it in a corner and

199
00:09:39,140 --> 00:09:41,570
forget about it, it's gonna die.

200
00:09:41,570 --> 00:09:44,670
In the case of a BRP it doesn't die,
it just becomes useless.

201
00:09:44,670 --> 00:09:47,080
There's two things that kill BRPs.

202
00:09:47,080 --> 00:09:49,110
One is that they don't get tested.

203
00:09:49,110 --> 00:09:51,860
You need to test that BRP,
otherwise it's worthless.

204
00:09:51,860 --> 00:09:55,040
If a failure happens and
you go to this untested BRP and

205
00:09:55,040 --> 00:09:57,470
something doesn't work, then you
just throw that plan in the trash,

206
00:09:57,470 --> 00:09:59,500
because now you've got to
come up with an all new plan.

207
00:09:59,500 --> 00:10:01,740
So it needs to be tested.

208
00:10:01,740 --> 00:10:05,140
The other thing is,
it needs to be updated, right.

209
00:10:05,140 --> 00:10:08,430
Systems change,
maybe you drafted this massive BRP,

210
00:10:08,430 --> 00:10:14,700
you spent thousands of employee hours
drafting an amazing BRP in 2010, right?

211
00:10:14,700 --> 00:10:19,630
And then in 2011,
maybe a new version of your your

212
00:10:19,630 --> 00:10:22,570
Linux distros came out or
a new version of Windows came out and

213
00:10:22,570 --> 00:10:25,080
you started migrating machines
over to this new version.

214
00:10:25,080 --> 00:10:28,420
Or just an application you use,
an update came out and

215
00:10:28,420 --> 00:10:32,600
now the instructions you drafted in
the BRP no longer match the software.

216
00:10:32,600 --> 00:10:33,800
When a disaster occurs,

217
00:10:33,800 --> 00:10:37,560
the instructions no longer work, and
you might as well not have a BRP, right?

218
00:10:37,560 --> 00:10:38,430
So, we need to update it.

219
00:10:38,430 --> 00:10:40,950
Whenever there's a signficant change
to our network infrastructure,

220
00:10:40,950 --> 00:10:44,480
to our company, to the way we do business,
the BRP has to get updated.

221
00:10:44,480 --> 00:10:49,390
And testing is how we spot areas where we
missed that, and we go through a test.

222
00:10:49,390 --> 00:10:52,250
We're, like, oh, shoot,
these don't match up.

223
00:10:52,250 --> 00:10:56,490
I ran into that during a BRP
test where we had an SSL VPN.

224
00:10:56,490 --> 00:10:59,600
And the software had
done a firmware update.

225
00:10:59,600 --> 00:11:03,310
And the user panels,
the user interface, had changed.

226
00:11:03,310 --> 00:11:05,980
Well, in our BRP we had
graphical instructions.

227
00:11:05,980 --> 00:11:08,130
So if you're an employee
at the home office and

228
00:11:08,130 --> 00:11:10,340
a disaster occurs, work from home.

229
00:11:10,340 --> 00:11:11,800
Here's how you connect to the SSL VPN.

230
00:11:11,800 --> 00:11:14,830
And it had the instructions, go to this
web page, log in with your credentials,

231
00:11:14,830 --> 00:11:16,190
you'll build a connection.

232
00:11:16,190 --> 00:11:18,710
The pictures didn't match, and so

233
00:11:18,710 --> 00:11:21,870
we had employees that would try
to follow these instructions.

234
00:11:21,870 --> 00:11:23,870
They would think they were
on the wrong website.

235
00:11:23,870 --> 00:11:26,190
Okay, I went to this,
it doesn't look like what's in the BRP.

236
00:11:26,190 --> 00:11:27,880
I didn't feel safe doing it.

237
00:11:27,880 --> 00:11:30,180
Well, thank goodness they felt that way,
first off.

238
00:11:30,180 --> 00:11:32,010
That's good security practice.

239
00:11:32,010 --> 00:11:35,580
But secondly, it highlighted
that we failed to update the BRP

240
00:11:35,580 --> 00:11:39,590
to reflect changes in our network
infrastructure, and so we updated that.

241
00:11:39,590 --> 00:11:43,642
We updated it during a test,
not during a critical moment and

242
00:11:43,642 --> 00:11:46,190
that that was a big deal, that helps.

243
00:11:46,190 --> 00:11:48,230
>> So,
it really is a living document then?

244
00:11:48,230 --> 00:11:52,980
You have to manage and maintain this
document on a regular interval?

245
00:11:52,980 --> 00:11:57,380
>> Yes, absolutely and
at least every six months.

246
00:11:57,380 --> 00:12:01,910
Maybe more frequently, depending on how
critical your outage is allowed to last.

247
00:12:01,910 --> 00:12:04,560
In the banking industry,
a lot of banks are insured by the FDIC or

248
00:12:04,560 --> 00:12:06,510
at least here in the United States.

249
00:12:06,510 --> 00:12:10,070
And the FDIC will allow
them 72 hours of downtime.

250
00:12:10,070 --> 00:12:10,780
>> Wow.

251
00:12:10,780 --> 00:12:15,000
>> If you have downtime greater than
72 hours, they take you over, and

252
00:12:15,000 --> 00:12:16,230
that's not something you want.

253
00:12:16,230 --> 00:12:21,040
So if you can only have
three days of downtime and

254
00:12:21,040 --> 00:12:24,330
your BRP is bad,
you put your whole bank at risk.

255
00:12:24,330 --> 00:12:28,000
And so they'll test as often as necessary
to make sure that doesn't happen.

256
00:12:28,000 --> 00:12:30,850
So your industry might not
be as stringent as that.

257
00:12:30,850 --> 00:12:33,810
You might not have that critical
requirement and so you might test

258
00:12:33,810 --> 00:12:37,980
less often, once a year or whatever,
but it is important to review it.

259
00:12:37,980 --> 00:12:42,450
>> So regular tests and then spot tests if
any time a major change in our network or

260
00:12:42,450 --> 00:12:43,160
something like that.

261
00:12:43,160 --> 00:12:45,450
We go back and review it just to
make sure everything's working.

262
00:12:45,450 --> 00:12:49,380
Personnel changes, numbers change,
that phone tree for example.

263
00:12:49,380 --> 00:12:50,820
That's gotta be kept up to date.

264
00:12:50,820 --> 00:12:53,840
>> Absolutely, yeah, and
we keep talking about this document.

265
00:12:53,840 --> 00:12:54,990
Let's take a look at one.

266
00:12:54,990 --> 00:12:58,840
There's a website out there on the
internet called www.SearchSMBStorage.com,

267
00:12:58,840 --> 00:13:01,960
and they've put out this
great BRP template.

268
00:13:01,960 --> 00:13:06,750
And what it's designed for is, if you're
in a small business or a medium business

269
00:13:06,750 --> 00:13:10,040
and you're like, man, where do I even get
started on creating one of these policies?

270
00:13:10,040 --> 00:13:10,990
The policies can be big.

271
00:13:12,160 --> 00:13:14,030
They usually are,
they have a lot of steps in them.

272
00:13:14,030 --> 00:13:17,520
This policy is empty, and
it's 28 pages long, right?

273
00:13:17,520 --> 00:13:21,026
So when you fill it out,
like the BRP at the bank we had,

274
00:13:21,026 --> 00:13:24,781
I mean, it was a massive stack,
it was hundreds of pages.

275
00:13:24,781 --> 00:13:27,711
Because it had step by step
instructions for a lot of things,

276
00:13:27,711 --> 00:13:30,060
how to get your company back in business.

277
00:13:30,060 --> 00:13:34,070
And it needed to be detailed like
that because it's really morbid,

278
00:13:34,070 --> 00:13:36,890
but what happens if your
entire IT staff is wiped out?

279
00:13:38,300 --> 00:13:42,200
Another IT company's gotta come in and
pick back up and get running.

280
00:13:42,200 --> 00:13:45,070
So, they need detailed instructions.

281
00:13:45,070 --> 00:13:48,170
And so what Search SMB Storage is,
they said, let's create a template

282
00:13:48,170 --> 00:13:51,330
that shows people the type of stuff that
might be in a business continuity or

283
00:13:51,330 --> 00:13:53,120

not we choose to read

00:01:54,940 --> 00:01:56,170

00:02:41,130 --> 00:02:43,630

00:02:43,630 --> 00:02:44,950
when it shouldn't have been.

00:02:44,950 --> 00:02:46,930
That's what these policies all define.

60
00:02:46,930 --> 00:02:50,470
Is the normal behavior that
would lead to those events not

00:02:50,470 --> 00:02:51,840

00:02:51,840 --> 00:02:53,500
So, the really, really useful.

00:02:53,500 --> 00:02:56,580
>> A lot of times we tend to think
of them as oh, this is the company

00:02:56,580 --> 00:03:00,160
trying to protect themselves against
litigation, or whatever the case may be.

00:03:00,160 --> 00:03:00,700
But.

A lot of times it's to protect us as well,
the employees.

00:03:03,800 --> 00:03:06,280
From some type of litigation
that might have occurred.

68
00:03:06,280 --> 00:03:07,540
So they are good.

69
00:03:07,540 --> 00:03:08,590
They have a good purpose.

70
00:03:08,590 --> 00:03:09,360
>> Yeah.

71

Now this security policies, they're
what are called top level documents.

00:03:13,140 --> 00:03:16,720

00:03:16,720 --> 00:03:18,060
But at the end of the day,

00:03:18,060 --> 00:03:20,750

00:03:20,750 --> 00:03:22,410
Your CEO, your President,

00:03:22,410 --> 00:03:25,330

running your organization.

00:03:25,330 --> 00:03:27,530
They're the authority behind the document.

00:03:27,530 --> 00:03:30,540
And they're basically dictating,
this is the behavior I want to see.

79
00:03:31,590 --> 00:03:34,460
If you deviate from that behavior,
you're outside the company norms and

00:03:34,460 --> 00:03:38,250
that may lead to termination or
other penalties, whatever.

00:03:38,250 --> 00:03:40,340
But this is what I expect, right?

00:03:40,340 --> 00:03:43,640
So at the top a little document,
down inside of it,

00:03:43,640 --> 00:03:45,490
we're going to be expressing
all sorts of things.

84
00:03:45,490 --> 00:03:49,410
What the purpose of that document is,
what it does, what we expect people to do.

85
00:03:49,410 --> 00:03:53,200
All sorts of other little pieces of
that puzzle that kind of fall together

86
00:03:53,200 --> 00:03:55,160
into making one of these.

87
00:03:55,160 --> 00:03:58,460
>> You know, we're going to, what their
purpose is and who it applies to.

Yeah, and that's the real tough because

00:04:10,420 --> 00:04:13,160

maybe if you know a little Latin.

00:04:13,160 --> 00:04:13,880
But if you don't,

93
00:04:13,880 --> 00:04:15,950
if you're your average run of
the mill employee, you can't read it.

00:04:15,950 --> 00:04:17,358
It doesn't make sense, and so

95
00:04:17,358 --> 00:04:19,751
those policies have to be
written more than one way.

00:04:19,751 --> 00:04:22,361
So there'll be a summary like
a generalization at the beginning.

00:04:22,361 --> 00:04:28,573
And then the real fine print that kind
of comes afterwards that really details

00:04:28,573 --> 00:04:34,490
things to a level that is,
they call it being unquestionable, right?

00:04:34,490 --> 00:04:37,370
That you can't Interpret
more than one way.

100
00:04:37,370 --> 00:04:39,490
Like, it's very well defined.

00:04:39,490 --> 00:04:40,840
This is what it means.

00:04:40,840 --> 00:04:42,900
And that's why it requires so much text.

00:04:42,900 --> 00:04:45,160
>> And this top level document,

00:05:01,260 --> 00:05:05,470

00:05:05,470 --> 00:05:06,050
not for the rest.

111
00:05:06,050 --> 00:05:08,280
So this kinda ties it all together.

112
00:05:08,280 --> 00:05:11,760
It makes sure that all those individual
